title: Sabres can't break Royals' rule
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Sabres can't break Royals' rule

 February 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 756
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GEORGETOWN, DEL. — They were separated by two points during their two regular-season games.And they were separated by two halfway through their third meeting.
That separation became wider though in the second half Monday, as Delmarva Christian School hit big shots in the paint and beyond the arc on the way to a 53-42 victory over Saints Peter and Paul High, giving the Royals their sixth Eastern Shore Independent Athletic Conference girls basketball title over the past seven seasons.
"Delmarva Christian played fabulous today," Sabres head coach Katie Murphy said. "I mean Bella (Marinelli), I think she hit just about every shot. I'd love to see her shot percentage from today. She was amazing. They all were. They played really hard. They executed correctly. They deserved to win."
And yet for the third time this season, this rivalry was shaping up to be a duel to the end. Sts. Peter & Paul (12-9), which came in on an eight-game winning streak, broke a 9-9 first-quarter tie when Kaylin Palmer (nine points) hit a bucket and Avery McCall converted one of two from the foul line for a three-point lead after one complete.
But the Royals (16-4) began connecting from beyond the arc in the second quarter. Marinelli, who drained four 3-pointers as part of a game-high 20-point performance, freshman Avery McCoy (nine points) and Layni Dukes (11 points) each hit 3-pointers, with Dukes' tying the game at 19-all with 1:31 left in the half.
Lucy Rankin kept the Sabres close, scoring six of her 12 points in the second quarter. A pair of Marinelli free throws and a Dukes layup moved Delmarva Christian to a 23-19 lead before Sts. Peter & Paul's Annie Albright scored to make it a two-point margin at the half.
The Royals began to widen their lead early in the third, as Marinelli buried a 3-pointer and Eve Bohinski (10 points) made a three-point play for a 29-21 lead. Emma Hainey's two free throws halted Delmarva Christian's mini-burst.
And though Sts. Peter & Paul remained within striking distance, the Royals began patiently working the ball around the perimeter before driving through the lane for layups that steadily extended their lead. Bohinski and Dukes each found an open lane for layups before McCoy's three-point play pushed Delmarva's Christian's lead to 36-26 late in the third.
"We made a couple shots that kind of got us going," Royals head coach Frank Roach said. "The first two games, jump shots weren't really falling much. I think that helped. And then we changed up our defense a little bit in that third quarter and that gave us a little bit of breathing room. I think the defensive switch is what kind of broke the game open."
The switch from man-to-man to a box-and-one helped Delmarva Christian outscore the Sabres, 13-7, in the third. Still, Sts. Peter & Paul stuck around, Palmer scoring the last basket of the third and the first of the fourth, drawing the Sabres within 36-30.
But Marinelli scored on a drive through the paint, hit a 3-pointer, watched Dukes score a layup, then drove through the middle again to give the Royals a 45-32 lead with under 4 minutes remaining.
"I told them to space it out," Roach said of his team's offense. "I know they (SSPP) were in a hurry to try to get some turnovers, get some steals. I said, 'Hey. Space the floor, use your handle. Let's attack the basket.' They did a good job attacking the basket."
Delmarva Christian's lead floated between 13 and 15 points before McCall, who notched her sixth double-double of the season with 15 points and 10 rebounds — both team highs — scored the Sabres' final seven points.
"I think nerves had a lot to do with it," Murphy said of her team. "I think in some cases we may have wanted to win too much instead of playing our game. Not settling into offense was a real huge thing. We were able to do that in the previous two games. And here they couldn't get their offensive rhythm no matter how many times we said, 'Run this offense. Do this. Slow it down.'
"Again, it's a young team," added Murphy, who has no seniors on the team. "They have grown a lot and continue to learn. They're a great group of kids who fought until the very end. There's no reason why they can't do this again next year."
Notes: McCall was named the ESIAC player of the year, and was joined on the all-conference first team by Rankin and Albright. … Hainey was honorable mention.

title: Bucs' Tucker Claxton looks to 3rd straight title
author: LUKE BONANNI Special to the Bay Times Record Observer
content:
Bucs' Tucker Claxton looks to 3rd straight title

 February 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LUKE BONANNI Special to the Bay Times Record Observer | Section: News 
 
 445
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — Senior Tucker Claxton has committed to Mount Saint Mary's for the fall. Claxton was a key piece to the 2023 State Championship for Kent Island High School's varsity men's lacrosse team and also contributed to the 2022 team that took home the state prize. This spring Claxton looks to lead the Bucs to a third-straight title.Athletics at KIHS have been very competitive and successful over the last few years. After two amazing years for the Bucs with the 2022 and 2023 graduating classes, Claxton's commitment to the Class of 2024 is unparalleled.
Lacrosse might be Claxton's best sport, but he's also been on varsity football since sophomore year. In 2022, the Bucs were eliminated in the state quarterfinals and looked to bounce back in 2023. That's exactly what they did. Led by Kasey Heath and Claxton, alongside many other key players the Bucs had on their stacked roster, they were able to make the state championship before falling just short to Milford Mill Academy. Claxton stated, "There are a few memories that stick out to me. One was being a part of the first team in Kent Island football history to make the state championship. Another was running out of the tunnel to see a couple thousand people supporting you week in and week out. Breaking the receiving record for Kent Island school history was very cool as well." Claxton broke this record in his final high school game in a quarterfinal loss to Huntingtown. Claxton has also been a member of the varsity basketball team for the last two years.
When asked about playing three sports during his high school career, Claxton said, "I haven't had more than really a week off since Covid. I'm always doing something as soon as one season ends I was right on to another. Even the summer was filled with football camp, workouts, and club lacrosse. But this has taught me great discipline and mental toughness which I think is a hard lesson to find."
Last year, Claxton's role on the Buccaneer lacrosse team increased dramatically. His father, Andy Claxton, holds second place as the all-time leader in face off wins at the University of Maryland, and last season served as the offensive coordinator for Kent Island. The state championship in 2023 meant a lot to Tucker Claxton. "Scoring the game-winning goal in the state semifinals, and winning the state championship with my friends and teammates I've known since kindergarten meant a lot to me. From playing together the whole time, and being able to hug my dad after to celebrate, that was always the dream," he said.
Luke Bonanni is a student reporter from Kent Island High School.

title: QA's Marks wins three region titles
author: Bill Haufe
content:
QA's Marks wins three region titles

 February 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 832
 Words 

 Read News Document

 LANDOVER — Ben Marks just wanted to get ahead of the traffic.He did and never allowed it catch him.
Queen Anne's County High's senior standout surged off the starting line through the first turn for a lead he never relinquished early Monday evening en route to winning the boys 800 meters for his third title during the Class 2A East Regional indoor track and field championships at the Prince George's Sports and Learning Complex.
"I chilled a little bit on my first two events so I was going to use the remaining energy I had to see what I could throw down in the 800," said Marks, who also won the 1,600 and 3,200 meters in convincing fashion before the 800. "I wanted to go out, race with integrity."
Seeded seventh, Marks started on the outside and drove immediately for the inside lane to get ahead of the pack and grab a lead coming off the opening curve. Shadowed by top seed Andrew Stein of Huntingtown through the bulk of the race, Marks never surrendered his lead, and never looked close to fading, crossing the finish line in a personal-record 1 minute, 57.60 seconds — 7 seconds ahead of Kent Island senior Giovanni Aguirre, who ran a PR of 2:04.29.
"I'm finally getting the speed under me," said Marks, who has clocked faster times in the 800 this season while running unattached in other meets. "I opened up pretty fast in this 800. I just wanted to get free of traffic because I knew my positioning wasn't ideal."
Marks admitted his legs weren't exactly feeling ideal after putting himself through in a tough workout just two days before.
"I knew going into today that my legs weren't going to be 100 percent fresh," Marks said. "That was OK because today is not the end-all, be-all. Obviously the main goal is outdoor, dropping down speed. My legs are a little heavy so me running that time, I'm not mad about it."
Marks, who won the same three events at last week's Bayside Conference championships, again began his string of title runs with victory in the 1,600 meters, where he ran a 4:35.27, finishing more than 7 full seconds ahead of second-place Trevor Thompson of La Plata.
Marks eased to the front as the lead pack thinned in the 3,200, settled into a comfortable pace, and again was never seriously challenged after moving into first, winning in 9:56.66 — 16 seconds ahead of runner-up Brendan Bischof of Huntingtown.
"Three wins today and we're moving on," said Marks, who will bid for his first state title at the 2A state championships on Feb. 19 at the Prince George's Sports & Learning Complex.
North Caroline's Brooke Sullivan, Autumn Vallee, Linda Ridgell and Seanna Rupp won the girls 4x800-meter relay in 10:40.48, edging second-place Patuxent (10:41.54).
Like Marks, Ridgell navigated her way through a crowded start in the girls 3,200 meters, found a steady a groove and remained in front while Calvert's Madison McCurry and the rest of the field gave chase for 16 laps.
"I just wanted to get a good start and increase my chances of getting first," said Ridgell, who won in 12:03.02 — 6 seconds ahead of McCurry.
The Caroline junior admitted she began to feel tired and sore, but felt confident she could win as the race reached the 11th lap.
Five days after clearing 7 feet, 6 inches to finish fourth at Baysides, Kent Island junior Siena Koch curled over the bar with personal-record 9 feet to win the girls pole vault. Koch was also part of the Bucs' 4x200 relay along with Grace Mathews, Naiya Grossman and Ava Tippett, who finished third in 1:53.61.
The top three finishers in each event qualified for states, or hit the standard time, height or distance.
Westlake (94 points) easily won the boys championship, but Kent Island took runner-up honors with 62 points, one point ahead of third-place La Plata.
In addition to his second place in the 800, Aguirre delivered another PR in the 500, finishing third in 1:07.48, and ran a leg on Kent Island's third-place 4x800 relay, joining Gunner Hansard, Hudson Scarlett and Caleb Heater to finish in 8:42.89.
Jack Morey cleared 13-6 to lead a 2-3-4 finish in the boys pole vault for Kent Island. Desmond Abbate placed third at 11 feet, and Qualib Carter was fourth at 10 feet. The Bucs also got big points from Jack Middleton, third in the high jump (6 feet) and Josh Fuller, who was fourth in the shot put with a personal-record 46-9.
North Caroline's Amir Long-Brown earned his way to states with a runner-up time of 8.47 in the boys 55-meter hurdles.
Ridgell led North Caroline to a third-place total of 48 points in the girls competition, which was won by Lackey (85). The Bulldogs also got points from multiple sources, with Amanda Snyder taking second in the high jump (4-10), Rupp placing third in the 500 (1:27.66), and Charlotte Stuetzle running a personal-record 2:40.64 for third in the 800.
Easton's Olivia Orrell placed fourth in the 1,600 with a personal-record 5:54.16.

title: USDA awards MARBIDCO funding to assist with expansion of livestock processing
content:
USDA awards MARBIDCO funding to assist with expansion of livestock processing

 August 16, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A5 | Section: News 
 
 545
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS - The United States Department of Agriculture recently announced it is awarding $3.8 million from its Meat and Poultry Intermediary Lending Program to the Maryland Agricultural Resource-Based Industry Development Corporation to finance the start-up and expansion of independent meat and poultry processing facilities in Maryland.MARBIDCO is a quasi-governmental economic development and financial intermediary organization with a mission to serve the commercial farming, forestry and seafood industries of Maryland.The USDA Meat and Poultry Intermediary Lending Program awards funds to financial intermediaries, like MARBIDCO, in the form of a grant to allow them to establish specialized revolving loan programs. The objective of the MPILP is to strengthen the financing capacity for small-and midsized independent meat processors, and to create a more resilient, diverse, and secure U.S. food supply chain.MARBIDCO is supplementing the USDA grant with another $1.3 million of its own funds to establish a special pool of lending capital of approximately $5 million.The Maryland Livestock Processing Loan Fund is designed to assist with the expansion of livestock and blue catfish processing capacity in Maryland. Farmers raising cattle, sheep, goats, and pigs still are facing very long lead times to get their animals processed, while blue catfish is an invasive fish species in the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries that is having a very detrimental impact on other species of fish and shellfish. Increasing commercial harvest and consumption of these catfish is one way to significantly reduce their numbers.Businesses engaged in the processing of livestock, or the invasive blue catfish can apply for a Maryland Livestock Processing Loan, which may also include an equity incentive grant of up to 10% of the project cost. Loan and grant proceeds can be used to purchase livestock processing and cold storage equipment, build or upgrade meat processing facilities, as well as purchase real estate on which the livestock processing activity will occur.MARBIDCO's Livestock Processing Loan Fund can offer standalone financing or work in conjunction with other financing provided by commercial lenders."This should be an incredible win for Maryland. The addition of new or significantly expanded meat processing facilities will positively impact many people within the food supply chain, from farmers and commercial fisherman to consumer's tables with these locally produced protein products," said MARBIDCO Executive Director Steve McHenry. "We are delighted to be a USDA grant recipient, and we want to thank the Maryland Department of Agriculture and our State's entire Congressional Delegation for their support of our application in what was a very competitive nationwide process." Loan amounts can range from a minimum of $250,000 up to a maximum of $2,500,000. MARBIDCO will charge a below-market fixed interest rate of 4% and will work cooperatively with borrowers on establishing other appropriate loan terms and conditions.An equity contribution of at least 7.5% of a project's total cost is required by the borrower (which can be matched dollar-for-dollar with a grant, not to exceed 10% of the project's total cost). The available equity grant match is coming from special funds appropriated to MARBIDCO by the State of Maryland to help enhance livestock processing capacity and cut down on long wait times.Further information and the program application form is available on MARBIDCO's website: www. marbidco.org. 
 
 Caption: PHOTO BY CONNIE CONNOLLY
 
Blue catfish fillets await skinning at the only USDA processing facility on the Eastern Shore.

title: Pastoral Ponderings: Getting back to the Gospel
author: Craig Gaunt
content:
Pastoral Ponderings: Getting back to the Gospel

 October 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Craig Gaunt | Section: Columns 
 
 279
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In times as divisive as ours, the church has the message and the practice to bring together and heal: The Gospel.God created all humankind in His image, and that means we all reflect that image one way or another in our common humanity. That image in each of us is the basis of our worth.
Sadly, each of us are also broken by sin, that image having been marred in us all. We cannot point a finger in condemnation at those different from us because we are all guilty of selfishness, wanting our own way rather than selflessly living for others. The line between good and evil is not between categories in which we try to separate ourselves from others; it runs down each individual human heart.
We know this because, if we are honest, each of us are capable of acts of great kindness or great wickedness. None of us are guiltless.
Yet, the good news, the Gospel says that God in His love has given each of us a chance to experience that love and to have that image restored in us. When we accept what God in Jesus Christ has done for us, turn from living as we once did, and believe in Him, then His restoration process begins. He makes us into a brand new person, with the desire to do the good that our world needs.
We are given the chance to be human the way God intended by enjoying a personal relationship with Him and showing His love to everyone.
The good news that can bring healing and peace to everyone is that everyone is equally a sinner and, at the same time, everyone is equally loved.

title: It's time for our nation to pray
author: T. D. Nichols; Denton Church Of Free Seventh Day Adventists
content:
It's time for our nation to pray

 October 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: T. D. Nichols; Denton Church Of Free Seventh Day Adventists | Page: 5A | Section: News 
 
 262
 Words 

 Read News Document

 If My People which are called by My name, shall humble themselves, and pray, and seek My face, and turn from their wicked ways; then will I hear from heaven, and will forgive their sin, and will heal their land. - 2 Chronicles 7:14The Bible tells us in Ecclesiastes 3: 1-8: "To every thing there is a season, and a time to every purpose under the heaven" There is a Christian hymn, "The Time For Praying Won't Be Long." Benjamin Franklin is said to be responsible for a usage that many of us have spoken or heard now and then, "Don't put off until tomorrow what you can do today." My friend, neighbor, fellow citizen, please consider the times in which you now live.In the true essence of things, no matter one's age, even if one is blessed to live to be a centenarian, in relation to eternity, one really does not have too much time to make sure as it is put by the Apostle Peter in 2 Peter 1:10," to make your calling and election sure: for if you do these things, you shall never fall." Think about it.Yet, if you are reading this, by the special grace of Jesus Christ, there is still time for you and for our God-given USA to turn to God.In this troubling, violent and irreverent age, we must call ourselves to the order of the God of Creation, and to the accountability and repentance for our declining spiritual condition and pray in humility and commitment to experience the promised healing of our person and of our nation.

title: Winston opens office support business in Preston
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Winston opens office support business in Preston

 May 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: News 
 
 525
 Words 

 Read News Document

 PRESTON — Savannah Winston is busy. She is a mother, she is working on a doctorate in education and she was recently appointed as president of the Preston Commissioners.And, she has just cut the ribbon on her new business support services building.
Winston has turned a 3,900-square-foot old bank into a multifaceted space to incubate other businesses.
"We do administrative support services. So part of that is to offer the business center services, you can come in and get your copies made, fax, scan, notary," Winston said. She also offers call center services and tax returns.
Her business's name is Van Tech Business Solutions. With it, she hopes to provide support to other local entrepreneurs.
The chamber of commerce has been a huge support in her efforts, Winston said, along with her friends, family and other community members.
"Tracy Snyder, director, she led the ribbon cutting ceremony. The whole community was there. People came from near and far. I had family that traveled in, and I had other businesswomen that traveled from the western shore to come over in support. My bishop was here to bless the building," she said.
Entrepreneurs see potential where others just drive by, Winston said. She is hoping to employ five people.
"That was one of the goals behind purchasing this property. As well as carrying out the vision of the mayor to bring economic development to the town. For so long this building was vacant. It has been a great six months of development," she said.
She reached out to the Maryland Capital Enterprise Women's Business Center in Salisbury to get help with her loan. She shared her business plan and didn't have any problem getting the funding, she said.
"This is all part of my leadership is to empower women in business, to really get out there. If you have a business, don't be afraid," Winston said.
Winston has a lot of space. Her own business needs only require about ¼ of the whole footprint. She plans to rent out the remaining space to long-term tenants as well as offer desks and office space for short-term business needs.
She has two renters already. One is Elegant Affairs event planning service and the other is Eternal Love Cleaning Service. There will also be a musical organ repairman, who will have his showroom in the back. She wants to open her front lot to food trucks.
"If you work from home or remotely, you can just come in and work in a different space or meet a client here. I also have more private office space you can rent by the day. Just go on my website and reserve your space for the day — you have a furnished office," she said.
She knows this will bring more businesses to town, another one of her goals, both as a businessperson and as a local elected official.
"If you want to see more businesses come to town, you have to lead the way," she said. "... I am an entrepreneur. It is all about bringing the resources to the community and allowing others to also to grow and expand their business opportunities. Why not do it together? I love partnerships and collaboration," she said.

title: Historic Christ Church bell to be restored
author: REBECCA PLACEK Special to The Star Democrat
content:
Historic Christ Church bell to be restored

 July 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: REBECCA PLACEK Special to The Star Democrat | Section: News 
 
 287
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — The Historic Christ Church Bell Tower in Stevensville will be restored with proceeds from the May 3 Maryland House and Garden Tour of Queen Anne's County.On July 7, board members from the Queen Anne's County Historical Society presented a check for $9,010 to Nancy Cook of Friends of Historic Christ Church.
Cook gave a talk on the 1631 founding of Kent Fort on Kent Island, the third-oldest permanent English settlement established by William Claiborne.
He and settlers built the first Christ Church on the south tip of Kent Island. In 1680, a new town and Christ Church were moved to the new town of Broad Creek, where Bay City is now. Then, in 1880, Christ Church was moved to the new town of Stevensville.
The new Christ Church was built in 1880 in Queen Anne style. The bell tower is in the "lancet" chimney style. Wooden pegs and bricks were reused from the earlier Christ Churches. Historic Christ Church recently was designated as the Arts & Cultural Center of Historic Stevensville.
Mike Thomas has researched the church bell. The bell was made in 1880 by the McShane Bell Foundry of Baltimore, America's oldest bell company, established in 1856. The bell is bronze, rings in C sharp, and weighs 400 pounds including the mountings. In 1880, the bell was shipped to the Rev. Thompson, Christ Church, Stevensville. Church bells are rung for religious and ceremonial purposes such as Christmas and for significant events such as weddings.
Donations also are needed for Christ Church upkeep. Checks may be sent to: Nancy M. Cook, 124 Bryce Road, Queenstown, MD 21658. Historic Christ Church is nonprofit organization registered with the state of Maryland. Donations are tax-deductible to the fullest extent of the law.

title: World War II veteran celebrates 100th birthday
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
World War II veteran celebrates 100th birthday

 January 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 1226
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Private First Class Kernie Thompson's nickname was "Young Boy" when he served overseas in the U.S. Army's 599th Ordnance Ammunition Company during World War II.That's because Thompson, at age 18, was the youngest of the 40 soldiers assigned to that all-African-American unit when he joined in 1943, the start of a two-year stint in which fought alongside his comrades in England, France, Belgium, Holland and Germany.
On Wednesday (Jan. 15), that veteran once known as Young Boy celebrated his 100th birthday, a milestone marked by a party in the Community Living Center at the Perry Point VA Medical Center, where the Baltimore native has resided since 2020.
There were party hats, lots of balloons, a beautiful birthday cake and Thompson's favorite candy — Hershey's Kisses, which he calls "silver bells." The party room was packed with people, including Thompson's fellow veteran residents, VA staff and members of his church family.
Among the party guests were Army officials, including Maj. General John Cushing, who is the Commanding General; and U.S. Army Combat Capabilities Development Command (DEVCOM) Command Sgt. Major Brian Haydt.
Thompson reportedly was his usual upbeat self during the party. Thompson relies on a wheelchair and is "not able to eat regular by mouth," but he remains "sharp as a tack" mentally, one longtime friend described. The new Centenarian has outlived his children and his friends from childhood and young adulthood.
Also at the party was the woman Thompson married more than 40 years ago, Clarice Thompson, his second wife, whom he nicknamed "Reesey." Thompson reportedly gets excited whenever he hears her name or learns that "Reesey" has come to visit him.
"He is the love of my life," Clarice said, before referencing his necessary VA residency and remarking, "I miss him, but I know that he is where he is suppose to be."
Thompson is soft-spoken and is strong in his Christian faith, according to a few party attendees who were interviewed.
He served more than 40 years as the chaplain at the oldest African-American owned and operated nursing home in the state, Maryland Baptist Aged Home in Baltimore, where he volunteered once a week.
A longtime member of a city Baptist Church, where he served as a deacon until age 94, Thompson also was active for more than 40 years in the Baptist Deacons Conference of Baltimore. In addition, Thompson provided usher, or deacon, training to parishioners throughout Maryland and other states, as part of an usher ministry associated with another one of the faith-based groups that he served.
"He's the kind of man who walks humbly and talks humbly. When he speaks, you listen," Clarice said. "He's the kind of man I would recommend any young people to just take a photograph of him in their mind and take on some of his characteristics — other than Jesus' characteristics."
Clarice added, "Not only was he disciplined in the military, he's a disciplined man as he walks with God."
One of the party attendees, Joseph Miller, president of that Baptist Deacons Conference of Baltimore, and his wife have been friends with Thompson and Clarice for more than 30 years.
"He is a wonderful guy. His smile is what gets you. He seems like a quiet person. His mannerism is quiet until you start talking to him. He's powerful. He talks softly, but carries a big stick," Miller commented with a chuckle. "He loves to talk."
Along those lines, Thompson's favorite topic of discussion: The Bible.
"He loves the word of God, and he will share it with you. When I come here to the VA center and talk to the residents, they always tell me what he taught them about the word of God," Miller said.
After retiring from his career as a Baltimore City maintenance worker, Thompson worked as an usher during Baltimore Orioles home games. He had that gig for three decades and was quite popular among spectators and all employees in the Baltimore Orioles organization.
"I was there when he got his 30-year ring, and he was proud of that (ring). They knew him well at the Baltimore Orioles, from the general manager, the manager, the players, the vendors, the mascot, and they all loved Kernie Thompson," Miller said.
An only child with an interest in woodworking, Thompson entered the U.S. Army at the tender age of 18 in 1943. Defending this country during World War II is among the many admirable contributions Thompson has made during his 100 years on this earth, thus far.
Thompson left his parents' West Baltimore home and traveled to Georgia, where he completed basic training. The military then sent Thompson to Camp Breckinridge in Kentucky, where he was put in the Army's 599th Ordnance Ammunition Company, which saw combat action after its deployment to Europe.
During a Cecil Whig interview two years ago, Thompson recalled, "Being overseas at war was a great experience, but some days were pleasant and some days were scary."
The following is an excerpt of some of the World War II remembrances Thompson shared during that interview:
Thompson noted that he enjoyed talking to not only his fellow soldiers, but citizens of the countries they were deployed to about their life and what it was like living in their country.
"They would ask about the United States and we would ask about their country and we would always talk to the people, we had a good relationship," Thompson said. "With the soldiers, we would play cards and everyone always had something to say to make you laugh."
But when Thompson and his fellow soldiers weren't playing cards, telling jokes or talking with citizens, they were receiving ordnance shipments, supplying soldiers with ammunition and exercising their knowledge from basic training — something Thompson said his survival was contingent upon.
"What they teach you is important to your life, especially in combat," said Thompson. "Your life might depend on what you were taught in basic training."
Thompson recalled that that training saved his life late one night in 1944, when his company was waiting for the arrival of a munitions shipment. After his group laid down to rest before the shipment arrived, they were awakened by the sight of enemy flares falling from the skies.
According to Thompson, flares were used to illuminate areas at night so planes and infantry could properly identify enemy soldiers, weaponry and other valuable targets — such as the ammunition holds that Thompson's unit was responsible for.
"Basic training taught us that when they drop flares, don't move and turn your face to the ground," said Thompson. "If you look up, the planes could see the glare of your face and it could mess up the dilation of your eyes. It was a scary night."
In 1945, after two years of his service, Thompson — who was then 21 — received word that the war was over.
"When we heard the war was over, it was a big joy," Thompson said. "We shouted and we celebrated. When I got back, the first thing I did was go with my mother to see my grandmother and we had a nice dinner and celebrated."
Following the war, Thompson got married, had a daughter and worked.
Reflecting on his wartime military service, Thompson commented, "Being a part of the Army and serving my county was one of the most rewarding things because I felt like I was fulfilling a duty that I owed to my country and it makes me feel good,"
Thompson then remarked, "I am a blessed man to be here."

title: Free family event: Frosty’s Holiday Village

title: CWDI Board President shares progress at Cambridge Harbor
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
CWDI Board President shares progress at Cambridge Harbor

 March 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 261
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — In a Feb. 29 news release, Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc. President Angie Hengst touched on some of the developments taking place at Cambridge Harbor.According to the news release, CWDI will unveil concept plans for a tree park and Memorial Garden along Byrn Street "shortly."
This park and garden is part of the larger Cambridge Harbor project that will develop space along the Cambridge waterfront. This project will include public spaces, a boutique hotel and residential and mixed-use spaces.
In the news release, Hengst said the tree park and garden will preserve Maryland's Champion English Elm tree and its twin, as well as honor those who worked at the former Dorchester General Hospital.
Also in the news release, Hengst shared that CWDI's Planning Committee met in February to discuss design plans for the East Gateway Park, at Route 50 and Maryland Avenue. Hengst said concept plans for this are almost complete. She said CWDI will share them with the public when they are complete.
For this project, Hengst said CWDI is working with local muralist Michael Rosato to create a new mural installation that would incorporate the current mural at the park along with new images that highlight Dorchester heritage.
"The park itself will have an educational component as well as provide visitors with a jumping off point to explore the rest of the city," she said in the news release.
CWDI's board will hold its next meeting at 4 p.m. on March 20 in the Dorchester Chamber of Commerce conference room. The open session portion of the meeting is open to the general public.

author: Staff Writer
content:
Easton podiatrist joins Orthopedic Center

 August 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Business 
 
 159
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Orthopedic Center has welcomed podiatrist Dr. Todd Albrecht to its provider team. The Orthopedic Center is an affiliate medical practice of University of Maryland Shore Regional Health, a member organization of the University of Maryland Medical System.Albrecht is well-known in the Mid-Shore community for having operated Easton Foot and Ankle Center since 1994. He earned his Doctor of Podiatric Medicine from the William M. Scholl College of Podiatric Medicine in Chicago, and his undergraduate degree in biochemistry from the University of Iowa in Iowa City, Iowa.
He completed his podiatric surgical residency at Central Medical Center and Hospital in Pittsburgh. He is board-certified in foot surgery by the American Board of Podiatric Surgery.
"We very pleased that Dr. Albrecht has joined our practice effective Aug. 12," said Orthopedic Center principal provider Dr. Thomas Stauch. "He has provided 20 years of exceptional podiatry care in our community that will contribute effectively to the growth of The Orthopedic Center."

title: Maryland gas prices stay almost level for week
author: Staff Writer
content:
Maryland gas prices stay almost level for week

 July 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: State News 
 
 455
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Average gasoline prices in Baltimore have fallen 0.4 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.44 per gallon today, according to GasBuddy's survey of 663 stations in Baltimore. Prices in Baltimore are 12.7 cents per gallon lower than a month ago and stand 30.2 cents per gallon lower than a year ago. The national average price of diesel has fallen 1.2 cents in the last week and stands at $3.78 per gallon.According to GasBuddy price reports, the cheapest station in Baltimore was priced at $3.19 per gallon yesterday while the most expensive was $3.99 per gallon, a difference of 80.0 cents per gallon.
The national average price of gasoline has risen 0.7 cents per gallon in the last week, averaging $3.47 per gallon today. The national average is down 0.8 cents per gallon from a month ago and stands 25.2 cents per gallon lower than a year ago, according to GasBuddy data compiled from more than 11 million weekly price reports covering over 150,000 gas stations across the country.
Historical gasoline prices in Baltimore and the national average going back 10 years:
July 29, 2023: $3.74 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.73 per gallon)July 29, 2022: $4.13 per gallon (U.S. Average: $4.21 per gallon)July 29, 2021: $3.07 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.16 per gallon)July 29, 2020: $2.28 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.19 per gallon)July 29, 2019: $2.59 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.72 per gallon)July 29, 2018: $2.76 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.84 per gallon)July 29, 2017: $2.25 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.31 per gallon)July 29, 2016: $2.06 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.13 per gallon)July 29, 2015: $2.63 per gallon (U.S. Average: $2.68 per gallon)July 29, 2014: $3.52 per gallon (U.S. Average: $3.51 per gallon)
Neighboring areas and their current gas prices:
Maryland: $3.46 per gallon, down 1.3 cents per gallon from last week's $3.48 per gallon.
Washington, D.C.: $3.64 per gallon, down 2.6 cents per gallon from last week's $3.66 per gallon.
Hagerston: $3.69 per gallon, down 4.5 cents per gallon from last week's $3.74 per gallon.
"We continue to see a mixed bag when it comes to gas prices across the country: states in the Great Lakes region are still being jolted by the Joliet, IL refinery outage, which has also impacted gas prices in some areas of Canada, while areas like the West Coast continue to see notable declines," said Patrick De Haan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy. "With the summer winding down and GasBuddy data showing disappointing gasoline demand and struggling oil prices, we could eventually see the national average falling a bit more, especially once the refinery in Illinois restarts operations. While hurricane season hasn't been a factor yet, it's also just starting to get into its prime, and that does remain a quiet wildcard for now."

title: Dare to do unthinkable
author: Mary Hunt
content:
Dare to do unthinkable

 August 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mary Hunt | Page: 28 | Section: News 
 
 323
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On an ordinary hot summer day in rural Georgia, just weeks before heading off for his first year of college, Scott Rigsby's life was to change forever.Riding in the back of a pickup truck after a long hard day of landscaping work, Scott and his buddies were laughing and talking about the upcoming weekend.Suddenly, and without warning, a passing 18-wheeler ran them off the road, sending Scott under a 3-ton trailer and dragging him more than 300 feet.By all human expectations, Scott should not have survived. But he did. And with horrific injuries. One leg was completely severed, the other left hanging by a thread - and he suffered third-degree burns all over his back.What followed were 26 surgeries, a second amputation of the leg that could not be saved, unspeakable depression, fear and uncertainty.In the blink of an eye, Scott's life changed from one with a bright college career ahead to one of unbearable challenges, dashed dreams and poverty.What kind of 18-wheeler has run you off the road of life? Is it unemployment?Divorce? Health issues?Whatever it is that has cut the legs out from under your financial situation, it's time for you to get up out of that recliner!Lost your home? Stop wallowing in self-pity. Pick yourself up and start looking for a landlord.Can't find a job? Maybe it's time to become your own next employer.Whatever it is that is keeping you deep in debt and a victim of a rotten economy, stop giving it power to hold you down!Give up looking in the rearview mirror of your life. What happened then is over now. It's done and there is nothing you can do to change it.You are stronger than you know and smarter than you think. Dare to think big and set goals to match - unthinkable goals!Mary Hunt is the founder of EverydayCheapskate.com, a frugal living blog, and the author of the book Debt-Proof Living.© 2023 CREATORS.COM 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Fire engulfs home on Cambridge's Race Street
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Fire engulfs home on Cambridge's Race Street

 August 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 202
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A porch fire, which is now being investigated by the State Fire Marshal's Office, engulfed a home on the 100 Block of Race Street around 10:30 a.m. Wednesday.Cambridge Rescue Fire Company's Assistant Fire Chief Andrew McCarter said five people were in the home at the time, but all of them got out uninjured.
"Thankfully, there was a fast response from Cambridge," McCarter said.
Thirty-six emergency personnel and 14 units from Dorchester, Talbot and Wicomico counties were deployed to the scene. By the time they arrived, the fire was too advanced to hear any smoke detectors, McCarter said.
The call came in to dispatchers as a working porch fire, which quickly spread to the rest of the home. McCarter said the fire took about an hour to put out.
McCarter said the Red Cross is working with the residents who were displaced by the fire while the fire marshal's investigation is underway.
"Support your local volunteers," McCarter said. "Smoke detectors save lives."
Once the fire was extinguished, the Rescue Fire Company purchased 20 pizzas from Carmela's Cucina. Carmela Lakovic provides officers, firefighters and EMS a discounted rate of 20%. "They're heroes, and I thank every one of them for risking their lives for us," Lakovic said.

title: Solar energy should not trample town's master plan
author: STEVE KLINE
content:
Solar energy should not trample town's master plan

 February 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STEVE KLINE | Section: Columns 
 
 871
 Words 

 Read News Document

 My love for the Chesapeake's Eastern Shore started in Chestertown.I used to visit each fall for the Chestertown Wildlife Exhibition and Sale, and it was one of my favorite weekends of the year — skeins of migrating Canada geese passing noisily overhead, a little bit of autumn in the air. That celebration of wildlife art was a fixture on Chestertown's fall calendar from 1965 to 2012, and it was my first exposure to the magic of Chestertown.
As with so many Eastern Shore towns, that magic comes from the close interplay of vista and village. Just a stone's throw from your favorite bookstore, you can enjoy the rural countryside in full by paddling Radcliffe Creek, cycling a scenic byway or photographing combines as they bring in the harvest.
Around the same time I was making those trips to Chestertown, not quite 20 years ago, the Eastern Shore Land Conservancy was working with Chestertown, Kent County and a professional planning firm to create the Chestertown Greenbelt Master Plan. The master plan was meant to encompass the future of the Clarke-Hopewell Farm, described by Chestertown Mayor David Foster as "our only real opportunity for expansion of Chestertown."
The nearly 500-acre farm, northeast of Chestertown's historic downtown, is one of the last remaining sizeable undeveloped tracts within the town's planning boundary.
This was just before the Great Recession. Real estate was booming, and there were plenty of questions about how development would shape the future of Chestertown and the entire Eastern Shore. Hence the master plan, developed with strong input from the community, to ensure that future development of the Clarke-Hopewell Farm would be an "organic extension of the historic fabric of the town," an effort to replicate in Chestertown's future what had worked so well in its past.
One of the questions asked at the inevitable community workshops during the process: "What defines the character of Chestertown and should be reflected in this new part of town?"
Responses included: "historic … small town feeling … neighborhood feel … walkable … life on a human scale." Those words do a nice job describing what works about Chestertown. The master plan hews closely to these ideas, providing a flexible and iterative development program designed to "accommodate much of the growth of the town and the county over the next 50–100 years." The plan includes hamlets and villages, each of which incorporates mixed-use buildings, civic uses and neighborhood greens.
But instead of human-scale hamlets and mixed-use neighborhoods, what now seems poised to occupy the Clarke-Hopewell Farm is a 45-megawatt utility-scale solar array. The array will send power straight to the grid, keeping lights on and computers buzzing in homes and businesses and data centers as far away as Illinois. And all of this has been planned despite clear and formal opposition from Chestertown and Kent County.
This change came about because the solar developer, a subsidiary of a massive Canadian-based asset management company, petitioned for and was granted a certificate of public convenience and need from the state of Maryland. What does that mean? Well, it's essentially a permission slip from the state, allowing the solar developer to simply ignore time-tested and well-understood local land use decisions.
This "preemption," as it's called, is being done in the spirit of addressing the challenge of climate change head-on, for which the state has adopted aggressive renewable energy generation goals. But in its rush to site solar power, the state has tilted the playing field. Parcels close to our towns and designated growth areas deserve careful attention, responsible land use and close examination.
In Chestertown's case, the state is trampling the town's best-laid plans and taking off the table a parcel that was meant to accommodate well-planned growth for the next 50 years or more. Instead of public parks, community orchards, apartments that young people can afford and easily bike from — instead of trees, a café, playgrounds, gardens, a barbershop or cottages — we'll have solar panel, solar panel, solar panel. More than 140,000 modules.
Solar panels do not need fertile soil. They do not need to have their hair cut and they do not bike to class in the morning. There are many other places solar fields can go. Where else is Chestertown supposed to go? There are not many other spaces the rest of Chestertown can grow into. At least not without contributing to what the Greenbelt Master Plan describes as the Eastern Shore's "auto-oriented suburban sprawl, which threatens to erode its rural character."
In the race to site solar power as quickly as possible, the Eastern Shore looks increasingly attractive. But we must have balance, a level playing field, some way to say, "Here or here, but not there."
Many of our open acres are best at producing food, and they should remain in agriculture. Other acres, located nearest our towns, are best suited for new neighborhoods. Some spots are well-suited for solar generation. But when we write a new set of rules that favor solar energy over all other land uses, there is no balance.
Rather than allowing Chestertown to "grow harmoniously … slowly and methodically as to maximize the efficiency of its land use," as the Greenbelt Master Plan so eloquently states, we will allow our land to be "rapidly digested." The Eastern Shore will lose.

title: Lt. Governor energizes Democrats at Unity Dinner
author: Laura Tayman
content:
Lt. Governor energizes Democrats at Unity Dinner

 October 18, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laura Tayman | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 481
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE - In the main hallway of the Kennard African American Cultural Heritage Center and Museum in Centreville last weekend, Maryland's Lt. Governor Aruna Miller greeted leaders of the Queen Anne's County Democratic Party for a short meet and greet before speaking to the awaiting audience of supporters."We have our work cut out for us," said Frank Alduino, member of the Democratic Central Committee in QA, when asked how support for the Democrats was faring.The Queen Anne's County Democratic Central Committee held what will now be their annual Unity Dinner, at the Center on Saturday evening, Oct. 14, providing Democrats across the county and state the opportunity to meet.Jordan Himes, political director for the Maryland Democratic Party, attended the event to "make sure we get as unified as we can as Democrats." {p class="p2"}In his introduction of Miller, Himes, whose grandmother is from the Eastern Shore and attended school in the Kennard Center, site of the former Kennard High School, said he was brought up knowing that you can never have the absence of hope."I encourage everyone here to use your voice," said Himes. "One voice can change one person, a person can change the county, the county can change the state, the state can change the country, and the country can change the world." In 2022, Maryland saw the most diverse ticket that's ever won in the history of Maryland. Miller thanked the audience for their support of the Moore/Miller ticket which won by the most votes in Maryland's history, and they were the only two people of color who ever won the office together in the United States.Miller told the audience they didn't vote for the Moore/Miller ticket to be the status quo. "You all wanted us to move boldly, decisively, and deliberately for all Marylanders. You elected us to leave no one left behind." Miller assured the crowd they had heard the voices of rural voters who told them that the only time they saw elected officials was during a campaign year. Because of this, Miller says, Governor Moore has decided to coordinate a tour bus of his entire cabinet to travel to every Maryland county and listen to the concerns of voters.Touting the success of the legislative session, Miller said the administration worked on raising the minimum wage; increasing services to Maryland veterans; providing high school seniors with a year-long, postgrad service option; increasing broadband services in rural areas; and ensuring training for abortion care providers."Things don't just happen, they are made to happen," said Miller. "We are fighting for equity and freedom. Let's all heal the world and make it a better place." 
 
 Caption: LAURA TAYMAN
 
Lt. Governor Aruna Miller joins the Queen Anne's County Democratic Central Committee members from top left, Tom Rider, John Stires, Connie {span}Lee Kratovil-Lavelle{/span}, Miller, Deborah Krueger, {span}Elaine McNeil, Frank {span}Alduino and in front, Lynn Mason with her grandsons.{/span}{/span}

title: Grasonville proposal looks to develop farmland for infill affordable housing
author: Staff Writer
content:
Grasonville proposal looks to develop farmland for infill affordable housing

 December 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 679
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GRASONVILLE — A proposed water and sewer amendment to supply a potential affordable housing development in Grasonville gained support during a public hearing Dec. 10.The proposal is to amend the property's water and sewer services to accommodate the development of 72 townhomes and 218 single family lots.
Located at 5400 Main Street, Aspire at Ewing Farm is a 112 acre property currently used for agriculture and is zoned Grasonville Planned Residential Neighborhood.
Flows from use are anticipated to be 72,500 gallons per day. Sewer service would be provided via a constructed gravity sewer pump station and water service would he provided by the Grasonville water system.
Sketch plan approval for the project was granted by the Queen Anne's County Planning Commission in October and met requirements of the Water and Sewer Master Plan.
The property has been part of the county's comprehensive water and sewer plan for a 10 year service since 2011, according to attorney Joe Stevens on behalf of developer K. Hovnanian.
The property has been ratified as part of the Grasonville Growth Area and zoned for planned residential development for decades.
The 2022 Comprehensive Plan highlights affordable housing as a high need in the county.
According to Mike Irons, division president of K. Hovnanian Homes of Maryland, LLC the Aspire Development will include "efficient homes without a lot of bells and whistles," aimed toward first time home buyers, workforce housing and affordable housing.
"We're bringing to the market something that the county needs," Irons said.
K. Hovnanian is also the builder and developer for the 55 and older Four Seasons Community.
Barry Griffith, planner with Lane Engineering, noted the location is an infill property surrounded by existing houses, schools and parks.
"We're a hole in a donut of development around us, and that's where we want new growth to go," Griffith said.
The property is located in a priority funding area, meaning the state and county have both acknowledged it as appropriate for state funding for future growth, he said.
Member of the Ewing family Mitchell Andrew noted the Ewings have been approached by local, regional and national developers over the years and "without a doubt" K. Hovnanian was the first that "really fit Grasonville," and met the needs of the county.
The public hearing saw over 10 in-person as well as six emails from residents voicing support for the amendment to move the development forward with resounding sentiment toward the county's need for affordable housing.
Agreeing the project met the needs of the county, Commission President Jim Moran noted the loose terminology of affordable housing that could change in the potentially two years before the development is ready.
Following potential commissioner amendment approval for sewer and water redesignation, the project would then move forward for additional approvals including site plan, subdivision and, Adequate Public Facilities Ordinance.
A public hearing was also held to consider amending the Queen Anne's County 2011 Comprehensive Water and Sewer Plan for Barnstable Lowery Farm's proposed development of 82 townhomes on a 11 acre lot in Main Street Chester.
The property is agricultural land consisting of two farms on either side of the three improved properties that are not included in the development proposal. The proposed development is part of Lowery Farm and Dream Farm. The portion adjacent to Main Street is zoned Town Center and the parcel to the rear of the site is zoned Countryside.
All residential development will occur in the Town Center zoning district.
Sewer services would be provided by Vacuum Sewer Collection Station 'G' and water services would be provided by the Stevensville/Chester water system.
Flows from the use are anticipated at 20,500 gallons per day.
The Planning Commission granted concept plan approval for the Barnstable Townhouse development in October and no anticipated off-site sewer or water infrastructure issues are associated with this proposal.
At public comment, Tracy Schulz, on behalf of Dream Farm ownership, spoke in favor of the project, citing the development appropriate for the area.
One email voiced concern for future developments' impact on water and sewer services on Kent Island, Grasonville, and Queenstown, and recommended posting projected usage numbers.
Public comment is still being accepted and a commissioner vote is expected at the Jan. 14 meeting.

title: Watson's impressive debut season reaches states
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Watson's impressive debut season reaches states

 March 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 660
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Shayla Watson went out for the girls wrestling team at Queen Anne's County High last year, but never had the chance to compete after suffering a preseason ankle injury.Despite that season-ending injury, Watson attended all the Lions' matches, and eventually became the team's stat girl.
She returned this season, and in her first exhibition match got pinned in 18 seconds.
A month and a half later, Watson faced that same opponent in a dual meet and pinned her in 30 seconds. Not long after that, the Queen Anne's junior pinned Northern Calvert's Emily Boling — ranked No. 1 in the state at the time — at the annual Queen of the Jungle tournament.
"She's been amazing all year," Queen Anne's head coach John Waters said of Watson. "She took fourth at Beast of the East and lost to the number two-ranked girl in the nation, 2-0."
Watson continued her impressive first-year roll last Friday night on her home mat, winning the 235-pound title during the girls Class 2A-1A East Regional tournament at Queen Anne's.
"She's very athletic," Waters said of Watson, who heads into Thursday's 2A-1A state tournament at the Show Place Arena in Upper Marlboro as the top-ranked wrestler at 235 pounds in the state. "So she can do things that other heavyweights can't do. That gives her a big advantage. And she's strong."
Watson (21-2) pinned Stephen Decatur's Amelia Gonzalez in 40 seconds in the semifinals before winning the championship final via a medical forfeit, joining senior Ally Conley as Queen Anne's only regional champs.
A two-time state champion, Conley (20-6) became the school's first four-time regional champ — male or female — when she battled off her back twice before earning a pin over Stephen Decatur freshman Calleigh McBride 34 seconds into the second period of the 100-pound championship bout.
"Ally's experience comes in and she doesn't panic when she's gets on her back," Waters said. "Being the first four-time regional champion from Queen Anne's County is pretty special."
Conley and Watson will have plenty of company in Upper Marlboro, as the defending state champion Lions qualified wrestlers in 11 of the 14 weight classes. In addition to Watson, Faith Connolly (2nd, 145), Annalise Michael (3rd, 105), Adyson Kendall (3rd, 120), Emmy Falcone (3rd, 125) and Linda Vail (3rd, 135) all qualified for states for the first time. They will be joined by Lilly Hammond (2nd, 140), Adelina Dickens (3rd, 155), Maggie Rooney (2nd, 170) and Kaylynn Bryant (2nd, 190).
Unlike the boys state tournament, where the top four from each weight class in the four regions qualify for states, only the top three girls advance to states. Queen Anne's Michael, Kendall, Falcone, Vail and Dickens each had to wrestle back and win their respective consolation final to qualify.
"Those girls, they knew that," Waters said. "So after their first loss of the night they knew they had to battle back. And they did. Addy Dickens had to wrestle a girl who pinned her earlier in the night.
"I sent them all messages after we got done cleaning up the mats," Waters continued. "Just told them how proud I was of them, because most of the girls missed at least two practices last week due to sickness. It was rough. We only had five girls at Monday's and Tuesday's practice, and they weren't the same five. For them to battle back and just, one, get their bodies ready to be able to compete, and then for some of them to lose their first match and wrestle back. It's been an awesome ride."
Who's going: Here's a list of other North Bayside wrestlers who qualified for the state tournament. The top three in each weight class qualify. Wrestlers are listed by school, their place at regionals, and weight class.
Cambridge-South Dorchester: Sienna Mitchell (2nd, 235); Colonel Richardson: Landine Dorleans (2nd, 120); Olivia McGregor (3rd, 140); Easton: Leah Gonzalez-Reyes (3rd, 110); Zelia Proa (2nd, 125); Thanh Mai Pham (3rd, 130); Khadija Popal (3rd, 170); North Caroline: Yelana Torres-Guzman (3rd, 235).

title: Pushing too far
author: Staff Writer
content:
Pushing too far

 March 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 130
 Words 

 Read News Document

 According to news reports, Gov. Moore is recommending an increase in Maryland's capital gains tax and an increase in the personal income tax. In each instance, the increase will only be for higher levels of income. Of course, such a tax will primarily affect those with the largest stake in the state's economy.In contrast, Canada's new prime minister recently announced he will not propose or support an increase in Canada's capital gains tax. While this may not seem especially perspicacious since the Canadian capital gains rate is already at 50%, it certainly does recognize a limit to what is economically sensible. It's wishful thinking but would be nice, therefore, if Canada's experience helped educate Gov. Moore and Maryland about the pitfalls of pushing the private sector too far.
ART CECIL
Easton

title: Ann Lord credits 'doing your own thing' as key to her 100 years
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Ann Lord credits 'doing your own thing' as key to her 100 years

 July 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: Caroline 
 
 458
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Born on June 16, 1925, Ann Lord celebrated her 100 birthday with a party on June 22, at The Residence at Eden Green in Denton where she lives.Lord enjoys animal watching at Eden Green. She has a bird feeder on her back porch where she can watch all different kinds of birds fly in.
Born in Hobbs, Maryland, Lord is the youngest of 11 children. She can recall when her family moved from Baltimore to Hobbs.
"My mother and father lived in Baltimore, and they came down before the new bridge was built; they had a ferry that came across," Lord said. "... My great-grandfather enlisted my dad in the Spanish-American War. So while he was in the war fighting, he came home on a weekend and married my mother who lived in Baltimore, and they both lived with my great-grandfather.
"My great-grandfather saw an advertisement in the paper, and it was advertising Hobbs, Maryland; they had a position open for a worker. Well, right away my great grandfather thought, 'Well, that's a good job for his son.' So they applied, and he got the job, that's how they got down here to Hobbs. They supplied a home for them to live in, and he took care of them."
Lord graduated from high school in 1943. She met her husband, Malcolm Lord, through her older brother. Malcolm graduated two years before Lord did, and she wrote letters to Malcolm during the time he was in World War II. When Malcolm came back, he married Lord in 1948.
Lord and her husband had four kids, five grandkids, seven great-grand kids and lived in Denton their whole life.
Right after high school, Lord began working at a bank in town for about three weeks, then after a conversation with the owner, she began working at Townsends.
After working at Townsends for seven years, Lord opened her own florist shop that was attached to her home in Denton.
After closing her florist shop, Lord worked for Caroline County Board of Education until she retired in 1986.
Lord's advice to a husband and wife having kids is to "think first."
"Think first about how your life is going to change completely," Lord said. "You just have to grow either with it or forget it. Most of them are forgetting it and getting divorces."
Although her age comes with a lot of wisdom, Lord regrets how forgetful she is at her age.
"The worst is is your forgetfulness," Lord said. "You really regret that you can't remember a lot of the things that were so important to you two years ago that now you forget about them."
Lord's advice to anybody going through life is to "do your own thing and decide what you want to do with your life and pursue it." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Caroline County Commissioners/July 8, 2025
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Caroline County Commissioners/July 8, 2025

 July 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 285
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — At its July 8 meeting, the Caroline County Commissioners took the following actions:Dr. Derek Simmons and CFO Jill Hignutt, Caroline County Board of Education, presenting their adopted fiscal year 2026 budget. Hignutt and Simmons explained multiple numbers within their budget including increasing administrators salaries to become competitive with neighboring counties. The commissioners also discussed Lockerman Middle School and the potential new location. Simmons said the Board of Education will keep a close working relationship with the commissioners throughout the process.Lori Bishop and Charlotte Brown provided an update on the addition to 4-H Park. The addition is almost complete, but the bathrooms failed inspection due to sinks being too tall and toilets being to far from the wall.Daniel Fox discussed Opioid Settlement Fund with the county commissioners. The county received $358,000 in local direct payments and $515,000 in target aid grants for opioid settlement. The county plans to talk with other departments and agencies to see how the fund will properly assist on a one-time basis.The county conducted the second reading and public hearing for an emergency bill on wastewater treatment facilities. The bill will allow for non-accessory wastewater treatment facilities to be permitted by special use exception, provided the facilities hold MDE discharge permits for five years and the proposed application is similar to the previous application. The Planning Commission had a positive recommendation. The commissioners moved the discussion to a third reading at their next meeting.During the county administration report, Kathleen Freeman told the commissioners about a conversation she had with Robbie Gill about a new YMCA in Caroline County. The commissioners are adamant about getting a new YMCA in Caroline County and believe the conversations need to turn into building.

title: Meeting, discussions at Cambridge YMCA heat up
author: Jim Johnson jjohnson@chespub.com
content:
Meeting, discussions at Cambridge YMCA heat up

 June 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jim Johnson jjohnson@chespub.com | Section: Columns 
 
 1318
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The gym was hot. Not unbearably hot, but close enough.Members of the Pauline F. and W. David Robbins Family YMCA in Cambridge filed into the gym on a blistering hot day to hear about plans for a new YMCA from the Y's leadership.
"Welcome to the world's largest sauna," somebody said as people picked up a bottle of water the Y provided for attendees.
Hundreds attended. Many of them were hot — not just because of the heat in the gym — but because they had heard about plans to move the YMCA to the proposed Cambridge Harbor site that is being developed by Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc.
They liked the Y right where it is on Talbot Avenue in Cambridge.
At the microphone was Robbie Gill. Much of the crowd's heat was directed at Gill, who is the CEO of the YMCA of the Chesapeake, the organization that oversees and runs not just the Cambridge Y but the 11 Eastern Shore YMCAs from Elkton in Cecil County to Pokomoke City and Salsibury on the Lower Shore.
I must say, Gill was cool. He was chill. People were angry, and they let him know it. I didn't see him sweating. He patiently answered questions after the crowd moved from the hot gym to the better air-conditioned lobby.
Let's say that a good part of the problem was self-inflicted.
The meeting was held less than two weeks after an email was sent out by the YMCA of the Chesapeake that led people to believe the organization had reached a deal with Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc. to build a new YMCA on the Cambridge Harbor site.
Both Gill and CWDI Executive Director Matt Leonard told the Star Democrat after that email landed in members in boxes that there is no such deal to build on Cambridge Harbor at this time.
The YMCA is advocating the need to build a new YMCA, Gill said in his interview with Star Democrat reporter Maggie Trovato. He said the existing site is not sustainable over the next two decades and can't provide certain programs, amenities and services.
He repeated that at the meeting with Cambridge Y members last Tuesday. I am not sure he changed many minds at the meeting.
Gill gave a presentation on a market study that tested three different sites for a new Cambridge YMCA facility. Two representatives from Triangle2, the firm that completed the market study, presented with Gill.
The three sites tested in the market study were the current YMCA location on Talbot Avenue near Gerry Boyle Park, Cambridge Harbor and a parcel on the corner of Maple Dam Road and Route 16, which is near Cambridge-South Dorchester High School.
Triangle2 CEO Lori Swann said 814 households were interviewed for the market study.
Swann said the current site and Maple Dam Road site did not test as well as the Cambridge Harbor site did.
According to the presentation, 73% of the interviewed county residents that were interested in joining the YMCA would be "very likely" to participate in a YMCA at Cambridge Harbor. The presentation showed that 61% felt that way about the current location and 42% felt that way about the Maple Dam Road site.
Gill said the market study made it clear that the community is in need of amenities that the current facility cannot provide.
During the question and answer portion of the meeting, member Phil Reed said his impression from the meeting was that Gill and the YMCA are sold on the waterfront site.
Kathy Abend, who has been a member of the YMCA for several years, said in an interview that she didn't think Gill seemed open to rebuilding on the current site.
"He was shutting this down," she said.
For the record, my wife and I are members of the Cambridge YMCA and work out there daily. We walk from our home to the facility, which we would not be able to do if the Y moved to Cambridge Harbor.
With that said, there are good reasons to build a new facility, and statistics from Y's elsewhere on the Eastern Shore support the contention that new facilities result in increased membership. Gill repeatedly brought up the experience in Chestertown, where a new facility resulted in a huge increase in membership, far exceeding projections when that project was started.
Gill also mentioned donors who have pledged the millions of dollars it will take to construct a new facility in Cambridge. Donor dollars are essential to a successful project..
Part of the problem the YMCA faces is its association with Cambridge Waterfront Development Inc. That organization has been shrouded in secrecy, secrecy that worries many in Cambridge that deals made behind closed doors may not be in the best interest of the town and its tax-paying residents.
While CWDI has shown more openness since Angie Hengst became president of the board this year, there is wariness dealing with the organization. You could see that wariness in the questions asked at the Cambridge Y meeting last week.
Probably the biggest fear — which may be unfounded but is still a fear — is that a backroom deal has been reached between the two organizations for the development of the Talbot Avenue YMCA property following a move of the facility to Cambridge Harbor.
"There has not been talk of a deal with the YMCA," CWDI Executive Director Matt Leonard said in an interview with reporter Maggie Trovato earlier this month, adding that the two groups do have conversations from time to time about the YMCA's interest in being a part of the project to develop space along the Choptank River.
Leonard said CWDI has had those kinds of conversations with multiple respondents of a July 2022 request for proposals. The YMCA was one of the respondents to that request.
The June 7 email the YMCA sent out included a "facility update" about banners the organization is replacing at its current Cambridge location on Talbot Avenue.
"As we work to highlight all the positives that come with building a new Robbins Family Y at Cambridge Harbor, we wanted to give you a sneak peak of the new banners," the email reads.
After the email was sent out, people on social media shared concerns about the YMCA's plans. Cambridge Association of Neighborhoods President Chuck McFadden said in an interview that when he saw the email, he was "taken aback," and he said the news was "buried" in an email about banners.
Gill, who has received emails and phone calls from concerned residents since the email went out, said the YMCA is advocating the need to build a new YMCA. He said the existing site is not sustainable over the next two decades and can't provide certain programs, amenities and services.
"We are trying to help frame a narrative because, right now, you have other people that are framing narratives that are just wrong," he said.
My opinion: I think the YMCA of Chesapeake should look closer at building new facilities on the existing site. In previous communities where I have been an editor, I have seen voters defeat bonds for new school buildings but then come back and approve bonds for projects where additions were built on to existing buildings.
The existing Cambridge YMCA is on 7 acres and offers space for sports fields and community gardens. Those would not be available with a move to Cambridge Harbor.
At the same time, a Cambridge Harbor location would be closer to U.S. Route 50 and would attract members from North Dorchester County and areas east of Cambridge, members who would not be interested in the current location deep in town.
I think either location with added amenities would attract members. It would be easier to build on a new location while keeping the existing facility operational, but with planning, the same thing could be accomplished at the existing location.
Members need to keep an open mind about a Cambridge Harbor location. At the same time, YMCA leaders need to listen to the concerns of its existing membership.
Jim Johnson is the executive editor of The Star Democrat. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Easton Town Council president candidates speak out against sign vandalism
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton Town Council president candidates speak out against sign vandalism

 March 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 460
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Candidates for Town Council president are speaking out against recent sign vandalism ahead of Easton's May 6 election.In a letter to police Thursday, current President Frank Gunsallus said he was notified that a swastika was placed on one of his campaign signs at the corner of South Aurora Street and South Lane. He said that came after "significant vandalism" of a number of his other signs.
"This act of hate has escalated the situation into a deeply troubling reality that demands our collective attention," Gunsallus wrote.
Don Abbatiello, the current Ward 2 representative running against Gunsallus for the presidential seat, said theft and vandalism do not belong in the town's elections.
In an interview Friday, Abbatiello said he informed Gunsallus of the defaced sign after discovering it while campaigning in town Wednesday.
"We obviously disagree on some issues, we're running against each other, but there's no reason to deface people's property," Abbatiello said. "There's no reason to bring hatred into this at all. We are still a community. We're still neighbors. We should act like it."
Gunsallus contacted the Easton Police Department after seeing the South Aurora Street sign. He also says campaign signs have been stolen from his home.
Abbatiello says a few of his signs have gone missing as well, though he's unsure if they were stolen or blew away due to wind.
Interim Town Manager Alan Lowrey, Easton's police chief, said an investigation into the defaced sign on South Aurora Street is underway. Lowrey told The Star Democrat that as for missing signs, some were taken down by town code enforcers due to violating town code.
Political sign violations include too many signs on one property or signs placed in a public right-of-way, Lowrey said. To avoid confusion moving forward, Lowrey has asked code enforcement to notify him of any signs not within the code so he can contact the candidate.
Lowrey says he's reached out to both Abbatiello and Gunsallus regarding signs that need to be moved or removed due to town code. Both candidates have complied, Lowrey noted.
Gunsallus and Abbatiello each denounced sign vandalism and acts of hatred.
"These types of things shouldn't happen during a campaign," Gunsallus wrote in a statement to The Star Democrat. "However, I'm hopeful this can be a turning point for our town to come together, reject hate, and foster love in its place."
"We're a community, we all live here together," Abbatiello said. "We need to get along with one another. And bringing in things like that, totally uncalled for."
Easton Police Department Sgt. Patrick Sally says stealing or defacing political signs are criminal offenses. He emphasized that many homeowners and businesses have security technology, such as Ring cameras, that can help identify those stealing or defacing signs.
"You're going to pay the price if you're caught," Sally said.
