title: Easton looking to go deep
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Easton looking to go deep

 September 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 984
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The 2023 high school football season wasn't the best of times for Easton High.Starting wide receiver Chase Raab was lost before the preseason. Quarterback Mikey O'Connor suffered a season-ending injury in Week 2. That injury list eventually ballooned to seven offensive starters, not exactly a recipe for a deep postseason run.
So head coach Matt Griffith inserted his younger players, hoping they would gain the experience needed to help the Warriors turn things around in 2024.
And what a turnaround it was.
All Easton did last season was go from a 1-8 in 2023 to 8-4, the biggest about-face in the program's past 40 years. That turnaround included a pair of playoff victories, the first time the Warriors had done anything like that in at least 40 years.
"We had a good year," said Griffith, who finished with the highest win total in his 10 years at the helm, and earned his 50th career victory when Easton defeated Kent Island in the second round of the Class 2A East Regional playoffs.
Now, Griffith and company want more.
"We're not going to rest on what we did last year," said Griffith, whose team joins Kent Island and Queen Anne's in the move from Class 2A to the 2A-1A ranks this season. "And while that was a successful season for some, we're going to choose success (based on) playing in the first week of December. If you're not going into the season thinking you want to play in the state championship game, then you got to change your mindset. We want to be better than we were last year."
Easton graduated seven seniors from last year, including O'Connor — now at Merrimack (Mass.) College — but return 17.
For the first time since 2018, an O'Connor will not start the season at quarterback for Easton. Brady Walls, a 6-foot-4, 210-pound junior who backed up Mikey O'Connor last season, takes control of an offense that looks solid at every spot.
"Size. Strong arm. High IQ," Griffith said of Walls. "He's a competitor. So he's going to put us in a good place. He's done a good job so far managing the offense in the preseason, and we're looking forward to hopefully a big junior year from him."
Griffith is also hoping to get some big games from his backfield, led by senior Dustin Blue (5-10, 212), sophomore Jamiere Copper (5-9, 200) and junior Jordan Horsey (5-11, 210).
"Physical, downhill runners," Griffith said. "We relied a lot on the running game last year with Mikey and a combination of the running backs. I think the running backs will take more of the running load this year. That's not saying Brady won't (run). But Brady won't run as much as Mikey did."
When Walls does drop back, he'll be looking at a receiving cast that has the potential to be among the Bayside Conference's best.
Lining up at wideout will be a combination of seniors Carter Mooney (6-0, 180) and Kent Island transfer Isaiah Diaz (6-4, 185), and freshmen Nicky O'Connor (6-1, 185) and Tatum Brooks (6-1, 180). There's also plenty of talent at slot, with seniors Zach Barnhart (5-8, 195), Kyree Acree (6-0, 175), sophomore Chad Stanley (6-0, 175) and Horsey.
"Isaiah, Nicky, Tatum and Chad are new to the system," Griffith said. "They're learning it. I think they are going to continue to get better as the year goes on. The more time we have for Brady to throw the ball and go through his progressions, the better off we'll be."
Providing that time for Walls and the holes for the backs is a seasoned group, led by three seniors — left tackle Tymiere Thomas (5-11, 275), center Jack Chapple (6-3, 225) and right guard TJ Truxson (5-11, 305). Junior Xavier Stowers (6-3, 240) returns from last year and starts at right tackle, while sophomore Brady Gilliece (6-4, 275) is at left guard. Junior Darrien Downes (6-2, 270) will be rotated in plenty.
"I think we're pretty happy with where we're at so far," Griffith said of his line. "We still have a lot of work to do. Great group. So they all return from last year, and Darrien is a nice addition to that starting core."
The defense also looks solid, returning nine of 11 starters from last year — it would have been 10 of 11 had senior Dionte Copper not suffered a season-ending injury over the summer.
Thomas and Stowers are at tackle, while senior Jeremiah Stanley (6-2, 185) and junior Messiah Joseph (5-9, 185) rotate at nose guard. Senior Tracey Groce (5-11, 285), juniors Elias Leonard (6-0, 315) and Braiden Fluharty (6-3, 225) provide depth up front along with Downes and Gilliece.
"Second year in the system with last year being the first in a new system under Al (Waters)," Griffith said of his defensive coordinator. "I think we're able to play a little faster. It's less teaching and learning, and more scheme and technique."
Linebacking could be a strength, with Jamiere Copper and Horsey starting inside, and senior Tayshaun Roberts (5-9, 215) and Blue setting up outside. Senior Alex Rhodes (5-10, 205) will get time inside, and juniors Teddy Antal (6-1, 185) and Nevin Whitaker (5-10, 215) figure to get snaps outside.
The secondary has senior Logan Friend (5-9, 165) and Brooks at the corners, though Diaz will also play there. Chad Stanley and Acree are at free safety, with Barnhart, Mooney and junior Jerrell Flanagan (5-10, 170) roaming at strong safety.
"I expect our defense is what kind of carries us early while our offense is still starting to click a little," Griffith said.
Seniors Kai Ferrias and Luke Stanco share the place-kicking duties, while Griffith can use either Axel Spalin or Horsey to punt.
"The Bayside's a tough conference to play in, and we're going to be challenged every week," Griffith said. "If our kids continue to do what we're asking them to do, and expecting them to do, we'll be able to compete with pretty much anybody that we play."

title: Nothing more difficult than taking lead on change
author: DAVID REEL
content:
Nothing more difficult than taking lead on change

 February 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DAVID REEL | Section: Columns 
 
 771
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Well before and since his swearing in on Jan. 20, President Trump has been moving aggressively to secure Senate approval of a team of cabinet and sub-cabinet members to implement his Make America Great Again agenda.To date he has achieved significant, but not yet universal, success on those approvals.
As I write this there are at least three of his nominations where final Senate approval is increasingly likely but not certain.
They are are Robert F. Kennedy Jr. for secretary of Health and Human Services, Kash Patel for FBI director, and Tulsi Gabbard for national intelligence director.
Earlier last month Trump's nomination of Pete Hegseth to serve as secretary of Defense was approved in the Senate by the narrowest of margins.
Following contentious committee hearings on his background and competence, Hegseth was confirmed only after Vice President JD Vance broke a 50-50 tie vote with a "yes" vote for him.
If any of the pending Trump nominations fail to receive full Senate approval it will be the first time since 1925 when a Republican controlled Senate rejected a Republican president's cabinet nomination. The president then was Calvin Coolidge and the failed nominee was Charles Warren for attorney general.
Trump's immediate Democratic predecessors — Barack Obama and Joe Biden had all their cabinet nominations approved by the Senate. In both cases there were Democratic majorities in the Senate and some of their more controversial nominations were withdrawn from consideration before full Senate consideration of their nominations.
The reasons for resistance to Trump are not surprising.
Over 500 years ago political observer and philosopher Niccolò Machiavelli wrote the following timeless observation on change:
"It must be remembered that there is nothing more difficult to take in hand, more perilous to conduct, or more uncertain in its success, than to take the lead in the introduction of a new order of things. Because the innovator has for enemies all those who have done well under the old conditions, and lukewarm defenders in those who may do well under the new. This coolness arises partly from fear of the opponents, who have the laws on their side, and partly from the incredulity of men, who do not readily believe in new things until they have had a long experience of them."
In 2024 Trump ran and won on a change platform and his commitment to take the lead in the introduction of a new order of things in Washington.
That is similar to the goal that former President Obama expressed when he first ran for the presidency.
Early and often on the campaign trail Obama said, "Washington is broken. My whole campaign has been premised from the start on the idea that we have to fundamentally change how Washington works."
After the election to his first term, Obama said with confidence that he had not miscalculated how difficult it would be to change Washington.
He said, "I didn't overpromise. And I didn't underestimate how tough this was gonna be."
After four years in office and his election to a second term Obama acknowledged with a combination of frustration, regret and self-reflection, that he had in fact miscalculated and underestimated how hard making changes was going to be.
He said "I'm the first one to confess that the spirit that I brought to Washington, that I wanted to see instituted, where we weren't constantly in a political slugfest … I haven't fully accomplished that. Haven't even come close in some instances. And, you know, if you ask me what's my biggest disappointment [it] is that we haven't changed the tone in Washington as much as I would have liked."
Time will tell if Donald Trump acknowledges and says much the same thing after the end of his second term.
The first test of success or failure for Trump will occur in less than two years.
In November 2026, all the seats in the House of Representatives and one third of the seats in the Senate will be up for election.
Historically, but not always, these elections are largely a referendum on a president's performance and agenda.
If the Republicans do lose control of the House or the Senate in 2026, any unapproved elements of Trump's MAGA agenda will likely be stalled, if not stopped completely.
Conversely, if that does not occur, the odds for success for Trump in continuing to advance his MAGA agenda are greatly increased.
It also increases the odds for Vice President Vance securing the Republican nomination for and winning the election as president in 2028.
Going forward, only one thing is certain.
Either way, we will soon be better able to affirm or challenge the thinking that in the political world, pursuing real change is often an exercise in futility, no matter who is elected president.

title: Vikings regain form, rout Trojans
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Vikings regain form, rout Trojans

 January 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 404
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — One night after its closest game this season, Cambridge-South Dorchester High's boys basketball team recaptured its dominating form.LaShaun Moody had 17 points and Sterling Perkins had 16 Tuesday night, as the North Bayside-leading Vikings rolled to an 88-66 victory over Kent County, raising their record to 12-0 overall, 10-0 division.
Koby Ennals added 14 for Cambridge-SD.
Jonah Somerville led Kent County (4-7, 2-7) with 23 points.
Moody scored a season-high 32 points on Monday, as the Vikings edged Salisbury School, 71-69, for their narrowest margin of victory this season. Samej Pinder had 14 points and Anthony Hughes and Perkins each had 12.
Piera Vazquez scored 25 to lead Salisbury School.
EASTON 65 COL. RICHARDSON 52EASTON — Marshall Bailey and Ja'Kai Brooks each scored 20 points Tuesday, as the Warriors (9-4, 8-2) won their fifth straight — not counting their forfeit loss to Cambridge-SD on Jan. 11.
On Monday, Bailey totaled 25 points in a 62-50 victory over Kent Island. Rayan Haq and Brooks finished with 12 points apiece.
Also Monday, Colonel Richardson's Dreden Lake scored 31 points in a 75-73 loss to Queen Anne's. Makiah Batson had 13 and Jazir Dickerson 11.
The Lions were led by Vince Gilberto's 28 points and Collin Woolford's 23 points. Queen Anne's (10-2, 9-1) has won four straight.
ST. MICHAELS 58 NORTH DORCHESTER 46SHILOH — Johnny Mautz scored 21 points and Nakhi Miller had 20 Monday night, leading the Saints (3-8, 2-7) to a regular-season sweep of the Eagles.
GIRLS BASKETBALLQUEEN ANNE'S 53 COL. RICHARDSON 35AMERICAN CORNER — Freshman Bea Holthaus notched her 10th double-double of the season with 12 points and 12 rebounds as the Lions pushed their record to 12-0, 10-0 Monday.
Holthaus also had five blocked shots. Laila Coles had nine points and four steals, RJ Ensor finished with seven points and 10 assists, and Emily Rendulic added seven points.
Ty Singletary's 17 points led Colonel Richardson (6-6, 4-6).
NORTH CAROLINE 56 ST. MICHAELS 12RIDGELY — Selaya Garrison's 12 points paced the Bulldogs to their fourth win in six games. Jasiyah Henry added nine points for North Caroline (6-4, 5-3).
SSPP 51 SALISBURY CHRISTIAN 15SALISBURY — Senior Morgan Quade scored a team-high 20 points and sophomore Avery McCall had 14 Tuesday, pacing Saints Peter and Paul in Eastern Shore Independent Athletic Conference play.
Sam Murphy finished with 11 points for the Sabres, who improved to 10-4 overall, 4-1 ESIAC.
McCall had 25 points and 11 boards Monday during a 48-44 loss to Seaford (Del.). Quade added 15 points.

title: TODAY IN HISTORY
content:
TODAY IN HISTORY

 December 29, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 16 | Section: News 
 
 324
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Today's Highlight in History: On Dec. 29, 1845, Texas was admitted as the 28th state.On this date: In 1170, Thomas Becket, the Archbishop of Canterbury, was slain in Canterbury Cathedral by knights loyal to King Henry II.
In 1812, the American frigate USS Constitution engaged and severely damaged the British frigate HMS Java off Brazil during the War of 1812.
In 1851, the first Young Men's Christian Association (YMCA) in the United States was founded in Boston.
In 1890, the Wounded Knee massacre took place in South Dakota as an estimated 300 Sioux Indians were killed by U.S. troops sent to disarm them.
In 1940, during World War II, Germany dropped incendiary bombs on London, setting off what came to be known as "The Second Great Fire of London." In 1972, Eastern Air Lines Flight 401, a Lockheed L-1011 Tristar, crashed into the Florida Everglades near Miami International Airport, killing 101 of the 176 people aboard.
In 1978, during the Gator Bowl, Ohio State coach Woody Hayes punched Clemson player Charlie Bauman, who'd intercepted an Ohio State pass. (Hayes was fired the next day.)
In 1989, dissident and playwright Vaclav Havel assumed the presidency of Czechoslovakia.
In 1992, the United States and Russia announced agreement on a nuclear arms reduction treaty.
In 2006, word reached the United States of the execution of former Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein (because of the time difference, it was the morning of Dec. 30 in Iraq when the hanging took place). In a statement, President George W. Bush called the execution an important milestone on Iraq's road to democracy.
In 2007, the New England Patriots ended their regular season with a remarkable 16-0 record following a 38-35 comeback victory over the New York Giants.
(New England became the first NFL team since the 1972 Dolphins to win every game on the schedule.)
In 2016, the United States struck back at Russia for hacking the U.S. presidential campaign with a sweeping set of punishments targeting Russia's spy agencies and diplomats.

title: Capital Region Honor Flight plans Oct. 3 trip
content:
Capital Region Honor Flight plans Oct. 3 trip

 September 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A2 | Section: News 
 
 346
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Honor Flight Network is excited to introduce Capital Region Honor Flight as the most recent hub to join the nonprofit organization's extensive network. Capital Region Honor Flight will serve veterans residing in Maryland, Delaware and the broader Washington, D.C. metropolitan area.This expansion aims to fill the void left by the discontinuation of Honor Flight Maryland's operations in the region. As with all Honor Flight trips, the experience is entirely free of cost to honored veterans.Under the leadership of Jenny Brawley, Capital Region Honor Flight is poised to make a profound impact, enlisting the support of dedicated local volunteers including Mark Brickell and Candi Johnson, among others.Capital Region Honor Flight is set to embark on its inaugural Honor Flight journey on Oct. 3. The trip will commence with 23 esteemed senior war veterans departing from Huntingtown Volunteer Fire Department in a memorable event made possible through the generous sponsorship of Mission BBQ. This trip reflects the community's shared commitment to honoring those who have selflessly served our nation.Capital Region Honor Flight trips for 2024 are already in the planning stages.Meredith Rosenbeck, CEO of Honor Flight Network, noted the significance of this newly created hub."We are thrilled to be able to serve the greater D.C. area again, now through Capital Region Honor Flight," Rosenbeck said. "While some veterans in the region may have independently visited the memorials built to commemorate their service, participating in an Honor Flight trip with other veterans brings an entirely new element to that experience. The shared camaraderie among veterans on an Honor Flight trip - combined with the outpouring of gratitude from the community - truly takes this experience to the next level." For veterans residing in the area, Capital Region Honor Flight extends a heartfelt invitation to apply for one of these transformative trips. To gather more information about Capital Region Honor Flight, or to apply as a veteran or guardian for a Capital Region Honor Flight trip, please visit capitalregion.honorflight.org.The public is invited to give the veterans a warm welcome back for this inaugural Capital Region Honor Flight trip.

title: Lions hope speed equals success
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Lions hope speed equals success

 August 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 761
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Brian Mooney brimmed with optimism his first two years as Queen Anne's County High's head football coach.As he enters this season, Mooney admits, "This is the happiest I've been in my three years (as head coach)."
Perhaps the biggest reason for Mooney's sunny outlook is the Lions' collective team speed. Of course, anyone seeking a second opinion on that topic can ask Donny Graef, who was Queen Anne's head coach for 25 years and is now in his second year back as an assistant.
"It's not the fastest," Graef said. "But it's definitely one of the fastest teams."
Pacing the fast cast is 5-foot-9, 165-pound junior Jadereon Thompson, who starts at wide reciever and safety, returns punts and kickoffs, and can go from zero to the end zone practically every time he touches the ball. He has plenty of fast company that includes senior running back DeRodney Smith (6-0, 170), along with senior Carter Dickey (5-8, 150) and sophomore Zavione Sudler (5-7, 145), who can spell Smith when needed.
"Jadereon's a burner," Mooney said. "So is DeRodney. Zay can go, and Carter Dickey's really fast."
The group behind them aren't exactly slouches in the 40. The McDonald twins, Alex and Alan — both listed at 5-5, 140, are at wide receiver, though Alex could see time at running back. The receiving group also includes senior Brooks Blodgett (6-1, 175) and junior Chance Hegedus (6-2, 185). Senior Dorrin Phillips (5-9, 215) returns at fullback with junior Hunter Kelly (5-10, 195) behind him.
Mooney said he will make a decision over the weekend on his starting quarterback, which has been a battle between senior Lance Arnold (5-11, 185) and sophomore Colton Starlings (6-3, 190).
If it can stay healthy, the offensive line could also be a strength. Senior Drew Sutton (5-11, 235) returns at center. Lining up on the right side are a pair of classmates, guard Brian Maleski (5-11, 210) and tackle Gannon Brown (6-4, 215). Senior left guard Levi Frank (6-0, 160) saw time as a starter last season and is flanked by sophomore tackle Austin Mattei (6-3, 215). Senior Jamison Woodward (5-10, 180) starts at tight end.
"Hopefully we don't have to have as many combinations as we did last year," Mooney said of an offensive line that was plagued with injury from start to finish last season. "They're growing. Austin is still learning. But if we can just stay healthy it should be a good group.
"Every one's bought into what we're doing," Mooney continued. "So everybody has bought into their role. The typical things that you're kind of coaching all the time we're not having to go back and do all the time. This group is locked in. This group is special."
There is plenty of speed and grit on the defense as well.
Frank and Phillips start at end with senior Ryan Robinson (5-11, 175) and junior Khalil Lively (6-0, 180) being rotated into the mix. Sutton returns at tackle and is joined up front by junior Brayden Combs (5-11, 220), with Brown and Mattei in the rotation.
Maleski starts at inside linebacker and is paired with Kelly, who was moved up from strong safety. Woodward is behind them.
The secondary has the potential to be very good, with Thompson, Smith, Dickey and senior Wyatt Wilhoit (5-9, 180) at the safeties, and Blodgett, Hegedus, Alan McDonald and senior Elijah Billups (5-9, 150) at the corners.
The special teams could also be among the Bayside Conference's best with Thompson, Smith, Hegedus and Sudler handling punts and kickoffs. Junior Adrian Altamirano has shown a big leg in practice and could have a big impact.
Mooney was encouraged by what he saw during last Friday's scrimmage against a bigger St. Paul's team. But like a year ago, the Lions are thin and hope to avoid the string of injuries that hampered last season.
"Last year we felt really good going into the season and then had a couple of bumps with health," Mooney said. "That's always the key for everybody. But I think the sky's the limit. I don't see any reason why this team can't go deep in the playoffs."
Queen Anne's will be part of the 2A/1A East Region this season along with Southern (Anne Arundel), Calvert, Lackey, Hammond and fellow Bayside Conference rivals Easton and Kent Island.
"We're just going to take it one game at a time," Mooney said. "I know that's coach-speak, but that's kind of how we have to be right now because of where we are in terms of numbers. We just got to re-evaluate where we're at every week and keep rolling. It's just an exciting time."

title: Scheffler storms into lead
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Scheffler storms into lead

 July 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: News 
 
 933
 Words 

 Read News Document

 PORTRUSH, Northern Ireland — The rain pounded Royal Portrush right when Scottie Scheffler poured in a birdie putt on his first hole Friday in the British Open. No matter. Nothing stopped the world's No. 1 player on his way to a 7-under 64 to build a one-shot lead going into the weekend.Scheffler made eight birdies on another wild afternoon of weather at Royal Portrush, and his 15-foot birdie attempt on the 18th stopped inches short for another.
The result was a one-shot lead over former U.S. Open champion Matt Fitzpatrick, who made four straight birdies to start the back nine until he cooled on the home stretch and had to settle for a 66.
The rain was heavy at times but never lasted long. The wind was breezy but never at strength that can cause fits. The scoring was lower, nearly two shots easier than the opening round.
Except for a few chasers, Scheffler made it look like it wasn't enough.
He was at 10-under 132 as he chases the third leg of the career Grand Slam, having won the PGA Championship by five shots in May.
Brian Harman got the best of the weather — surprising sunshine — and took dead aim in his hunt for another claret jug. Harman played bogey-free for a 64 that left him only two shots behind, along with Li Haotong of China, who had a 67.
Everyone else was five shots behind or more.
That includes Rory McIlroy, who went around Royal Portrush in his native Northern Ireland with plenty of cheers but only a few roars. McIlroy had a 69 but lost a lot of ground because of Scheffler, Fitzpatrick and Harman.
He started the second round just three shots behind. He goes into the weekend seven shots behind the top-ranked player in the world.
Fitzpatrick was at his lowest point just four months ago when he changed his caddie and coach and began pulling himself up. And now he takes that into the weekend against Scheffler.
"He's going to have the expectation to go out and dominate. He's an exceptional player. He's world No. 1, and we're seeing Tiger-like stuff," Fitzpatrick said. "I think the pressure is for him to win the golf tournament. For me, obviously I hope I'm going to have some more home support than him, but it's an exciting position for me to be in given where I was earlier this year."
Fitzpatrick was rolling along until a pair of short putts he missed, from 5 feet for par on the 14th and from 3 feet for birdie on the 17th. Even so, he holed a 25-foot par putt on the final hole and assured him being in the last group at 9-under 133.
Scheffler was sharp from the start. He hit eight of the 14 fairways — compared with three in the opening round — though his misses never left him too badly out of position. But he is seeing the breaks on smoother Portrush greens, and he looks confident as ever.
None of his eight birdies were closer than 7 feet. Five of them were in the 10-foot range and then he threw in a 35-foot birdie on the sixth. His lone bogey came on a drive into deep grass on the 11th that kept him from reaching the green.
The statistics led to a shrug.
"Overall, I'm hitting the ball solid," Scheffler said. "The tournament is only halfway done. I got off to a good start."
Harman was called the "Butcher of Hoylake" when he won the claret jug at Royal Liverpool two years ago because the British press was fascinated by the Georgia native's love for hunting. Now it's about his golf, and it was superb.
Harman played bogey-free, only once having to stress for par as Royal Portrush allowed for some good scoring in weather that again did not live up to its expectation.
Not that anyone was complaining. Temperatures were warm, at least by Irish standards. The breeze was noticeable without being overly punishing.
"They're very different golf courses, but the golf is similar," Harman said. "You've got to be able to flight your golf ball. You've got to know how far everything's going. Then you can't get frustrated. You're going to end up in funny spots where it doesn't seem fair, and you just have to kind of outlast that stuff."
The group at 5-under 137 included Harris English (70), Harman's former teammate at Georgia; Tyrrell Hatton of England (69) and Chris Gotterup (65), who wasn't even planning to be at Royal Portrush until winning the Scottish Open last week.
Also still around is Bryson DeChambeau, who made a 13-shot improvement from the first round with a 65. Still, he was 11 shots behind.
McIlroy wasn't at his best in the opening round and was pleased to be only three behind. Now he has a real mountain to climb. But at least he's still playing, unlike in 2019 at Royal Portrush when he shot 79 and then had a terrific rally only to miss the cut by one shot.
"I didn't have this opportunity six years ago, so to play an extra two days in this atmosphere in front of these crowds, I'm very excited for that," McIlroy said. "I feel like my game's definitely good enough to make a run."
That was before Scheffler began to run away from so many except a small collection of challengers. But this is links golf. And this is the Emerald Isle, where the weather seems to have a mind of its own.
Still, Scheffler has gone 10 tournaments without finishing out of the top 10 and would appear to present a challenge every bit as daunting as Royal Portrush.

title: A yacht to do: Bay Bridge Boat Show comes to Kent Narrows
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
A yacht to do: Bay Bridge Boat Show comes to Kent Narrows

 March 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 601
 Words 

 Read News Document

 KENT NARROWS — Setting sail into the boating season with a new charter, the Bay Bridge Boat Show is coming to the Kent Narrows area at Safe Harbor Narrows Point April 11 through April 13.After 26 years at the Bay Bridge Marina, the new venue at Safe Harbor Narrows Point promises to retain the spirit attendees love while strengthening community fellowship alongside even more amenities and better parking.
"We are extremely excited that we were able to keep the Bay Bridge Boat Show in Queen Anne's County and think the new location at Safe Harbor Marina Kent Narrows will only enhance the economic impact to the region," Heather Tinelli, director of Queen Anne's County Economic and Tourism Development said. "It is our hope that patrons of the boat show will stay overnight, enjoy all of our wonderful dining options, shop locally and of course buy a boat."
Whether boat enthusiasts looking to buy a new vessel or those looking for a day on the banks of the Chesapeake Bay, the powerboat show is complete with services, products, exhibitions and shipshape retail therapy.
Community and conservation are a focus of this year's spring power boat show, according to Annapolis Boat Shows' President, Mary Ewenson.
Committed to sustainability and conservation and environmental impacts, the boat show is proud to welcome numerous non-profits, and environmental organizations highlighting resources with free seminars, including the Department of Natural Resources, Coastal Conservation Association of Maryland, and the Department of Agriculture.
"Getting people excited about boats is a good way to get excited about the Chesapeake Bay. If you don't get out on the Bay you don't know it needs protecting, Ewenson said.
She is excited that by partnering with local businesses and building connections with the community, the show really connects with the community and emphasizes local involvement.
Welcoming attendees by land and water, both local and away, the boat show offers a unique opportunity to showcase the culture of the surrounding Kent Narrows, including additional shopping, restaurants, hotels, businesses, and the Cross Island Trail.
"It will really benefit the whole area. This is not a convention center, this is people's lives and businesses," Ewenson said of this year's show venue.
In addition to showcasing the local area, the boat show also seeks to provide accessibility to anyone with maritime interests, with onsite hands-on training available to make any land lubber sea worthy of a new vessel.
With new powerboats on the market to behold, an expanded demo dock will offer attendees the opportunity to climb aboard a wide array of powerboats of every style and size. From fishing boats and trawlers to pontoon boats and luxury cruisers, last year's powerboat show saw more than 250 boats, and at least as many are expected this season, she said.
"If you're a seasoned boater or a first timer, the show will offer something new for everyone to explore," said Annapolis Boat Shows' General Manager Sheila Jones.
Marine industry career networking opportunities will also be available alongside information about nearby boating clubs and schools.
And a great aspect of spring shows is that you can take your new boat out on the water right away, she said.
"Whether you're here for the boats, the education, or the food and entertainment, it's always a ton of fun. And the beautiful new venue means visitors may board even more exciting new powerboats and shop everything from gear and accessories to electronics, communication equipment, education, clubs, and more."
Shuttles will run between the lot at the old outlets off Exit 41 and the show.
An event certainly not to 'skiff', you can 'ketch' more information about the Bay Bridge Boat Show and other local shows at BayBridgeBoatShow.com.

title: Man charged with murder in fatal shooting
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Man charged with murder in fatal shooting

 June 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 724
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Investigators have filed murder charges against a man who allegedly shot a visitor at close range outside his residence near Elkton earlier this week during an incident that was caught on security camera video, according to Cecil County District Court records.The suspect — Donald Raymond Snyder Jr., 41 — reportedly surrendered himself to the Maryland State Police late Thursday night at the agency's North East Barrack, in accordance with arrangements that had been made amid the investigation.
Snyder is accused of gunning down Christopher Cimorose, 55, of Elkton, at approximately 9:20 p.m. on Monday in the driveway of Snyder's residence in the unit block of Locust Point Road, south of Elkton.
MSP troopers and other first responders rushed to that Locust Point Road residence at 9:24 p.m. Monday, after Snyder called and told a 911 dispatcher, "Someone just got shot," at that address, police reported.
"As the dispatcher was collecting the information on the call for service, she asked Snyder directly if he shot the gun. Snyder replied, 'Yeah'," according to the charging document.
At the scene, troopers spoke to Snyder and his 46-year-old girlfriend, Michelle McCarthy, before driving them to the North East Barrack, where MSP Homicide Unit investigators interviewed them, police said. Investigators secured Snyder's weapon, which had been placed in the bed of a pickup truck on the premises before first responders arrived, police added.
Paramedics pronounced Cimorose dead at the scene, police reported.
During the on-scene investigation, MSP detectives confiscated external security cameras on Snyder's property, after obtaining a warrant to do so, court records show.
Investigators note in court documents that "a few of the cameras" faced the driveway "where the intentional killing of Cimorose took place," and that they produced a video showing the fatal shooting and the events leading up to it.
Investigators had sent the confiscated DVR security system to MSP's Digital Forensic Lab on Wednesday, and technicians there extricated a 19-minute-long, motion-activated video clip of what occurred outside Snyder's residence on Monday night, court records show.
The video first shows Snyder and McCarthy exit the Locust Point Road residence and then get into McCarthy's vehicle in the driveway at approximately 9 p.m. Monday, with McCarthy sliding into the driver's seat and Snyder getting into the seat directly behind her, police reported.
About two minutes later, the video shows Cimorose pulling into that driveway in a red Nissan Versa, according to court records, which indicate that Cimorose was there to pick up McCarthy. The document does not provide a reason why Cimorose was there to pick up McCarthy.
The video then shows McCarthy exit her vehicle and walk to the front passenger's seat of Cimorose's Nissan and Snyder walk directly to the open window of the Nissan's driver's side door, police reported.
"Snyder almost immediately punches Cimorose in the head/face area, as he was still in the vehicle. As a response to being punched, Cimorose's vehicle lunged forward, dragging Snyder for a few feet," according to the charging document.
Before the Nissan came to a stop, Snyder armed himself, based on the footage, police reported.
"Snynder removes 9mm handgun from his waistband and points it at Cimorose. Cimorose places his vehicle in park, opens his door (and) attempts to get out of his vehicle — at which time Snyder fired three (3) times, striking Cimorose in the neck and chest area. Cimorose is observed falling to the ground next to his vehicle. Lying next to him was wooden table leg," court records allege.
During his police interview at the MSP barrack later that night, Snyder maintained that Cimorose was the aggressor, court records show.
"Snyder stated 'As far as I can see, the man grabbed a pipe and came at me.' Snyder also stated, 'I never wanted to do this'," according to the charging document.
MSP investigators consulted with the Cecil County State's Attorney's Office before filing criminal charges against Snyder on Thursday, court records indicate.
Snyder is charged with second-degree murder, a felony that is punishable by up to 40 years in prison if convicted, and five other offenses, including first-degree assault, use of a firearm in the commission of a felony or a crime of violence and reckless endangerment, court records show.
He remained in the Cecil County Detention Center on no bond Friday, after his bail review hearing earlier that day, according to court records, which show that Cecil County District Court Administrative Judge Bonnie G. Schneider presided over that proceeding.

title: Uninformed and fact deficient
author: Staff Writer
content:

 Words

 It grieves and saddens me to read Letters to the Editor from people who base their choice of presidential candidacy on personality, perceived state of mind, level of mentation and age to mention a few subjective analyses.The criteria that should be used in this selection process are what are that candidates' policy positions on the various serious issues our nation desperately needs to have viable solutions for.
Uninformed , vitriolic, personal and emotion laced comments speak volumes about how uninformed and fact deficient a significant segment of our voting population is.

title: Country Cooking: Inventive recipes from the 1940s
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Inventive recipes from the 1940s

 February 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1294
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Yes, it is that time of year again. And I do not mean Super Bowl, or Valentine's Day or tax time. It is a time that I let slip by quietly.I was born on Feb. 11, 194... My mother told me it was 3 degrees that February morning. I was born at home, so that meant the doctor traveled across town on snow- and ice-covered roads. My sister was 10 years old and at that time. I already had six older brothers, soon to be followed by three more brothers.
My sister's birthday was Feb. 15, and she did not want to share birthday parties. Some world and national news in the 1940s included the Italian partisans killed Mussolini, Hitler committing suicide after destroying major cities in Germany, World War II ending, Harry Truman taking the office of President after Roosevelt passed away.
Not only were things hard on our Bishopville farm, but the whole world was feeling the impact of World War 2. Creativity blossomed during the Great Depression and carried on into the 1940s.
The decade of the 1940s brought many things to our world: The microwave oven, ball point pens, Velcro, Tupperware and the frozen orange juice.
History has shown us again and again that financial hardship drives people to get a little more inventive in the kitchen.
Wartime rations necessitated substitutes and ingredient-stretching techniques. As a matter of fact, on the back of my birth certificate are stamps for sugar and flour. Thankfully, my parents never needed to use them.
After the war ended, food manufacturers explored methods that gave products a longer shelf life. During the latter half of the decade, more convenience products arrived on shelves as scientists delved into researching food preservation.
Like most 1940s recipes, meatloaf experienced a resurgence in popularity during the Great Depression. The use of bread or cracker crumbs helped stretch the ground beef as it was getting harder and harder to come by.
When the soldiers came back home from the Pacific they also brought home a love of SPAM. Philippines, Guam, Hawaii and Okinawa were places Spam was the most popular. Most of the time eggs were mixed with Spam because they were cheap and most everyone had chickens in the backyard.
"Victory Gardens" were another big thing in the 1940s. Many papers circulated various vegetable recipes. Soups and stews were cost-effective meals that could also stretch more precious ingredients such as meat and dairy.
No bake cookies that used things such as Corn flakes were served in just about all houses, even the White House.
One invention that has surely at one time or another been in just about everyone's hands — the corn dog — was created by German immigrants in Texas, who were sausage-makers finding resistance to the sausages they used to make. They have been credited with introducing the corn dog to the United States in the early 1920s, though the serving stick came later.
Carl and Neil Fletcher can claim that having introduced their "Corny Dogs" at the State Fair of Texas sometime in 1942. In 1946, on Muscle Beach in Santa Monica, California, Dave Barham opened the first Hot Dog on a Stick location.
So, as you see, the corn dog has a long disputed history, but boy are we glad to have it.
Here are some recipes from the 1940s this week to not only celebrate my birthday but to revisit a time where counting every penny and getting creative was a must.
HOMEMADE CORN DOGS1 cup yellow cornmeal, 1 cup all-purpose flour, ¼ cup white sugar, 4 tsps baking powder, ¼ tsp salt, ⅛ tsp black pepper, 1 cup milk, 1 egg, 1 quart vegetable oil for frying, 2 (16-oz) packages beef frankfurters, a pack of wooden skewers.
Combine cornmeal, flour, sugar, baking powder, salt and pepper in a medium bowl; stir in milk and egg to make a batter. Heat oil in a deep fryer or large saucepan to 375 degrees, pat frankfurters dry and insert a skewer into each one, roll frankfurters in batter until well coated. Fry two or three corn dogs at a time in preheated oil until lightly browned, about 3 minutes. Drain on paper towels.
1940s BROWN SUGAR MEATLOAFCooking spray, ½ cup packed brown sugar, ½ cup ketchup, 1 ½ lbs lean ground beef, 2 large eggs, 1 small onion (chopped), ¾ cup milk, ¾ cup finely crushed saltine cracker crumbs, 1 ½ tsps salt, ¼ tsp ground black pepper, ¼ tsp ground ginger.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Lightly grease a 5-by-9-inch loaf pan. Press brown sugar into the bottom of the prepared loaf pan and spread ketchup over sugar. Mix all remaining ingredients thoroughly in a mixing bowl and shape into a loaf. Place on top of the ketchup and sugar crust. Bake in the preheated oven for 1 hour or until juices are clear.
SPAM AND EGGS2 large eggs (beaten), 1 container fully cooked luncheon meat, 2 oz Cheddar cheese (grated).
Cube the meat. Heat a nonstick skillet over medium heat. Pour eggs into the skillet, then scatter luncheon meat over top. Cook and stir until eggs are nearly set, 3 to 4 minutes. Sprinkle cheese over top and stir until cheese is melted, 1 to 2 minutes.
GARDEN FRESH TOMATO SOUP4 cups chopped fresh tomatoes, 2 cups chicken broth, 4 cloves garlic, 1 large slice of onion, 2 tbsps butter, 2 tbsps all-purpose flour, 2 tsps white sugar to taste, 1 tsp salt to taste.
Combine tomatoes, chicken broth, garlic cloves and a large slice of onion in a stockpot over medium heat. Bring to a boil, and gently simmer for about 20 minutes to blend flavors. Remove from heat and run the mixture through a food mill into a large bowl or pan, Melt butter over medium heat in the now empty stockpot. Stir in flour to make a roux by cooking, whisking constantly, until the mixture turns medium brown. Gradually whisk in a bit of the tomato mixture to prevent lumps from forming, then stir in the rest. Season with sugar and salt to taste.
NO BAKE COOKIES½ cup white sugar, ½ cup light corn syrup, 2 tbsps butter, ½ cup peanut butter, 3 cups of corn flakes cereal.
Bring sugar and corn syrup to a boil in a saucepan over medium heat. Stir in butter and peanut butter until thoroughly combined, then remove from the heat. Place cornflakes into a large bowl. Pour peanut butter mixture over top and mix until cornflakes are well coated. Drop 1-tablespoon scoops of the mixture onto a waxed-paper lined baking sheet. Flatten slightly if desired, then allow to cool for 30 minutes before serving.
STUFFED PEPPERS
1 cup cold water,½ cup uncooked long grain white rice,1 tablespoon vegetable oil,1 pound ground beef,6 medium green bell peppers,16 ounces tomato sauce, divided,1 tablespoon Worcestershire sauce,¼ teaspoon garlic powder,¼ teaspoon onion powder, salt and ground black pepper to taste,1 teaspoon Italian seasoning. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Bring water and rice to a boil in a covered saucepan. Reduce heat to low and simmer until rice is tender, about 20 minutes. Meanwhile, heat oil in a skillet over medium heat. Add ground beef and cook until evenly browned and crumbly, 7 to 9 minutes. Hollow out bell peppers by removing and discarding the tops, seeds, and membranes. Slice the bottoms of the peppers if necessary to make sure they stand up straight. Arrange peppers in a baking dish with the hollowed sides facing upward. Prepare filling by mixing cooked beef, cooked rice, 1/2 of the tomato sauce, Worcestershire sauce, garlic powder, onion powder, salt, and pepper. Spoon an equal amount of filling into each hollowed pepper. Mix remaining tomato sauce and Italian seasoning in a bowl, and pour over the stuffed peppers. Bake in the preheated oven, basting with sauce every 15 minutes, until peppers are tender, about 1 hour.

title: Everybody has a role in suicide prevention
author: Andrew Moon
content:
Everybody has a role in suicide prevention

 September 1, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Andrew Moon | Page: A10 | Section: News 
 
 628
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For All Seasons is hosting a free community event, "We All Have a Role to Play in Suicide Prevention," from 7 to 8:30 p.m. on Thursday, Sept. 7, at the Avalon Theatre in Easton.The event is part of a powerful speaker series presentation led by suicide expert and leader within the Veterans Affairs' National Suicide Prevention Program, Dr. Andrew Moon, and facilitated by For All Seasons President and CEO Beth Anne Dorman. Participants will strengthen their awareness around the topic of suicide prevention, and learn how to reduce suicide risks, leaving attendees with the hope, readiness, and strategies to make a difference in their community.Moon will share his invaluable experience in averting crisis points before suicidality. He is a clinical psychologist with a career focus on trauma, suicide prevention, and education, and is currently the senior advisor for partnerships, engagement and education for the Department of Defense Suicide Prevention Office. He will share insights into national, state and local mental health data, specifically how suicide impacts specific groups, including veterans, first responders, LGBTQ+ populations, and youth.In addition, he will outline the pivotal role each one of us plays in suicide prevention, offering practical strategies for recognizing signs of struggle and responding effectively.Moon will share how to foster an environment of safety for those in your circle to prevent suicide and support those you care about.The month of September is No Matter WhatYou Matter Suicide Prevention Month and For All Seasons urges all citizens to actively work toward the prevention of suicide and to reach out to one another and ask - "Are you OK?" listen - without judgment, and share - vital resources to promote an inclusive and mentally healthy community.In the U.S., suicide is the second leading cause of death for people ages 10 to 14 and 25-34.In Maryland, suicide is the third leading cause of death for 10 to 34-year-olds. In 2021, 1 in 5 Maryland Mid-Shore teens ages 14 to 17 attempted suicide at least once.These statistics are staggering, and these deaths are often preventable.Checking in with someone could help save a life. If someone you know is showing signs of depression, withdrawal or unusual behavior, take time to check-in. Reach out to your circle of friends and family. Be attentive to those whom you have concerns about, and connect them to resources. There are proven treatments to help those with suicidal thoughts and behaviors.Someone experiencing a crisis may not recognize that suicidal thoughts are often temporary, and with professional support, hope and healing are within their reach.Ask: "Are you OK? Are you having suicidal thoughts?" Be direct and compassionate.Research shows that asking this question will not put the idea into someone's mind.Share: "You are not alone. Help is available." Connect them to services.For All Seasons is just a phone call away.Listen: You don't need to have all the answers. Be fully present without judgment. Allow the person to share their story.Most importantly, if you need suicide prevention resources and a step-by-step conversation guide visit: NoMatterWhatYouMatter.org. For All Seasons' 24-Hour Crisis Hotlines are English 410.820.5600 and Español 410.829.6143. English/Español Text is 410.829.6143. For the National Suicide & Crisis Hotline: Dial 988.For All Seasons provides the highest quality mental health and victim services to children, adults, and families across Maryland's Eastern Shore. Services are offered in both English and Spanish and include therapy, psychiatry, victim advocacy, 24-hour crisis hotlines, outreach, and community education.For information about For All Seasons walk-in hours, contact For All Seasons at 410-822-1018 or visit ForAllSeasonsInc.org.Caption: Pictured is Dr. Andrew Moon, suicide expert and leader with the Veterans Affairs' National Suicide Prevention Program, who will help facilitate the upcoming For All Seasons talk on suicide prevention on September 7 from 7 to 8:30 p.m. at the Avalon Theatre in Easton. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Federalsburg welcomes its new town manager
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Federalsburg welcomes its new town manager

 July 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: Caroline 
 
 159
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — The Federalsburg Town Council has hired Sally Slook as its new town manager."The mayor and council of Federalsburg are thrilled to announce that Sally Slook has joined the team as the new town manager," according to a statement from the town Tuesday.
"Sally brings a wealth of experience and expertise to the role, including a Master of Public Administration and 17 years of experience managing municipalities in Pennsylvania and Delaware," the statement read. "The town looks forward to her contributions in moving Federalsburg forward."
Slook previously served as director of building and housing for the Borough of West Chester in Pennsylvania. She has experience as town manager serving for Henlopen Acres in Delaware from July 2023 to May 2024.
Mercedes Moyer served as interim town manager since February after former Town Manager Kristy Marshall resigned.
While one vacancy has been filled, the town of Federalsburg's recent vacancy for police chief is still open after Joseph Gasser resigned on June 25.

title: Easton man sentenced to five years for sex offense
content:
Easton man sentenced to five years for sex offense

 September 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A2 | Section: News 
 
 162
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - An Easton man was sentenced Wednesday to five years in prison for sexually assaulting a teenage girl.Caroline Circuit Judge Heather Price sentenced Rysheim Gibson, 25, to 10 years in prison and suspended all but five years after Gibson pleaded guilty to a third-degree sex offense.The charge stemmed from the reported sexual assault of the teenager, which occurred last December in Caroline County.According to charging documents, Gibson provided the teen with marijuana and later sexually assaulted her in a home in Preston.Police investigation revealed that at the time, Gibson was registered as a Tier I sex offender in Maryland.A Tier 1 offender must remain on the state registry for 15 years.Gibson will receive 105 days of credit for time already served.Following his release, Gibson will be placed on five years of supervised probation and will be prohibited from contacting the victim.He will be required to register as a Tier II sex offender, a 25-year registry in Maryland.

title: ‘A gem’: State and local leaders celebrate Port Street Commons project
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
‘A gem’: State and local leaders celebrate Port Street Commons project

 November 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 596
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — A multi-use property bringing affordable housing and behavioral health services to Easton is officially complete.Port Street Commons, a 24,000-square-foot project led by The Arc Central Chesapeake Region, celebrated the end of construction with a ribbon-cutting ceremony that included local and state officials. The space houses nine apartment units as well as a headquarters for The Arc, complete with offices and a behavioral health suite.
Speaking to more than 100 attendees Thursday morning, The Arc President and CEO Jonathon Rondeau said the organization is "building a future where equity and inclusion are the norm."
"There will be people whose lives change within these walls because of the services they receive, the connections they make, the housing they can afford," Rondeau said.
The $11 million project, financed through a capital campaign, received $2.5 million in investment from the state and $750,000 in federal funding, Rondeau said. Chesapeake Neighbors, a housing subsidiary of The Arc, held a lottery in September for potential tenants that fell within the income requirements, with more than 250 people entering.
There are seven two-bedroom units and two three-bedroom units, all of them featuring free Wi-Fi and appliances. Two of the first-floor units are tailored to accommodate tenants with disabilities.
Members of the Easton Town Council and Talbot County Council, along with Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) and Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico), attended Thursday's ceremony.
Easton Mayor Megan Cook said the project is a fit for the town's goal to revitalize the area next to the Tred Avon River. She noted Port Street Commons is the first project to fall under the town's mixed-use waterfront zoning.
"We're eager to encourage mixed-use facilities such as this, allowing for exciting new businesses in tandem with more affordable housing, both of which are critical for growth in our community," she said.
The site at 480 Port Street was identified in July 2021, and construction began just under two years later. In an interview, Rondeau said the quick timeline helps The Arc fulfill the community's immediate housing needs, adding that the town was a crucial partner.
"There's a lot of development happening here in Easton," Rondeau said. "It's a small town, only so many inspectors and things like that. The town has been great. They've really worked with us to help meet those timelines when we had a problem."
Rondeau said four families who were randomly drawn have been confirmed, with the first of those moving in Dec. 2. All nine apartments should be occupied by March, he said.
Julia Glanz, deputy secretary of the Maryland Department of Housing & Community Development, and Carol Beatty, secretary of the Maryland Department of Disabilities, both complimented the housing project during the ceremony.
Beatty said the apartments tackle "one of the most common concerns" she hears from Marylanders with disabilities — a lack of accessible housing that is also affordable.
Glanz was excited about the project and hopes it can be an example for other mixed-use housing endeavors.
"It is, I think, a gem across the state," Glanz said in an interview. " … From what I've seen in the last year and a half, this is very unique. And it's bringing so many different facets of life into one space."
The deputy secretary noted that the House Expansion and Affordability Act of 2024, which encourages higher-density affordable housing projects, reduces government barriers. However, Port Street Commons completed most of its three-and-a-half year turnaround before that act was passed.
"The Arc being able to do that without that legislation … is a testament to the community effort here in Easton and Talbot County, which we don't see everywhere," Glanz said.

Celebrity Update

 December 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jay Bobbin | Page: D10 | Section: News 
 
 281
 Words 

 Read News Document

 David DuchovnyQ: It's been interesting to see David Duchovny back in the public eye for the movie he made with Meg Ryan. How long was he on "The X-Files"?A: The actor's run as FBI Agent Fox Mulder began in 1993, and he has said that he didn't expect the Fox series (now repeating on Comet) to last as long as it did, nor to be as popular as it became. His regular weekly run on the show went through the seventh season, when headlines were made by a lawsuit Duchovny filed against 20th Century Fox Television, alleging that it sold rights to repeats of the show to Fox-affiliated stations for less than they were worth thus costing him some profits.The suit was settled, but Duchovny's contract for the show was up, so he left as a full-time cast member (with Robert Patrick assuming the role of a Mulder surrogate, John Doggett). However, Duchovny returned for part of the eighth season, with the explanation that Mulder had been abducted by aliens.He also came back for the presumed series finale in Season 9, but as it turned out, he wasn't done with the show yet.Fox gave "The X-Files" revivals as a limited-run program in 2016 and 2018, which were deemed to be the 10th and 11th seasons of the show. Series creator-producer Chris Carter has inferred that there are more stories in that universe to be told, but any discussions of a continuation of the franchise haven't come to fruition. The show also yielded two theatrical films in which Duchovny played Mulder (opposite Gillian Anderson's Agent Dana Scully), "The X-Files: Fight the Future" (1998) and "The X-Files: I Want to Believe" (2008).

title: Corporate tax breaks end up costing schools
author: THE CONVERSATION
content:
Corporate tax breaks end up costing schools

 February 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: THE CONVERSATION | Section: National 
 
 1063
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Built in 1910, James Elementary is a three-story brick school in Kansas City, Missouri's historic Northeast neighborhood, with a bright blue front door framed by a sand-colored stone arch adorned with a gargoyle.As bustling students and teachers negotiate a maze of gray stairs with worn wooden handrails, Marjorie Mayes, the school's principal, escorts a visitor across uneven blue tile floors on the ground floor to a classroom with exposed brick walls and pipes. Bubbling paint mars some walls, evidence of the water leaks spreading inside the aging building.
"It's living history," said Mayes during a mid-September tour of the building. "Not the kind of living history we want."
The district would like to tackle the $400 million in deferred maintenance needed to create a 21st century learning environment at its 35 schools — including James Elementary — but it can't. It doesn't have the money.
PROPERTY TAX REDIRECT
The lack of funds is a direct result of the property tax breaks that Kansas City lavishes on companies and developers that do business there. The program is supposed to bring in new jobs and business but instead has ended up draining civic coffers and starving schools. Between 2017 and 2023, the Kansas City school district lost $237.3 million through tax abatements.
Kansas City is hardly an anomaly. An estimated 95% of U.S. cities provide economic development tax incentives to woo corporate investors. The upshot is that billions have been diverted from large urban school districts and from a growing number of small suburban and rural districts. The impact is seen in districts as diverse as Chicago and Cleveland, Hillsboro, Oregon, and Storey County, Nevada.
The result? A 2021 review of 2,498 financial statements from school districts across 27 states revealed that, in 2019 alone, at least $2.4 billion was diverted to fund tax incentives. Yet that substantial figure still downplays the magnitude of the problem, because three-quarters of the 10,370 districts analyzed did not provide any information on tax abatement agreements.
Tax abatement programs have long been controversial, pitting states and communities against one another in beggar-thy-neighbor contests. Their economic value is also, at best, unclear: Studies show most companies would have made the same location decision without taxpayer subsidies. Meanwhile, schools make up the largest cost item in these communities, meaning they suffer most when companies are granted breaks in property taxes.
A three-month investigation by The Conversation and three scholars with expertise in economic development, tax laws and education policy shows that the cash drain from these programs is not equally shared by schools in the same communities. At the local level, tax abatements and exemptions often come at the cost of critical funding for school districts that students from low-income households and who are racial minorities.
In Missouri, for example, in 2022 nearly $1,700 per student was redirected from Kansas City public and charter schools, while between $500 and $900 was redirected from wealthier, whiter Northland schools on the north side of the river in Kansas City and in the suburbs beyond. Other studies have found similar demographic trends elsewhere, including New York state, South Carolina and Columbus, Ohio.
The funding gaps produced by abated money often force schools to delay needed maintenance, increase class sizes, lay off teachers and support staff and even close outright. Schools also struggle to update or replace outdated technology, books and other educational resources. And, amid a nationwide teacher shortage, schools under financial pressures sometimes turn to inexperienced teachers who are not fully certified or rely too heavily on recruits from overseas who have been given special visa status.
Lost funding also prevents teachers and staff, who often feed, clothe and otherwise go above and beyond to help students in need, from earning a living wage. All told, tax abatements can end up harming a community's value, with constant funding shortfalls creating a cycle of decline.
INCENTIVES AND PAYOFFS
Perversely, some of the largest beneficiaries of tax abatements are the politicians who publicly boast of handing out the breaks despite the harm to poorer communities. Incumbent governors have used the incentives as a means of taking credit for job creation, even when the jobs were coming anyway.
"We know that subsidies don't work," said Elizabeth Marcello, a doctoral lecturer at Hunter College who studies governmental planning and policy and the interactions between state and local governments. "But they are good political stories, and I think that's why politicians love them so much."
While some voters may celebrate abatements, parents can recognize the disparities between school districts that are created by the tax breaks. Fairleigh Jackson pointed out that her daughter's East Baton Rouge third grade class lacks access to playground equipment.
The class is attending school in a temporary building while their elementary school undergoes a two-year renovation.
The temporary site has some grass and a cement slab where kids can play, but no playground equipment, Jackson said. And parents needed to set up an Amazon wish list to purchase basic equipment such as balls, jump ropes and chalk for students to use. The district told parents there would be no playground equipment due to a lack of funds, then promised to install equipment, Jackson said, but months later, there is none.
Jackson said it's hard to complain when other schools in the district don't even have needed security measures in place. "When I think about playground equipment, I think that's a necessary piece of child development," Jackson said. "Do we even advocate for something that should be a daily part of our kids' experience when kids' safety isn't being funded?"
A young student in the East Baton Rouge district told the school board that money going to tax breaks for corporations could provide better internet access or be used to hire someone to pick up the glass and barbed wire in the playground. But at least they have a playground — Hayden Crockett, a seventh grader at Sherwood Middle Academic Magnet School, noted that his sister's elementary school lacked one.
"If it wasn't in the budget to fund playground equipment, how can it also be in the budget to give one of the most powerful corporations in the world a tax break?" Crockett said. "The math just ain't mathing."
This article was written by Christine Wen, Texas A&M University; Danielle McLean, The Conversation; Kevin Welner, University of Colorado Boulder; and Nathan Jensen, The University of Texas at Austin. The Conversation is an independent and nonprofit source of news, analysis and commentary from academic experts.

title: McHenrys prove resilience is key in farming
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
McHenrys prove resilience is key in farming

 March 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 627
 Words 

 Read News Document

 KENNEDYVILLE — It's a comeback story for young farmers and entrepreneurs Joe and Jenell McHenry, one that's steeped in a little bit of a miracle.That story was documented by Maryland Public Television in a segment for their show, "Maryland Farm and Harvest" where Joe and Jenell told the story of Joe's recovery after overturning a tractor, sustaining life-threatening injuries.
With help from family, friends and divine intervention, the couple said, he's back working on his business, a direct-to-consumer beef operation, McHenry's Beef in Kennedyville.
The McHenrys' segment on "Maryland Farm and Harvest," season 11 episode 12, aired on Feb. 27, part of a program featuring farm safety where viewers met Brian Freese, a rescue instructor at the National Education Center for Agriculture Safety.
Robert Ferrier, series producer of, "Maryland Farm and Harvest," for three years now, has been inspired by farmers' stories.
"They're the hardest workers I know. And they truly love what they're doing," he said.
Always on the lookout for agriculture stories, after his team met Jenell, Ferrier knew there was a great story to tell.
"The McHenrys personify the current crop of young farmers," Ferrier remarked. "They're great people."
MPT spent about three hours shooting at the McHenry property, a farm that has been in Kennedyville since 1965, with Associate Producer Luke Fisher writing the script. In a fast turnaround, the episode was created in roughly three weeks.
Further into the episode, Clendining informed the audience that farming is one of the most dangerous professions.
The McHenrys can certainly attest.
In his own words, Joe talked about how sudden his accident happened.
Nov. 5, 2022, at 6:30 a.m., Joe said they just had two weeks of terrible harvesting conditions. He was stressed, driving his tractor on US state 298, and had just glanced away to look at the dew on the soybeans.
In that flash of a moment things changed.
His wheels hit fresh gravel, and the rear end of the tractor kicked out, flipping into the ditch.
"I wasn't sure if I yanked the wheel, but that was the last thing I remembered until I woke up," Joe recounts.
He sustained a broken pelvis, dislodged spine, a puncture wound and internal bleeding.
"I was in a bad place," Joe acknowledged. Jenell can clearly remember the disconcerting events.
As emergency services rushed to the scene, she got a text from Joe's sister, asking if Joe was helping assist with the accident.
Jenell tried to contact her husband, and when she didn't receive a response, she felt something awful just happened.
Her fears were realized, when she arrived by the roadside to see the flipped tractor and her husband being loaded in the ambulance.
Joe came to before he blacked out again, with the familiar voice of a first responder, a friend's, fading. He awoke again at Christiana Care emergency room before being placed in a medicated coma to allow for healing.
Jenell prayed.
"I asked the good Lord to keep him breathing with no brain injuries, and that's what I got," she said.
With his friends and family praying, Joe underwent an experimental surgery where rods and plates were placed to help him walk again.
As MPT's narrator put it, "He would spend the next 37 days in the hospital before moving to rehab."
Joe did recover, with friends, his employees, and the community at his side.
From strong adversity, the McHenry's keep going. Something that amazes Ferrier, even after his years of working for companies like Discovery, visiting exotic locales.
More than 16 million viewers have watched "Maryland Farm and Harvest" since its debut in 2013, Ferrier said.
"We celebrate agriculture in all its forms. Whatever you raise, grow or pick, we love telling the stories."
View episodes on MPT Tuesdays at 7 p.m., or past episodes at video.mpt.tv/show/maryland-farm-harvest/. Episode segments are available on the series' YouTube channel at youtube.com/c/MarylandFarmHarvest/featured.
Check out the McHenrys' products at McHenry's Beef on Facebook or Instagram.

title: Denton approves budget with lower tax rate
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Denton approves budget with lower tax rate

 May 7, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 530
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Denton Town Council presented and approved its fiscal year 2026 general fund budget and appropriations with a 2% lower property tax rate."We were able to lower the tax rate 3 cents," said Dallas Lister, a Town Council member, "which is a commitment that we've been trying to make each year, is to try to be as efficient as possible and not let the taxes increase where we can. This has been a lot of work on the staff, we really didn't have a lot of hard lift this year. We just set some priorities and staff made it happen, so it's spectacular."
The tax rate decreases from 69 cents per $100 of assessed value to 66 cents per $100 of assessed value on properties taxed within the boundaries of Denton. Town officials credit increased property values in Denton for being able to lower the rate.
"Because our property rates were higher, if we had stayed the same, people would have had the same tax rate but they would have been paying more money because of the percentage," McNinch said. "That's when when we decide to go down, the impact is, $40,000 roughly on our budget."
According to McNinch, the officials understand that some fees might increase, but they felt lowering the tax rate was the best decision for the town residents and for the council.
"We're aware that other taxes and fees might increase, but we need to hold our line ... we want to make sure we're providing the best services to our public and other things that might go up are county, state, utilities, that we don't have control over," McNinch said. "But with us trying to reduce and trying to put these things in place. We understand it's tough out there right now. It is for us too."
Denton tax revenues will increase by close to $150,000, while license and agencies revenues will decrease next fiscal year, according to the approved budget.
While a majority of the expenditures saw minor increases and decreases, Park and Recreation received the biggest decrease, dropping by $60,000.
"We've gotten things done," McNinch said. "We've gotten the Fourth Street Park done, we're partnering with the county, and the Sharp Road Park looks different. We've had park plans in place and and we've been able to get things done. So yes, that impacts the budget positively."
Tourism Visitor Center received a $14,000 increase, and Main Street received about a $4,000 increase in the budget. According to Mayor McNinch, Denton being named the first American Discovery Trail Town has an "impact on the decision."
"We want our visitor center open as much as possible," McNinch said. "We've been able to help support that a little bit more over the course of the last couple of years. We see the benefit of tourism for economic development.
"Things like the American Heritage Trail, we do see an increase in visitation to our visitor center. Those things are important, and we also increased the Main Street budget a little bit, because again that all works in trying to provide a community that people want to visit and want to live."
For more information on Denton Town Council fiscal year 2026 budget, go to dentonmaryland.com/departments/finance/tax-rates.

title: QAC achieves significant milestone in reducing marine industry plastic waste
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
QAC achieves significant milestone in reducing marine industry plastic waste

 July 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 440
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Queen Anne's County has achieved a remarkable success in its ongoing efforts to reduce plastic waste generated by the marine industry. The county's recent initiative to recycle single-use boat shrink wrap has resulted in a significant increase in the amount of plastic diverted from landfills.In the second year of the program, the Queen Anne's County government, in partnership with Plastic Free QAC and the Marine Trades Association of Maryland, has seen a 370% increase in the amount of recycled shrink wrap compared to last year.
This year, a total of six tons pounds of plastic shrink wrap was collected and recycled, a substantial increase from the 1.62 tons collected in 2023.
Queen Anne's County Commissioner Phil Dumenil expressed his enthusiasm, stating, "This significant increase in our recycling efforts underscores the dedication and commitment of our residents and businesses to protect our county. By expanding the availability of MTAM recycle bags and increasing the public awareness, we have made it easier for everyone to participate in this important initiative."
Key highlights of this year's success include:
Increased participation from individual boat owner with a notable rise in the number of individual boat owners participating in the recycling program, showcasing the community's growing environmental consciousness.Expansion of recycling bag pickup locations; the program expanded from one to four convenient pickup locations for MTAM recycle bags, including:West Marine in Chester, Rommel's Ace Hardware in Stevensville, Centreville Town Hall and Refill Goodness in Stevensville.Commitment from local marinas and boat companies. Several local businesses committed to responsible disposal of shrink wrap, among them: Bay Bridge Marina, Bosun's Marine, Atlantic Yacht Services and Pocket Yacht Company
The MTAM recycle bags, sponsored by the County Commissioners, were provided free of charge and made available at multiple locations. The dedicated MTAM shrink wrap dumpster at the Grasonville Transfer Station facilitated easy and eco-friendly disposal for boat owners from early April to June.
This initiative is part of Queen Anne's County's broader commitment to environmental stewardship and sustainability. By continuing to work together, the county aims to set an example for other communities across Maryland and beyond.
Plastic Free QAC started in 2018 with the mission to reduce single-use plastic usage in general and places focus on education and building public awareness, according to Sara Shelley, president of Plastic Free QAC.
"We are really thrilled with the community response," she said.
Understanding that old habits with single-use plastics can be hard to shake, Plastic Free QAC looks to continually build involvement by connecting with individual boat owners and hosting community-wide clean ups, Shelley said.
For more information about the recycling program, including where to pick up MTAM recycle bags and drop off cleaned shrink wrap, visit https://lnk.bio/RecycleBoatShrinkwrap.
