title: Memorial proposed to recognize US Colored Troops in Centreville
author: NIAMBI DAVIS Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Memorial proposed to recognize US Colored Troops in Centreville

 September 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: NIAMBI DAVIS Special to the Star Democrat | Section: News 
 
 699
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — For many years, Chris Pupke, past president of the Queen Anne's County Historical Society and advisory board member of the Kennard African American Cultural Heritage Center, has shared his knowledge of the county's African American history with the community through a series of lectures.His talks on the county's United States Colored Troops veterans, those enslaved and free men who gave their service and lives to the Union Army during the Civil War, have honored descendants and enhanced public knowledge of the county's diverse history.
On Aug. 13, joined by Jim Barnett, Tilghman Hemsley and Marcia Landskroener, Pupke presented a proposal to the Queen Anne's County Commissioners for the creation of a statue to honor the county's U.S. Colored Troops veterans.
Accompanied by visual aids, his presentation featured the regiments and military campaigns in which Queen Anne's County free and enslaved men courageously served. In describing the invaluable service of the nation's Colored Troops veterans, Abraham Lincoln proclaimed that "without the military help of the Black freedmen, the war against the South could not have been won."
More than 120 Queen Anne's County men fought with the 39th U.S. Colored Troops in the Battle of the Crater, part of the July 1864 Siege of Petersburg. They were trained to lead the attack until a last-minute change proved to be disastrous.
When the U.S. Colored Troops were sent in to salvage the operation, they discovered the mission was lost. "But they stood fast. These heroes stood in reserve, ready to do their duty, to honor their oath to the country, for which they paid a dear price," Pupke declared.
Sgt. James Bond of Centreville was enslaved by James Bordley of Centreville. Bond enlisted on Dec. 17, 1863 and was immediately made a sergeant. Bond may have been among the casualties of the Battle of the Crater.
In the fall of 1863, more than 125 men from Queen Anne's County enlisted in the 7th U.S. Colored Troops Regiment. The fight took them to the barrier islands from Hilton Head to Jacksonville. "You know these men were brave," Pupke said. "If you've ever walked the beach and seen the movie Glory, it was that kind of fight."
Particularly poignant was the recollection by Col. James Shaw of the September 1864 Battle of Chaffin's Farm: "Not a man faltered, but all who did not fall reached the work, charged boldly, and did all in their power to take it. ... they are all missing."
Before Queen Anne's County's Robert Riley enlisted in Company B, 7th U.S. Colored Troops Regiment, he had been enslaved on the Wye River. His Pension File included a surgeon's note of "scars of whip on back when a slave." But as a soldier, Private Riley was present at the Battle of Fort Gilmer and among his fellow African American troops at Lee's surrender at the Appomattox Courthouse. Riley is buried in Chesterfield Cemetery in Centreville.
To honor these men who fought for their freedom and for their country, a group of veterans approached Tilghman Hemsley with the idea of creating a statue in their memory.
"I thought it was a very worthy idea," he stated. After walking the grounds of the Courthouse, Hemsley believed the best placement for the monument would be set in the same promenade as the memorial honoring county prisoners of war. The inscription would include the quote by Abraham Lincoln with the U.S. Colored Troops story engraved in granite.
Hemsley shared concept drawings of the proposed statue with completion for the monument expected for 2025.
On Sept. 7, from 5 to 7 p.m., the Queen Anne's County Historical Society will host a free fall picnic at Wright's Chance, located at 119 S. Commerce St. in Centreville. This event replaces the July event, which was postponed due to the intense heat experienced throughout the entire month.
Pupke will discuss Queen Anne's County US Colored Troops history. Kay Brown, a member of Bryan's United Methodist Church, will share church history and the success of Bryan's United Methodist Church in preserving a significant piece of Queen Anne's County history.
This opportunity was provided by a grant awarded to the church by the Maryland Commission on African American History and Culture and the Maryland Historical Trust's African American Heritage Preservation Program. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 'We can turn lightbulbs on'
author: Staff Writer
content:
'We can turn lightbulbs on'

 April 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 318
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Thank you for Maggie Trovato's uplifting article, "We Can Turn Lightbulbs On." It offered a rare but welcome dose of hope.The piece spotlighted the work of three retired health care professionals — led by Dr. Judy Gieske — along with a team of volunteers launching Introduction to Careers in Healthcare (ITCH), a program designed to spark and sustain student interest in health care careers from middle through high school. It will serve Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties.
The timing couldn't be better. Construction has finally begun next to the Talbot Community Center on a long-promised, modern inpatient medical facility — expected to open in 2028. Yet even the most advanced hospital is useless without skilled, dedicated staff.
Our current Memorial Hospital depends heavily on traveling doctors and nurses. While competent and committed, they aren't rooted in our community. Many of us remember a time when our health care providers lived next door, when nurses were trained locally at the McQueen-Gibbs School, and when the hospital was the region's largest employer. The quality of care felt stronger because the staff had a personal stake in our well-being.
Memorial Hospital once helped drive local economic growth. Quality health care made Talbot County attractive to retirees, professionals, and families alike — people drawn to both the lifestyle and the peace of mind that came with reliable, community-centered care.
The ITCH program aims to reignite that connection by:
Introducing health care careers early.Supporting local students through their journey.Building a skilled, homegrown workforce.Reconnecting the hospital and the community.
These are long-term goals, but the potential return on investment is huge — economically and socially.
I urge my neighbors to support ITCH in any way they can. Whether through mentorship, donations or spreading the word, every effort matters. Let's bring the hospital back to the community — and the community back to the hospital.
Thanks to the Star-Democrat for shining a light on this promising initiative.
HUGH M. SMITH
Easton

title: Residents eager as St. Michaels considers dog park locations
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Residents eager as St. Michaels considers dog park locations

 September 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 384
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — A dog park in St. Michaels has been in discussion for almost four years. Now, with a special meeting planned, the town and commissioners are turning their attention to finding a location where the dog park can properly serve the community.The commissioners want to take into account multiple factors when decided the location of the dog park, including cost of building and maintenance, liability concerns, who is allowed to use the park, and limiting the amount of people affected by the noise and traffic.
While a date is still being chosen for the special meeting, some dog owners in town said they were excited that the town is looking to get the ball rolling.
"It's exciting," said Jonathan Dietrich, St. Michaels resident and owner of two dogs, as he was walking his dogs through town. "It's exciting as long as the location is right and everybody approves of it. I know it's been a very long journey, and it's pretty complicated, but it would be great. It would be great if we could get one but we'll see what happens."
When dog park discussion started in St. Michaels four years ago, a group of lawyers in St. Michaels came together and created a group called "The Friends of St. Michaels Dog Park."
Member Devon Hewitt spoke at the August town meeting about donors for the dog park and potential locations.
According to Hewitt the group of lawyers did research and came up with multiple locations, but the conversations fell through. After the new commissioners were elected, conversations began again.
While determining the master plan for San Domingo Creek Park construction at the August Town Council meeting, discussion arose about a dog park being included in the master plan. The town commissioners decided not to include a dog park in the plan.
One of the reasons brought forward at the meeting was that if dog park plans were added to the master plan, the grant received from the Maryland Department of Natural Resources could be pulled back.
While the location for the potential dog park is unclear, St. Michaels residents say they are ready to see movement.
When Stacy Sass, a resident of St. Michaels, was asked how soon she would hope to see a dog park in St. Michaels for her dog Ginger to play in, she said, "tomorrow."

 DENTON - From new ambulances to new schedules, the Caroline County Department OfEmergency Services has presented to the CountyCommissioners its recent purchase requests and shift changes.The department recently purchased two new rescue units from FESCO Emergency Sales based in Elkridge, approved by the commissioners.Posting a photo of the rescue vehicles on its Face-bookpage, the department thanked the county Commis-sioners, the Basic Life Support Committee and the citizens of Caroline County for their support."This is one more way we are committed to bring the best care to Caroline County the post stated.EMS Director Mark Sheridan proposed a new schedule for personnel, explaining to the Caroline County Commissioners on Sept. 12 howthe change would promote fewer unscheduled call-outs and attract new first responders to the CountyThe commissioners gave the green light to Sheridan to work OUt the details.The "24/72"shift schedule allows employees towork24 hours Straight followed by 72 hours off."The shifts that we work now is four-on-four-off," Sheridan said, which is "a pretty grueling shift on you for a family.Sheridan pointed OUt that Queen Anne's County EMS has used the 24/72 schedule for20years, and Wicom-ico County's recent shift to it has been very successful."A survey of employee preferences received 100% participation."Everyone voiced their opinion on what shift they wanted to work, and they also created a Iist Ofbenefits that they felt that would help them with their work-life balance, sald Sheridan.He said the department is fully staffed, but I can tell you that since my coming here, in two years we've had a tremendous turnover in 911."Sheridan said the employee selection process may be part of the problem "because it's tough to select the right person, but every time someone walks in the door and we get a turnover, it costs the county about$35,000.""Generally, why people leave the 911 Center in Caroline is either benefits somewhere else, pay or schedule," Sheridan said.Calling adequate downtime away from work "huge" for first responders, a schedule that allows more of it might contribute to better mental health for them, he said. The schedule would also promote building "a more team concept."Dispatchers were "100% for the 24-hour option," Sheridan said."I wouldn't sit here and talk to you today if I didn't believe this could be done in Caroline County," Sheridan said. "I believe that people would want to work for Caroline County, and I think that instead of us always catching up and following everybody else, this gives us an opportunity to be a leader in the industry."Sheridan said that the shift changes, which he expected would implemented by January, were "an operational issue" that didn't require a vote by the commissioners, but he wanted "to have an open line of communication" with them.Included in its consent agenda appropriations, the Caroline County Commissioners unanimously approved several purchases for the department.On Sept. 12, the commissioners approved the purchase of four stretchers and four stair chairs from Stryker Sales Corporation for $114,641.At its Sept. 26 meeting, the commissioners approved the purchase of two Horton Model #603 ambulances for $316,801 each from FESCO Sales. 
 
 Caption: SUBMITTED
 
The Caroline County Department of Emergency Services recently purchased two new rescue units from FESCO Emergency Sales based in Elkridge approved by the commissioners.

WEDNESDAY MORNING ARTISTS, 9:30 a.m., 900 Peachblossom Place, Cambridge. Discussion about activities for the new year will be featured, celebration of the new location for art display and sales at Vintage Venue. Group shares our artwork at meetings and many collaborate with different forms of media. New members welcome.
WATERMEN'S STORY SWAP, 5:30 p.m., Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, 213 N. Talbot Street, St. Michaels. Panel of both working and retired watermen hailing from around the Eastern Shore. The suggested ticket price is $8 per participant, with both in-person and virtual options available at cbmm.org/WatermenStorySwap.
ADVANCED HEALTHCARE PLANNING, 10 a.m. to noon, Talbot Hospice, 586 Cynwood Drive, Easton. Understand your options for Advanced Directive paperwork. Offered every second Thursday of the month. Free and open to the public. Call 410-822-6681 to register.

RESTORING WATERWAYS LECTURE, 1 p.m., Tilghman Island Volunteer Fire Department, 5979 Tilghman Island Road. Maegen White from ShoreRivers will speak about restoring waterways on the Eastern Shore. Free admission, donations accepted.
YOGA CLASS, Oxford Community Center, 200 Oxford Road. 9:30 a.m. Intermediate yoga with Suzie Hurley. Info: 410-226-5904 or www.oxfordcc.org.
ICE & OYSTER FESTIVAL, noon to 9 p.m., downtown Cambridge. Dazzling 3D ice sculptures, kid-friendly ice games, local oysters and craft beer, amazing ice bars, ice carver demonstration, s'mores, wood burning fire pits, live music on two stages. 410-228-3575

title: MID-SHORE CALENDAR
content:
MID-SHORE CALENDAR

 August 8, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A2 | Section: Calendar 
 
 1149
 Words 

 Read News Document

 TUESDAY, AUG. 8.HEALING THROUGH YOGA, 8:45 to 9:45 a.m., at Talbot Hospice, 586 Cynwood Dr., Easton. No Fee. A weekly yoga class to help find strength in the grieving process. For anyone grieving the death of a loved one. Taught by Leslie Orndoff, RY T. No prior yoga experience necessary. Registration required: bereavement@talbothospice.org or 410-822-6681, ext. 116.STEADY & STRONG, Oxford Community Center, 200 Oxford Road. 10 a.m. A 45-minute class for adults who seek enhanced core and muscle strength and better balance. Led by Janet Pfeffer. $10 per class, $80 for 10 classes. Pre-registration required. Info: 410-226-5904, oxfordcc@verizon.net or www.oxfordcc.org.SENIOR WALK, 10:30 a.m., Martinak State Park. Meet at the park office or a guided walk on a paved trail. title: TODAY IN HISTORY/Sept. 24
author: Staff Writer
content:
TODAY IN HISTORY/Sept. 24

 September 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 362
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Sept. 24, 2017, more than 200 NFL players kneeled or sat during the national anthem after President Donald Trump criticized the players' protests in a speech and a series of tweets.Also on this date:
In 1789, President George Washington signed a Judiciary Act establishing America's federal court system and creating the post of attorney general.
In 1869, thousands of businessmen were ruined in a Wall Street panic known as "Black Friday" after financiers Jay Gould and James Fisk attempted to corner the gold market.
In 1906, President Theodore Roosevelt established Devil's Tower as the first U.S. national monument.
In 1957, the Los Angeles-bound Brooklyn Dodgers played their last game at Ebbets Field, defeating the Pittsburgh Pirates 2-0.
In 1960, the USS Enterprise, the first nuclear-powered aircraft carrier, was launched at Newport News, Virginia.
In 1963, the U.S. Senate ratified a treaty with Britain and the Soviet Union limiting nuclear testing.
In 1968, the TV news magazine "60 Minutes" premiered on CBS.
In 1969, the trial of the Chicago Eight, later the Chicago Seven, began. (Five were later convicted of crossing state lines to incite riots at the 1968 Democratic convention, but the convictions were ultimately overturned.)
In 1988, Jackie Joyner-Kersey won gold and set a world record in the women's heptathlon at the Summer Olympics in Seoul.
In 2013, a powerful 7.7-magnitude earthquake rocked southwest Pakistan, killing at least 376 people.
In 2015, a stampede and crush of Muslim pilgrims occurred in the holy city of Mina, Saudi Arabia. While the official Saudi death toll stood at 769, The Associated Press estimated that more than 2,400 people were killed.
In 2022, Russian forces launched new strikes on Ukrainian cities as Kremlin-orchestrated votes took place in occupied regions of Ukraine to create a pretext for their annexation by Moscow.
Today's Birthdays: Football Hall of Famer Joe Greene is 78. Actor Gordon Clapp is 76. Actor Harriet Walter is 74.
Filmmaker Brad Bird is 67. Actor Kevin Sorbo is 66. Actor-screenwriter Nia Vardalos is 62. Celebrity chef Robert Irvine is 59. TV personality Ross Matthews is 45. Olympic gold medal gymnast Paul Hamm is 42. Actor Spencer Treat Clark is 37. Actor Grey Damon is 37. Actor Ben Platt is 31. Actor Joe Locke is 21.

title: Bridge - How would you handle the trumps?
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - How would you handle the trumps?

 August 15, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: A8 | Section: News 
 
 265
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Here is the second deal from a session partnering my wife last month at a Bridge Base Online casual table. It featured a textbook example for maintaining trump control.How should South play in four hearts after West leads the club king?Yes, I was the only North to rebid two hearts rather than one spade. However, I still like my call despite the poor trumps. It backfires when partner is 4-4 or 4-5 in the majors and not strong enough to bid again.Otherwise, she will rebid two spades, and I will raise. I win when she has five hearts and a weak hand. This way, we find our eight-card fit.Also, if she were to rebid two clubs over one spade, I would have to pass. Two hearts would promise some 16 high-card points. Note also that my wife's jump to four hearts promised at least five trumps. With only four, she would have rebid three notrump or fudged somehow!Finally, yes, she might have rebid three diamonds or four clubs (a splinter bid). I would have signed off with such useless trumps.The danger to four hearts is a bad trump break, which is almost a certainty at BBO!The correct technique is to win the first trick and to duck a round of trumps. You ruff West's club continuation and now cash the heart ace to see the expected 4-1 division. However, you play on diamonds to set up your side suit and cruise home, losing only three trump tricks.Starting with the heart ace and another heart is fatal here. ©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Hollywood producer returning to Talbot roots for fresh perspective
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Hollywood producer returning to Talbot roots for fresh perspective

 November 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 377
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Chris Moore has many titles to his name: Harvard University Graduate, director, producer of "American Pie" and "Good Will Hunting," and one of his favorites: Talbot County native.Moore, after making his name in Hollywood, is coming back to the Eastern Shore to hear from the locals who helped him fall in love with film.
At the Oxford Community Center Thursday, Nov. 21, he will seek to engage in valuable dialogue with residents to better understand what movie lovers from across the country are wanting to see from the film industry.
"I could have been originally from somewhere else where, honestly, I wouldn't care what they had to say, but the thing about Talbot County, and what I love about coming back to it… is that it's a real slice of America," Moore said.
Moore said he grew up going to the Avalon and loving the world that TV and movies took him to.
After studying American history at Harvard, where he met and worked with Matt Damon and Ben Affleck, he left for California, where he worked in the mailroom at an agency and later got promoted to literary agent before selling several scripts, including "The Stoned Age," "PCU," "Airheads" and "My Girl."
He later went on to produce 1999 film classic "American Pie," a breakout hit that launched Moore's career as a Hollywood producer.
But for Moore, a lot has changed since the 1990s, including the way that people watch films. Subscription-based streaming services have changed audiences' consumption of content by "over producing" content and making it difficult to gauge what people actually want to see, he said.
Moore said he wants to take a step back and go back to his roots to better understand how to give audiences quality content. And for him there's no better sounding board than the people of the Eastern Shore.
For Moore, the event on Thursday will be interactive, funny and most importantly informative of what he believes best represents American culture and audiences.
"I don't want people to think this is like going to a college lecture," Moore said. "We're going to have some fun and talk about movies and talk about entertainment, talk about fun stuff and in a way that people laugh and can engage and it can be a lively night."

title: Easton gears up for 39th Festival of Trees
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Easton gears up for 39th Festival of Trees

 November 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: Local News 
 
 831
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The 39th Festival of Trees will take place in Easton on Nov. 29 through Dec. 3. Events include the Festival of Trees, which is held in the Tidewater Inn, as well as Carols by Candlelight, Santa's Workshop, Santa 5K Fun Run/Walk and a jewelry raffle.Every year, there is a theme for the festival, which is put on by the Friends of Talbot Hospice. This year's theme is "Holiday Traditions." The trees will be decorated based on that theme, festival chairman Karla Wieland-Cherry said.
"It takes a year to plan. It's a lot of work," Wieland-Cherry said. "It's all volunteer work, all volunteers. And this is our 39th year. The big thing is the trees, so we have the trees sponsored by various businesses, organizations and individuals. And they can either choose to decorate the tree, or we also have a list of volunteers who will come in and decorate the tree."
The festival raises funds for Talbot Hospice. Wieland-Cherry emphasized the work of volunteers in raising hospice funds, as well as the family aspect of the weekend-long event.
"My children are involved, my son comes and volunteers, my daughter used to sing, my husband, he's the music chairman," Wieland-Cherry said.
" ... It's just a wonderful way to kick off the holiday season," she continued. "I have such a blessed team of volunteers that work so hard to make this such a success."
On Friday night, the Preview Gala will kick off the festivities. From 6 to 8 p.m., guests will have the first opportunity to view 100 exquisitely trimmed trees of varying sizes. Tickets to the gala are available in advance for $125 per person or $200 per couple.
While the larger trees are sponsored in advance, gala guests get the first opportunity to purchase the smaller trees, from 12 inches to three feet and in varying price ranges.
The Gold Ballroom at the Tidewater Inn opens to the public Saturday morning and remains open through Tuesday. As always, local performers will be cycling throughout the event to provide music and singing.
Also Saturday morning, participants will hit the pavement at 9 a.m. for the Santa 5K Fun Run/Walk. There will be on-site registration starting at 8 a.m. at Idlewild Park in Easton and advance sign-ups will be available online.
Later in the day, Santa's Workshop opens. From 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. on both Saturday and Sunday in the Tidewater Inn's Ballroom Garden, children will rotate through stations after being greeted by Santa and posing for photographs.
Children can write letters to Santa, participate at craft stations, play games and enjoy a selfie station with props for photo opportunities. Santa's Workshop is no additional charge to those that pay for admission to the Festival of Trees.
Returning for the fifth year, Carols by Candlelight is an event free for all families. On Saturday from 5 to 7 p.m. Families can sing along with choral groups, bell ringers and musicians while enjoying hot cocoa and holiday treats.
Santa will be located on the grounds of The Bullitt House at the corner of Washington Street and Dover Street in downtown Easton. Other visitors include The Grinch, Elsa and Buddy the Elf.
This year, the Festival of Trees introduces a Fine Jewelry Raffle, courtesy of Kyle Edward Fine Jewelry of Easton. A pair of satin ball earrings and a diamond bezel necklace will be offered in the raffle to benefit Talbot Hospice. One raffle ticket costs $25 and is available online at and at Kyle Edward Fine Jewelry on 27 South Harrison St. The raffle will be drawn at 5:30 p.m. on Dec. 3 at the conclusion of Festival of Trees.
New this year is the debut of one-of-a-kind, keepsake luminaries in honor of a loved one. Designed and created by Pat and Eric Harvey, a limited number of the metal luminaries will be sold online, then displayed in the Gold Ballroom. At the conclusion of the Festival of Trees, the luminaries will be available for pickup in time to enjoy for the holiday season.
As Christmas is a season for remembering, friends and family remember their loved ones in a very special way by purchasing a poinsettia. The name of someone dear is placed on a Memory Scroll next to a stunning 12-foot poinsettia "tree" in the Tidewater Inn's Gold Ballroom.
Friends of Hospice was formed in 1984 and began hosting the Festival of Trees in 1986 to raise money for the Talbot Hospice Foundation. To date, close to $4 million has been raised by the Festival of Trees to assist with Talbot Hospice's operating budget.
As a celebration of life for those who have received Hospice care during the past year, the continued success of Festival of Trees is made possible by the generous financial contributions from local individuals and various businesses. To get involved in any capacity, or to inquire about a sponsorship, contact Festival of Trees Co-Chairmen Karla Wieland-Cherry at dkcherry4@aol.com or 410-310-8421 and Denise Haddaway at 443-995-4431 or denise.haddaway@gmail.com.
To learn more about Talbot Hospice, visit talbothospice.org. Festival information can be found at festival-of-trees.org/.

title: Storm should hit Eastern Shore Saturday
content:
Storm should hit Eastern Shore Saturday

 September 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 400
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The Talbot County Department of Emergency Services issued a weather briefing on Thursday evening for the tropical storm that is expected to pass over the Eastern Shore on Saturday.Threat - Talbot County residents and visitors are encouraged to monitor the status of Tropical Storm 16.At this time, the main threats are heavy rainfall, damaging winds, and tidal flooding.Impacts are expected to begin Friday night and last through Sunday. Damaging winds and heavy rainfall could result in downed trees and power outages.Low lying and floodprone areas should expect minor to moderate tidal flooding during high tide cycles throughout the weekend.Public Recommendations - Persons should take this opportunity to review general emergency preparedness, check emergency preparedness kits, and standby for potential impacts of this storm on our area. Make sure your homes and families are equipped for downed trees and power outages.Take this time to tie down loose outdoor items. Visit ready.gov or talbotdes.org for more information.Forecast Remarks - Topical Storm 16 is forming off the coast of the Carolinas and expected to be a post-tropical storm by time the storm moves into our area. We could see 2-3 inches of rainfall, wind gusts up to 40 mph, and sustained winds between 20-30 mph. Rain will begin Friday evening, with the arrival of winds as early as Saturday morning. Minor to moderate tidal flooding should be expected along coastal areas during high tide cycles Saturday and into Sunday.Regional Coordination - At this time, Talbot County Department of Emergency Services is participating in daily conference calls with the Maryland Department of Emergency Management and the National Weather Service. At this time, we are sending out briefings via email and social media. If forecasts change and there is an anticipated greater impact to Talbot County, we will contact our partners regarding future briefings.Watches and Warnings - At this time, our area does not have any Tropical Storm Watches or Warnings. The National Weather Services does not anticipate us being issued a Tropical Storm Watch or Warning for this event.Communications - Updates to key personnel by email. General preparedness information available to the public. The next briefing will be issued approximately 1 p.m. Friday, Sept. 22.Forecast information can be found at the below links:▪ National Hurricane Center Tropical Storm 16 Information nhc.noaa.gov/graphics at1.shtml? start#contents▪ Local Weather Forecast information with watches and warnings for our area weather.gov/phi/▪ Tidal Information weather.gov/marfc/

title: One is enough for Queen Anne's
author: Bill Haufe
content:
One is enough for Queen Anne's

 October 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 711
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Neither one needed a lesson on the importance of scoring first."The first team that scores is more likely to win than the second," Kent Island High head field hockey coach Laura Harding said.
"Getting that early goal, it sets the tone," Queen Anne's County head coach Shana Corder said. "And I knew going into this game, I knew both teams were going to come out to win it in regulation."
Queen Anne's and Kent Island played to a scoreless, double-overtime tie Oct. 19 before each team scored twice in a shootout in their regular-season finale.
It didn't take that long Tuesday afternoon.
Haley Cole's goal on a corner just 7 minutes in proved enough, as the Lions blanked Kent Island, 1-0, for their second straight Class 2A East Region I championship.
Queen Anne's (12-1-1) is seeded third in the 2A state tournament and will host No. 6 seed Centenniel (11-3) on Thursday at 4 p.m. in a quarterfinal.
"We're successful on our corners because our defense is so amazing," said Corder, whose team has won back-to-back Bayside Conference and regional titles for the first time in the program's history. "And it pays off for us. And all you need is one to go in. And honestly going forward, this is how the state tournament's going to go. One goal is going to get it."
One goal was all that was needed on this beautiful autumn afternoon.
Queen Anne's earned two corners in the game's first 5 minutes, then got a third with 7:20 remaining in the first quarter. Jordan Bilbo sent an entry pass to Ellee McLean, who quickly sent the ball back Bilbo. Positioned to the right of the goal, Bilbo centered a pass to an unmarked Cole about five yards from the cage. Cole didn't hesitate, quickly sweeping shot under the lunge of Bucs goalie Brynja Petursson and into the left side of the cage for a 1-0 lead.
"We've been working really hard on corner execution, and every practice it's been getting better and better," Cole said. "And I got the perfect pass from Jordan and happened to be the one. It was really a team effort. We were all in there to get it done and earn the corner. I just happened to be the one lucky to tap it in."
That was plenty for Queen Anne's defense.
Since yielding a goal to Crisfield on Oct. 7, the Lions haven't surrendered a goal over their last six games — not counting the 1 vs. 1 against the Bucs in the regular-season finale. Corder again played Cassidy Alexander (four saves) and Caroline Kimball (two saves) two quarters each Tuesday. And even though Sydnie Harris — one of the new mainstays on a rebuilt defense — was not 100%, she played tough minutes along with linemates Sydnee Carr and Mel Gill. Corder dropped forward Aly Edwards back on defense when Harris needed a breather.
"I just knew if we scored first I knew we could do it because my defense is amazing, and they're peaking," Corder said of a unit that has now logged 10 shutouts this season. "They are peaking right now. They've done well all season.
"I had to put one of my forwards back to defense," Corder said of Edwards. "But the kids listen to what we tell them in practice and they know everybody's role. So we're just able to be successful even being sick. I'm super proud of the girls."
Harding was also proud of her defense, which limited an opponent to one goal or less for the 11th time this season. Petursson made seven saves, including a stop McLean's penalty stroke with 7:45 left in the second quarter, and made another save when the Bucs were down a man for 2 minutes in the third quarter.
"We made the save and we battled back on all the corners down here in the first half," said Harding, whose team stopped Queen Anne's on 10 of its 11 corners.
Kent Island (9-4-1) almost pulled even with 2:50 remaining, when a drive in the circle missed connecting with Ellie Burnside at the post.
"They have a good defense," Harding said of Queen Anne's. "And they've got a great goalie. It's going to be a big battle again next year, too. I think we'll be right back here again next year."

title: King's granddaughter carrying forward his legacy
author: JESSICA A. JOHNSON
content:
King's granddaughter carrying forward his legacy

 January 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JESSICA A. JOHNSON | Section: Columns 
 
 673
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I happened to catch the recent "CBS Mornings" news interview of Yolanda Renee King, the only grandchild of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Coretta Scott King. While promoting her new children's book honoring her grandparents titled "We Dream a World," Yolanda gave a profound answer when asked what she would say to them if they were alive today. "I think I would first start off with an apology," she said, which was surprising to CBS host Nate Burleson, who immediately asked the young activist what she meant by her response. Yolanda continued, "An apology to where we are right now, as a nation and really as a world."Yolanda is only 15 years old, and it is evident that she has a deep understanding of what her grandparents fought for as leaders of the civil rights movement. In August of last year, during the 60th anniversary of the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom, Yolanda boldly declared that her generation would "be defined by action, not apathy."
As Yolanda is growing up before our eyes, she has the youthful exuberance of her grandfather's resolve and displays the dignified grace of her grandmother. Yolanda saying she would apologize to her grandparents for our nation not yet reaching the potential they believed in should make us thoughtfully reflect on how Dr. King also warned about becoming apathetic.
Apathy is a brutal paralyzer of life. It can cause us to be ensnared in a dangerous mode of stagnation emotionally, spiritually, and sometimes physically. Apathy also triggers entitled disinterest in our society. In 2021, Tom Nichols, an instructor at Harvard Extension School and the U.S. Naval War College, asserted in an interview with The Harvard Gazette that "narcissism and nihilism" are the primary threats to our country's democracy and societal relationships. Elaborating on the latter, Nichols said that many people ask why our society is "so mean and heartless and awful," but many of them do not contribute anything to make their communities better, or they will vote against policies that affect their well-being due to "narcissistic beefs."
"We have become surly villagers," Nichols maintained, "me, my family, my little plot of land, and everybody else can go to hell." This type of sullen attitude is what Yolanda is urging our country to overcome as she is an emerging voice on critical issues such as gun violence and homelessness.
As Yolanda continues to attentively study the Godly principles that enabled her grandfather to be that drum major for justice who changed the course of our nation, I am reminded of two of his sermons where he encouraged his followers to live with purpose and passion and to shower others with Christian love.
The first sermon is titled "But If Not," a 1967 message that King delivered at Atlanta's Ebenezer Baptist Church. King expresses that the "ultimate test" of our faith is when we get to a "but if not" moment in life, a moment where we have to travel along an arduous journey with no other option but to lean on God's promises.
This passage stands out to avoid being gripped by apathy during a spiritual test: "... somewhere along the way [in life] you should discover something that's so dear, so precious to you, that is so eternally worthful, that you will never give it up." The second sermon is "Levels of Love," an Ebenezer address King gave in 1962. He implored the congregation to "rise to agape, to Christian love" because "[t]he greatness of it is that you love every man, not for your sake but for his sake. And you love every man because God loves him."
It is remarkable that Yolanda exemplifies the love and compassion her grandparents demonstrated as she diligently works to uplift others. She is blazing her own path, and it is truly inspiring to watch it unfold. She probably has not had a "but if not" moment yet in her young life thus far, but I have no doubt she is developing the character and strength to face the challenges she knows are coming.

title: "An Evening wit Marti Gould Cummings and Peachz" at Church Hill Theater
author: Staff Writer
content:
"An Evening wit Marti Gould Cummings and Peachz" at Church Hill Theater

 January 26, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 289
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Marti Gould Cummings, a native of Kent County and a New York-based drag queen performer, is returning to the Church Hill Theater for fundraiser of music and laughter."An Evening with Marti Gould Cummings and Peachez" is scheduled for Feb. 17 at 7:30 p.m. Tickets are $35 in advance and $40 at the door. The show benefits Church Hill Theater.
Born and raised in Locust Grove, some of Marti's earliest stage experiences were here at CHT, as a member of the annual summer Green Room Gang Program. Peachez is Peachez Iman Cummings.
"Marti is a world-renowned drag artist who has appeared on Bravo, the Good Network, and Fusion. They made history when they ran for City Council in NYC as the first non-binary and first drag candidate for city office in New York and founded the Hell's Kitchen Democrats. Marti served on the Mayor's Advisory Council on Nightlife and sat on Community Board 9. They were invited to lead a panel at the United Nations making them the first drag artist to do so and have been invited to the White House. Their a film Queen of NY, (October 2023) documenting their campaign is making waves across the film festival circuit," the Eastern Shore theater said in a press release promoting the event.
Peachez is the winner of season 23 of Food Network's "Worst Cooks in America" and was featured in the Hulu hit "Drag Me to Dinner". "Peachez is focused on using her platform to highlight Black queens in the city's seemingly monochromatic nightlife scene," the theater said its show announcement.
For more information or to reserve tickets, call the Church Hill Theatre office at (410) 556-6003, Monday through Friday between 11 a.m. and 5 p.m., or visit their website at www.churchhilltheatre.org.

title: Academy Art Museum gets new director
author: Tom McCall
content:
Academy Art Museum gets new director

 November 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Arts 
 
 511
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Charlotte Potter Kasic, the new director of the Academy Art Museum, has a lot of ideas. But her first weeks, she said, will be dedicated to completing a listening tour.Her latest post was the Barry Art Museum in Norfolk, Virginia, where she was executive director. Now she has a new challenge with helming the Academy.
"Every time I see a challenge, I lean in," Kasic said.
She was not entirely unfamiliar with the Academy Art Museum before applying for the job.
"When Eric Neil left the Academy in 2012 or 2013, he became the director of the Chrysler Museum of Art, and I was the director of the Chrysler Museum Glass Studio, which was like an annex," Kasic said.
She's been impressed with the museum's existing work and potential.
"When you break it down, there are classes. There are programs and exhibitions. There is collections. There is fundraising. There are galas. It is wild how much happens here with so little. I think this place is doing a great job of hitting a lot of audiences," she said.
Kasic is excited to work with the staff to continue these efforts.
Kasic has past in glass blowing, in which she said she learned about collaboration and teamwork. She created Cirque de Verre (circus of glass), which traveled around the United States to museums and art spaces that had glass blowing furnaces.
"Glass I love because you work in teams. It is hot. It is visceral. There is a lot of strong communication skills," Kasic said. "I like things to be immersive, multisensory and interdisciplinary. When you think of olfactory, that is how you access your deepest memories. Music can change your mood in a minute. Art can do that as well."
Kasic has a masters degree from Rhode Island School of Design and has done residencies at Penland, Oxbow, Pilchuck and in Australia.
After the Chrysler she moved to Vermont to start a family. She ended up being the director at the Yestermorrow Design Build School, which celebrates sustainable design and craft.
The siren song of Norfolk brought her and her family back to the Chesapeake, where she joined the team at the Barry Museum. She says it has become the glass art capital of the East Coast. There, Kasic helmed a 25,000 square foot expansion and closed out a $23 million campaign.
Now at the Academy Art Museum, she sees a collaborative community that brings Plein Air, The Craft Show and the Waterfowl Festival into the institution. She also has a clear-eyed approach to what the Academy can offer the community.
"I would like to see more of our permanent collection on view. We have so much that exists but people don't get to see," she said.
Even with these plans, she realizes that there is a lot of collaborating to be done.
"It is important to say how invested the board is in this place. I have seen more board involvement and more community investment than any other organization I have been in. People are so dedicated. It is really remarkable and it speaks to the strength of this place," she said.

title: TODAY IN HISTORY
content:
TODAY IN HISTORY

 September 6, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A10 | Section: News 
 
 249
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Today's Highlights in History:On Sept. 6, 1901, President William McKinley was shot and mortally wounded by anarchist Leon Czolgosz at the Pan-American Exposition in Buffalo, New York. (McKinley died eight days later.)On this date:In 1909, American explorer Robert Peary sent a telegram from Indian Harbor, Labrador, announcing that he had reached the North Pole five months earlier.In 1943, 79 people were killed when a New York-bound Pennsylvania Railroad train derailed and crashed in Philadelphia.In 1949, Howard Unruh, a resident of Camden, New Jersey, shot and killed 13 of his neighbors.In 1972, the Summer Olympics resumed in Munich, West Germany, a day after the deadly hostage crisis that left eleven Israelis, five Arab abductors and a West German police officer dead.In 1975, 18-year-old tennis star Martina Navratilova of Czechoslovakia, in New York for the U.S. Open, requested political asylum in the United States.In 1991, the Soviet Union recognized the independence of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia.In 1997, a public funeral was held for Princess Diana at Westminster Abbey in London, six days after her death in a car crash in Paris. In Calcutta, India, weeping masses gathered to pay homage to Mother Teresa, who had died the day before at age 87.In 2001, in a dramatic shift, the Bush administration abandoned the Clinton-era effort to break up Microsoft.In 2002, meeting outside Washington, D.C. for only the second time since 1800, Congress convened in New York to pay homage to the victims and heroes of September 11.

title: World Waterfowl Calling Championships echo through Easton High auditorium
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
World Waterfowl Calling Championships echo through Easton High auditorium

 November 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 373
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Quacks, squeals and honks reverberated through Easton High School's auditorium Saturday night.The World Waterfowl Calling Championships, the final event of the Waterfowl Festival's Saturday schedule, brought waves of camo to the school for the event's seven competitions: the Jr. World Live Duck Calling Championship, the Jr. World Goose Calling Championship, the World Team Live Goose Calling Championship, the World Team Live Duck Calling Championship, the World Live Duck Calling Championship, the World Live Goose Calling Championship and the World Goose Calling Championship.
Winners of the different competitions took home a variety of prizes including plaques, money and — of course — decoys.
Contestant John Walls took home the big title of the night, World Goose Calling champion, which came with a $5,000 check. This is Walls' third World Goose Calling Championship win.
After yelling for joy with his fists in the air, Walls told emcee Dave Bloodsworth, "It's the Super Bowl, man." He thanked his friends and family before talking about celebration plans.
"I'm going to have a lot of fun tonight," he said. "It's a bad night to be a Busch Light."
Other champions of the night include Logan Heibner, 16, named Jr. World Live Duck Calling champion; JT Johnson, 15, named Jr. World Goose Calling champion; Chandler Martin and Slayton Gearin, named World Team Live Duck Calling champions; brothers Bryan and Bobby Heim, named World Team Live Goose Calling champions; Seth Fields, named World Live Duck Calling champion and Chance Wadsworth, named World Live Goose Calling champion.
After his win, Fields thanked his wife.
"For listening to all my routines in the kitchen," he said.
Bloodsworth said five judges in the back of the auditorium graded contestants on their routine, flow and sound throughout the night.
Before the competition began, junior callers Carter Whaley, 14, and Peter Aul, 16, sat on the stage, feeling both nervous and excited for the final competitions of the night to begin.
For Aul, who traveled from Pennsylvania for the championships, it was his first time at the Waterfowl Festival. He said he found out about the festival through buddies.
As for how he got into calling: "I just got a call and started running it better than everybody in my area and decided, you know what? I'm going to throw my name in."

title: St. Michaels announces gingerbread contest, ornament
author: Staff Writer
content:
St. Michaels announces gingerbread contest, ornament

 October 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Life 
 
 421
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Bakers and pastry chefs of all ages and talent levels are encouraged to get their gingerbread house games on with the return of the Christmas in St. Michaels Gingerbread House competition this December and a purse totaling $2,000 in prizes up for grabs.The competition is an important component of the fundraising the all-volunteer organization achieves with the annual event, with the creations highlighted and on display at the Gingerbread "House" Preview Cocktail Party at the Woman's Club of St. Michaels on Thursday, Dec. 12, beginning at 5 p.m.
"We are encouraging participants to donate their creations for our silent auction, to be held the evening of the cocktail party," says this year's Gingerbread House Competition Co-Chair Michele Lowe. "All auction proceeds support the beneficiaries of Christmas in St. Michaels."
Entrants can pick their category for participation, which includes master chefs and caterers, adults, young adults, children, children with adults, kit-made houses, and non-profit organizations. Participation is free, with pre-registration needed at christmasinstmichaels.org/events.
The 2024 Christmas in St. Michaels Collectors Ornament has also been announced and is the 21st in the series. This year's ornament depicts the Chesapeake deadrise workboat with its crew and a friendly canine companion. The image was provided by St. Michaels artist Sherry Smith.
The boxed ornament is available for purchase at select local retail shops and the weekend-long Christmas in St. Michaels Marketplace and Sweet Shoppe. Online purchases can be made at www.christmasinstmichaels.org/ornament.
The deadrise workboat has been a staple among Chesapeake watermen for decades. "Deadrise" refers to the almost flat, V-shaped hull that provides a shallow draft to accommodate the waters in creeks and rivers of the Eastern Shore. Boats range from 25-45 feet in length and are powered by large, inboard four- or six-cylinder engines, usually diesel-fueled.
Workboats typically sport women's names on the transom or bow, paying tribute to wives and daughters. Others, such as the one in this ornament, refer to the town, river or creek the boat calls home port.
"It is typical to see dozens of these deadrise workboats plying the waters of the Eastern Shore in the wee hours of the morning as they seek the day's catch, returning to the pier in the early afternoon to get their catch to market," says Christmas in St. Michaels Chair Pat Martin. "We're honored to add this limited-edition ornament to our collection to pay tribute to watermen and their boats in the St. Michaels area and the Chesapeake Bay region at large."
Event details, online ticket and ornament purchases, and more about Christmas in St. Michaels are at christmasinstmichaels.org.

title: Heads in the sand
content:
Heads in the sand

 September 13, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A6 | Section: Letters 
 
 259
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Well, now we have a president who is in total denial of knowing anything about his son's business dealings even though he carried him on Air Force One and Two all over the world to foreign countries to meet with leaders and business people.Do all Democrats have their head in the sand?This president has lead this country down a road to destruction by inviting illegal aliens (I am tired of hearing them called migrants.They are hear illegally) to come into our country putting a tax burden on the working class to house, feed, educate and provide health care for all these illegals from foreign countries.This president aided and abetted our enemy in Afghanistan as he provided for their people to escape but would not bring our people home. We have cities that have been ruled by Democrats for decades and they are the worst in the nation and if you don't think so just look at Baltimore, Chicago, L.A. and New York to name a few.How long will people be tied to one party that they would rather see our nation go down the tube then to do what is right for our children and grandchildren.If we continue in the direction that we are going, undermining our Constitution and Bill of Rights, we will be a dictatorship with one ruling party taking away our guns, closing our places of worship, giving us run away inflation and forcing us to buy total electric. Folks, if we don't stop them this will come to pass.JOHN GONDECKEaston

title: Christmas Cheer - Maryland Stories: Cabaret Carolers Warm Up The Winter With Song
content:
Christmas Cheer - Maryland Stories: Cabaret Carolers Warm Up The Winter With Song

 December 14, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: A7 | Section: News 
 
 524
 Words 

 Read News Document

 During a busy month of performances for their talented, youthful group, the Children's Theater of Southern Maryland Cabaret Carolers will continue their merry delivery of glad tidings throughout the area this weekend by hosting a pair of concerts at two Calvert County establishments.Comprised of nearly two dozen elementary and middle school students primarily from Calvert County with several from St. Mary's County added to the mix, the Children's Theater of Southern Maryland Cabaret Carolers will perform on Saturday from 1 to 4 p.m. at Mrs.
Moo's in Prince Frederick then again on Sunday at the Bulrushes Cafe from 9 a.m. to noon.
"The carolers will perform three sets of six to eight songs at each location over those two days," said Southern Maryland Children's Theater public relations and social media manager Lara Reisman, who is slated to be the group's president for two years beginning next month. "Most of the group is from Calvert County, but we have a few from St.
Mary's County. They're a very talented, dedicated vocal group and they love to perform at area venues during the holidays."
In fact, the group's two performances this Saturday at Mrs. Moo's holiday open house and again the following morning at Bulrushes Cafe will put the finishing touches on a very busy month for the carolers.
Last Saturday, Dec. 9, the Cabaret Carolers performed for three hours at the Holidays Tree Lighting in Prince Frederick and several days earlier they performed at Asbury Solomons retirement community.
"The kids love to perform any time of year, but especially around the holidays," said Reisman, who has been associated with the group since its inception in 2001. "They enjoy rehearsing together and they can't wait to perform.
They usually do three sets of six to eight songs beginning at the top of each hour."
While most residents do not associate ice cream with the winter months and upcoming Christmas and New Year's Day holidays, Mrs. Moo's is going to sweeten the pot for the local group by unveiling an ice cream sundae named in their honor on Saturday.
Reisman admits that it is a fitting tribute to a youthful group that provides holiday cheer each winter.
Aly Cross, who has directed the group in "Newsies, Jr.," "A Christmas Story," "Beauty and the Beast" and "Once On This Island Jr." and will be directing "High School Musical" in the spring, also teaches all of the acting classes each semester.
In the spring, the acting classes will be held at the College of Southern Maryland's Prince Frederick campus.
"This group is very, very unique," Cross said.
"We have a great group of kids. There's no pressure on these kids to memorize things. It's a great chance for them all to sing Christmas carols together.
They're learning a little bit of choreography to go along with the songs.
When they performed at the Asbury Solomons they were overwhelmed by the response from the audience." 
 
 Caption: The Children's Theatre of Southern Maryland Holiday Cabaret Carolers will be performing concerts this Saturday afternoon at Mrs. Moo's in Prince Frederick then again on Sunday morning at Bulrushes Cafe.

 PHOTOS COURTESY BRYN CROSS

 The Children's Theatre of Southern Maryland Holiday Cabaret Carolers gives children a chance to showcase their talents.

title: Chesapeake Multicultural after-school program lets students learn through taste
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Chesapeake Multicultural after-school program lets students learn through taste

 April 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 541
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Thursday evening, over a dozen fourth and fifth graders walked through Bonheur Ice Cream and Pie in downtown Easton and learned from local chefs of the profession of devoting themselves to sweets.These students are part of the Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center After-school Program, a program designed to enrich Hispanic elementary school students of Talbot County.
During the program, students focus on science, technology, engineering and mathematics; reading skills; and food supplement nutrition education to ensure they are educated and well prepared for lessons inside and outside of the classroom.
Estela-Vianney Ramirez, assistant director of the after-school program, said she has been working with the program for over a decade, and it is a beautiful experience to help expand the world for these students.
"It's very rewarding to teach the class," Ramirez said. "Those memories really stick in their, the students', minds and enable them to actually give out to the community, too, because some of our volunteers in our after-school program were our students who went through the program 10 years ago."
Ramirez notes that she sees her former students working in offices and throughout the Eastern Shore, and she is happy to be a part of their development.
During the tour of Bonheur, Chef Tyler Heim brought the students to the kitchen and explained the process of making ice cream and the work that goes into every pint. One by one, students were moved throughout the kitchen and shown the behind-the-scenes of sweet treats and rich desserts.
Julia Foxwell, director of community engagement for Bluepoint Hospitality, said it was a delight for the chefs to share their passion for sweets with the students.
"We have been working with the Chesapeake Multicultural Center for some time on how best to support their initiatives while also providing enriching experiences to their students," Foxwell said. "Bringing the girls and boys in to learn kitchen basics — from prep to final product — exposes them to new concepts, flavors and perhaps a future passion of their own. Chefs (Harley) Peet and Heim loved hosting the kids in the kitchen and even got a few ideas for new flavors."
Victoria Gomez Lozano, Hispanic outreach coordinator for Chesapeake Multicultural Resource Center, said this program is important in reaching out to community members who may not know about the center's services.
"We started this program to give the underserved children of this community the opportunity to have extracurricular activities and to be exposed to a lot of things that they may not have the opportunity to," Gomez Lozano said. "It's also a good way to contact their parents and the families in the community as well so they can open up to us and so we can give them our services."
At the end of the tour, every student was given a scoop of ice cream and a choice of toppings to create their own flavor.
Each student enjoyed the ice cream while laughing with friends.
Student Yerelin Fuentes said she has been in the after-school program for a few years now and loves the chance to learn new things and spend time with her friends outside of class. But what she loves most, she said, is the ability to learn to be a good person.
"They show us how to be a hero," Fuentes said.

title: Dorman receives Rotary's highest service award
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Dorman receives Rotary's highest service award

 January 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Life 
 
 617
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Beth Anne Dorman, president and CEO of For All Seasons, was honored with Rotary's highest award, the J. Howard Anthony Community Service Award.For All Seasons is a behavioral health and rape crisis center. They are also the only agency in Talbot County doing this work in Spanish and English.
They bring in 20 to 25 new people a week for their new no wait five-days-a-week services. Because of COVID-19 they got skillful at telehealth and now offer services in all 24 jurisdictions in Maryland.
According to Beth Spurry, the president and owner of Wye Finanicial Trust and a mentor of Dorman's, in the past decade, Dorman has taken the organization from just 24 employees to over 100, most of whom are women.
"Because those nearly 100 employees that are meeting the mental health, the rape crisis needs of our community are the employees that are handling the toughest of the tough and doing it with a smile on their face. I have a smile on my face because of them. So thank you for this award," Dorman said.
A few days after the award was announced, she reflected.
"It is their largest award. I was first a part of Rotary when I first got out of college. It was called a group study exchange," Dorman said. "The group study is a professional exchange. I was given the opportunity to apply to be a part of a group that traveled to Japan. I was there for six weeks. I visited higher ed places in the Ibaraki Prefecture."
It is a specialized award. You cannot have been in Rotary for 10 years. You have to have lived and worked in the community in which you were serving for 10 years.
"It is a big deal for them. They have an opportunity to pick one person from the community. So I was blown away when he (Tom Hill) called me and told me that it was going to be me," Dorman said.
"I think it brings to light the importance of living through service in your community. That is the core of who I am, as far as servant leadership. I am as good as the team I have put together. We continue to serve in the community. It spurs a conversation about the importance of service no matter how big or small," Dorman said.
For All Seasons hosts many events throughout the year, like the backpack giveaway and Frosty's Holiday Village, that reach thousands of people.
"In all of that, the biggest piece for me is providing an example for my children, for women, for girls, for young people. My kids know I am busy and on my phone all the time, but they always know I am doing really important work. And that plants in them that they can be someone in the community," Dorman said.
She said she has a supportive team that helps her. Starting with her husband and her kids, Dave and Melinda Finley at Anchor Church on Goldsboro, Alice Ryan of the Women and Girls Fund, and Spurry.
"I was given a huge gift at the awards ceremony in having her (Spurry) be the person to present me the award. Beth has not only been a guiding light, but a pretty strong mentor. She will say, 'I think you can do better and here is why.' She has been an incredibly encouraging mentor," Dorman said.
She said this was a really important moment in her career.
"If all fell away tomorrow, this is the community that has supported me as I am supporting them. I will have a part of the Anthony family legacy forever and be able to say here is the impact I had in the community, which I call home," she said.

title: Sending Shelly home
author: Staff Writer
content:
Sending Shelly home

 May 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: News 
 
 657
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Chestertown to Tilghman Island can be a long drive, especially if you're riding the whole way in a plastic box with air holes punched in the top.But for a special diamondback terrapin, the school bus trip was a one-way ride home.
For the past year, Shelly has lived in an aquarium at Kent County Middle School in Chestertown as part of a research program.
Recently, middle school teachers Samantha Cawthorne and Roberto-Luis Copeland; Shelly, who rode in the aforementioned plastic box; and a group of sixth-graders traveled to Tilghman Island in Talbot County.
From there, they caught a boat to Poplar Island, where Shelly originally came from. Shelly was part of the Terrapin Program through Maryland Environmental Service, the agency heading up the Paul S. Sarbanes Ecosystem Restoration Project at Poplar Island.
As part of the research program, Shelly spent her first year growing from a tiny hatchling to a young terrapin at Kent County Middle School before being release back on Poplar Island.
For Copeland, this was his first time raising a terrapin, an experience he described as "amazing."
"Not only was it truly great for the students to learn more about terrapin ecology and physiology, it was also a good opportunity for students to learn about the environmental impacts we as humans impose on literally our backyard, the Chesapeake Bay," Copeland said.
Cawthorne said she loved every minute helping raise Shelly and was very thankful for the experience.
"Seeing the look of awe and excitement in the students' faces whenever Shelly made her way to my classroom was nothing short of wonderful. The students learned so much about terrapins and we were very sad to see her go," Cawthorne said.
For more than a decade, the State of Maryland has been rebuilding Poplar Island.
In its day, there were families that called Polar Island home. It also hosted a getaway used by the most powerful people in Washington, D.C., including U.S. presidents like Franklin Delano Roosevelt and Harry Truman.
The waters of the Chesapeake eroded Poplar Island so much so that by 2000, it was predicted the entire island would soon be washed away.
The Poplar Island restoration site is still under construction. While no people live on the island, many species of wildlife now call it home — or at least a stop on their migratory route.
Scientists led by biologist Willem Roosenburg at Ohio University are conducting a study of terrapins on Poplar Island. They locate nests and count and measure eggs.
"A lack of land predators, undisturbed sandy shorelines, and a variety of habitat types make Poplar an ideal terrapin nesting site," the Terrapin Program website states.
With around 800 diamondback terrapins — the state reptile of Maryland — hatching annually on Poplar Island, the researchers collect about 150 eggs each year and give the juveniles to schools raise.
This "head start" program aims to determine if this level of human involvement in terrapins' early stages of life gives them a better chance in the long run of surviving in the nature world, according to the Terrapin Program site.
It also gives students the opportunity to more personally engage with the Bay's ecosystem.
"Through this program, students are playing an important role in relevant, cutting-edge research focused on the conservation of the species," the Terrapin Program site states. "The combination of scientific applications, hands-on involvement and the emotional attachment to the terrapins provides a unique opportunity to inspire a meaningful connection with the Chesapeake Bay."
Through releasing Shelly back into the wild, Cawthorne and Copeland both said they hope the middle school students learned that any action they take, no matter how large or small, can have a huge impact on the health of the Bay.
The field trip was funded in part by the Kent County Public Schools Education Foundation Fund.
Part of Mid-Shore Community Foundation, the education foundation fund helps cover the costs of extended field trips, provides mini-grants to teachers and more.
For details about the Kent County Public Schools Education Foundation Fund, or to make a donation, visit www.kent.k12.md.us/Foundation.aspx.

title: Chickens find community support in Ridgely
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Chickens find community support in Ridgely

 September 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 381
 Words 

 Read News Document

 RIDGELY — On Monday, Ridgely commissioners and residents discussed potentially allowing chickens within town limits.Listed in Chapter 64-4 of the town's code, the breeding, feeding, pasturing and penning of chickens and multiple other animals is currently prohibited within the town. But after some discussion from town residents, rules regarding chickens could change.
According to town staff, the conversation has been ongoing through the past couple of months, but it gained traction after residents began preparing petitions and presentations on chickens.
Mason Sparks, a resident of the town, gave a presentation to the town on chickens at the commissioners' August meeting. At Monday's meeting, Sparks said that he knocked on 471 doors and received 178 responses from residents, 87.6% of whom were in favor of allowing chickens.
Resident Andrew Meyer also spoke on Monday in favor of chickens being allowed within the town limits.
"I just want to start by saying that I strongly support allowing chickens in town," Meyer said. "There's towns and cities all over the country that currently allow chickens. Today, more and more people want to know where the food's coming from, and raising backyard chickens for eggs is one way that people can ensure that they have healthy raised source of food."
Meyer addressed some concerns he said he has heard about chickens.
"As far as noise, hens are no louder than barking dogs or children playing. As far smells, a small backyard coop that's kept clean would have minimal smell. It's no more disturbing than any other farm smells that town is currently surrounded by. I think the benefits outweigh any small disturbance that would cause to any neighbors around the town."
After hearing from residents, the commissioners voiced their opinions.
"It seems like the residents are definitely in favor," Commissioners Chad Leister said. "I know that I personally reached out to all our neighboring town councils and spoke to them, mainly just to see, some I guess bad feedback they would have for the chickens, and, as you know, there wasn't really a whole lot of it. So, I think I'm willing to be okay with it."
The commissioners made a motion to work on the legal wording of the town code to draft an ordinance to allow chickens within the town. The ordinance is expected to be presented at the next meeting.

title: Bridge - The more you see, the more you know
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - The more you see, the more you know

 August 21, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: A5 | Section: News 
 
 254
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Eric Hoffer, who thought his best book was "The Ordeal of Change," wrote, "The hardest arithmetic to master is that which enables us to count our blessings." At the bridge table, if you are playing for money and master the counting of suit lengths and high-card points, at the end of the session, you will be counting your winnings.In today's deal from a match pointed duplicate, how should South plan the play in five spades after the defenders begin with two rounds of hearts?North's negative double showed four spades. Playing for money, North would have doubled five hearts and collected 300 points.However, worried that most pairs would buy it in four spades, North pushed on to five spades.Clearly, South had to avoid a club loser, and he knew to leave the key suit as late as possible. He ruffed the second heart, drew one round of trumps and played a diamond to the king. East took that trick and played another trump. Declarer won on the board, cashed the diamond jack, crossed to the spade queen and played off the diamond queen and 10, pitching clubs from the dummy.It was time to work out the club position. What had South learned?East was known to have started with three spades and five diamonds. The bidding also strongly suggested that East had four hearts. If so, his hand distribution was 3=4=5=1.Singularity rules. Declarer cashed his club king and ran the club jack, chosen to encourage an unwise cover.Well counted.

title: Ballots not cast online
author: Staff Writer
content:
Ballots not cast online

 January 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 81
 Words

 I feel the need to clarify part of Rich Adrian's letter that appeared last Sunday. His letter may leave the impression that Maryland ballots printed at home are then cast online. This is not true.After a ballot is printed from the website, the voter fills it out and mails it in. There is no voting online, so there is no hacking. The printed ballot is mailed and treated with the same scrutiny for authenticity as any other mail-in ballot.

title: New Year ushers in single-use plastic bag ban in Town of Centreville
author: Staff Writer
content:
New Year ushers in single-use plastic bag ban in Town of Centreville

 January 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 489
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The town of Centreville instituted a single-use plastic bag ban that went into effect on Jan. 1.Centreville joins Anne Arundel and Prince George's counties and the City of Frederick whose plastic bag bans also started the first of the year. According to the Maryland Retailer's Alliance, more than 70% of Marylanders now live in jurisdictions with carry out bag policies in place.
On July 20, 2023, Centreville Town Council passed the ordinance to ban single-use plastic carry out bags within Centreville town limits.
For Town Council President Ashley Kaiser while the ban addresses single-use plastic bags the spirit of the ordinance is to encourage the use of reusable bags and eliminate the reliance on plastic bags, many of which end up polluting our highways and waterways.
"Consumers have an opportunity to play a significant role in the implementation of this bill. I don't think that anyone who is shopping at a local business wants to burden a local business, but instead wants to support them. If a paper bag fee is going to be a problem for you, decline the bag," says Kaiser. "There are things people can do to change their behavior like making a point to remember to always carry reusable bags with them," she adds.
Following that philosophy, the Town of Centreville launched a "Bring Your Own Bag" campaign in October in coordination with Plastic Free QAC. The campaign included specially designed reusable bags with a rack card featuring information on the bag ban as well as tips for how to remember to bring your bag to your next shopping trip.
Bags were handed out at Centreville Day in October and at the Centreville Farmers' Market Heck with the Malls market day in December and were made available at Town Hall. A limited supply of Town reusable bags and vintage farmers' market reusable bags are currently available for consumers to pick up at Centreville Town Hall from 9 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Monday through Friday.
The Centreville single-use plastic bag ordinance stipulates that retail establishments with the exception of food service facilities "shall charge, collect and retain at least 10 cents for each paper carry out bag that it provides to a customer."
Exceptions to the ordinance includes, but are not limited to:
Nonprofit fraternal, civic, war veterans, religious, or charitable organizations and fire companies can still use plastic carry out bags.
Due to cross contamination concerns restaurants may not allow customers to use their own reusable bags. Restaurants will provide paper bags, but will not charge a paper bag fee.
The Centreville Market's Market and cottage food businesses can continue to use plastic.
Pharmacies and opticians will not charge a paper bag fee for prescription items.
Consumers and business owners who want to read the full text of the ordinance and frequently asked questions can visit townofcentreville.org and type "plastic bag ban" in the search window. For more information, please contact Carol D'Agostino, mainstreet@townofcentreville.org or 410-758-1180, ext. 17.
