title: PoliTalks transitions leadership as new era begins at Washington College
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
PoliTalks transitions leadership as new era begins at Washington College

 May 1, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 822
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — The founders of PoliTalks, Washington College students Stephen Hook and Zach Affeldt, are stepping down from group leadership as they graduate next month.While both are preparing for promising careers, Hook assured the crowd at their spring lecture on April 24 at Hynson Lounge that the club's future is in good hands. The event, held on the second floor of Hodson Hall, featured renowned speaker Heather Mizeur, who delivered the lecture "Disagreement is Democratic."
The lecture, free to the public, included an introduction to the new PoliTalks leadership: co-presidents Charlotte Schurman and Grace Walsh. "We feel confident in our team to take the group forward," Schurman said during a catered meal and Q&A session following Mizeur's discussion.
Schurman and Walsh are continuing the tradition of PoliTalks: to provide a safe, respectful forum for political education and conversation.
Hook reflected on the club's success during a politically charged climate, noting that he was pleased to see people with differing views engage in peaceful discussions about polarizing issues during the Trump administration.
Mizeur, a former Maryland state delegate, candidate for Congress, and CEO and founder of WeAreOne Alliance, led these discussions. This was her second time giving the lecture. She discussed the guiding principles she learned while reaching across the aisle and campaigning.
Just as she did at the Toll Science Center on Oct. 17, 2024, Mizeur introduced her mnemonic device: **RESPECTFUL**, which stands for Reciprocity, Engagement, Sovereignty, Pause, Equanimity, Curiosity, Trust, Freedom, Unhook, and Listen.
In this session, she focused on the "S" — **Sovereignty**.
Mizeur defined sovereignty as "the ability to stand in your own agency." She explained that how we respond to political disagreements, while maintaining self-control and understanding, is key to sovereignty.
Mizeur stated that the nation's collective sovereignty is currently under assault. She criticized the Trump administration for trampling due process and weaponizing fear and control, leading to the dehumanization of people.
"The initial response to these policies," Mizeur said, "is to react with fear and frustration, instead of responding with sovereignty, which is a conscious choice rooted in integrity."
Sovereignty, Mizeur explained, is a calming force that leads us to a different path, one that cannot be legislated or controlled.
"It's not earned, but inherited," Mizeur said.
She offered lessons on how to reconnect with one's own inherited sovereignty.
Mizeur emphasized that sovereignty does not mean being a doormat. It requires setting boundaries, practicing a firm "yes" and "no," and avoiding separation from others, which leads to isolation and despair. She encouraged practices like journaling, speaking with a friend or partner, and engaging in joyful activities to help individuals maintain sovereignty.
Mizeur also emphasized the importance of listening to the body's warnings and stepping back from social media to detox and nourish oneself.
"Sovereignty is a practice, not a switch you turn on and off when needed," Mizeur added.
She said practicing these principles brings deeper joy, freedom, and can spark real change in hearts and lives.
The discussion continued over a catered dinner, where guests of all ages discussed how to apply these principles in their own lives. Some shared stories of losing friends or family members over political differences and blocking people on social media. Tensions over political debates had surfaced in families.
One attendee suggested that protests, such as the "Hands Off Rally," should include what participants are fighting for, in addition to what they oppose, emphasizing the positive.
A few attendees remarked that they no longer view people with opposing views as "enemies." A central lesson from Mizeur's talk was to lead with curiosity and learn from everyone, regardless of their political affiliation.
Others acknowledged that life experiences can lead to differing viewpoints, and sometimes, religion plays a role in those differences.
One woman pointed out issues on which everyone could agree, such as the need for more jobs and affordable housing.
Hook, who founded PoliTalks after witnessing the need for peaceful discussions on campus following a Washington College lecture by conservative speaker Robert George, expressed his satisfaction with the club's success. George had cut his speech short on Sept. 7, 2023, due to protests.
"This is the best possible way we could have ended with the club," Hook said.
He thanked everyone involved, especially Mizeur, for her nonprofit work in coalition building through community partnerships. "Heather brings a unique narrative to the conversation around political dialogue that we believe is important for our community to hear," Hook said.
For those who missed Mizeur's talks, they can sign up for her newsletter and receive information about her 2025 programming at [https://www.weareonealliance.org/](https://www.weareonealliance.org/).
What's next for PoliTalks under new leadership?Schurman noted that environmental justice is a strong focus across campus. She plans to invite Serena C. McIlwain, Maryland secretary of the environment, for a future lecture.
As they call for more student involvement, PoliTalks plans to hold monthly meetings.
Several members of the Chestertown government attended the event, including Mayor David Foster and Council Member Sheila Austrian of Ward 1. Austrian found the discussion eye-opening and thanked the college and PoliTalks for reaching out to the community in such a meaningful way.

title: TODAY IN HISTORY/Jan. 21
author: Staff Writer
content:
TODAY IN HISTORY/Jan. 21

 January 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 557
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Jan. 21, 2010, a bitterly divided U.S. Supreme Court, in Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission, vastly increased the power of big business and labor unions to influence government decisions by freeing them to spend their millions directly to sway elections for president and Congress.On this date:
In 1793, during the French Revolution, King Louis XVI, condemned for treason, was executed on the guillotine.
In 1910, the Great Paris Flood began as the rain-swollen Seine River burst its banks, sending water into the French capital.
In 1915, the first Kiwanis Club, dedicated to community service, was founded in Detroit.
In 1924, Russian revolutionary Vladimir Lenin died at age 53.
In 1942, pinball machines were banned in New York City after a court ruled they were gambling devices that relied on chance rather than skill (the ban was lifted in 1976).
In 1950, former State Department official Alger Hiss, accused of being part of a Communist spy ring, was found guilty in New York of lying to a grand jury. (Hiss, who proclaimed his innocence, served less than four years in prison.)
In 1976, British Airways and Air France inaugurated scheduled passenger service on the supersonic Concorde jet.
In 1977, on his first full day in office, President Jimmy Carter pardoned almost all Vietnam War draft evaders.
In 2003, the Census Bureau announced that Hispanics had surpassed blacks as America's largest minority group.
In 2013, a day after being inaugurated for a second term in a private ceremony, President Barack Obama took a public oath, summoning a divided nation to act with "passion and dedication" to broaden equality and prosperity at home, nurture democracy around the world and combat global warming.
In 2017, a day after Donald Trump's inauguration, more than 1 million people rallied at women's marches in the nation's capital and cities around the world to send the new president an emphatic message that they wouldn't let his agenda go unchallenged.
In 2020, the U.S. reported its first known case of the new virus circulating in China, saying a Washington state resident who had returned the previous week from the outbreak's epicenter was hospitalized near Seattle.
In 2021, on his first full day in office, President Joe Biden signed 10 executive orders aimed at combating the coronavirus pandemic.
In 2022, the FBI said Brian Laundrie, the boyfriend of slain cross-country traveler Gabby Petito, had admitted to killing her in a notebook discovered near his body in a Florida swamp.
Today's birthdays: World Golf Hall of Famer Jack Nicklaus is 84. Opera singer-conductor Placido Domingo is 83. Actor Jill Eikenberry is 77. Country musician Jim Ibbotson is 77. Singer-songwriter Billy Ocean is 74. Former U.S. Ambassador to China Gary Locke is 74. Former U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder is 73. Actor-director Robby Benson is 68. Actor Geena Davis is 68. Sen. Kevin Cramer, R-N.D., is 63. Basketball Hall of Famer Hakeem Olajuwon is 61. Actor Charlotte Ross is 56. Actor John Ducey is 55. Actor Karina Lombard is 55. Actor Ken Leung is 54. Rock musician Mark Trojanowski (Sister Hazel) is 54. Rock singer-songwriter Chan Marshall (Cat Power) is 52. Rock DJ Chris Kilmore (Incubus) is 51. Actor Vincent Laresca is 50. Singer Emma Bunton (Spice Girls) is 48. Actor Jerry Trainor is 47. Country singer Phil Stacey is 46. R&B singer Nokio is 45. Actor Izabella Miko is 43. Actor Luke Grimes is 40. Actor Feliz Ramirez is 32.

title: 'An answer to prayer'
author: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Kent County News
content:
'An answer to prayer'

 February 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Kent County News | Section: Life 
 
 447
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — When daily life is filled with burdens, needs, and concerns, how do we find ways to uplift the community around us?One local church, Emmanuel Episcopal Church on 101 N. Cross St in Chestertown, has found an answer.
Their answer lies in a chalkboard displayed on the fence outside of their church for all to access. The board, entitled "Today I pray for," was an idea that Rev. Claire Nevin-Field brought from her former church in Philadelphia.
She said the board, "was a way to hold up the concerns, griefs and joys of the community around us, both so we could pray for those things people listed and so they would know we cared about them."
In November 2023, the board made its debut on the church fence. Parishioners Andrew Field and Elizabeth Riedel built the board. Nevin-Field said when the board gets full, they take a picture of it, pray for each spot and erase it.
The prayers are also announced every Sunday during morning service.
"The board has been warmly received. Anyone who has commented to me has been grateful for the chance to put a prayer 'out there,' and the people here at Emmanuel have been glad that we can offer this to the community. If we are to love our neighbors as ourselves, we have to see every single person, every blessed person, as beloved of God and so we want to honor and respect our neighbors by praying for those things that are of concern to them. It is an acknowledgement that we are part of the community of Chestertown, Kent County, Maryland … and that what affects one of us affects each of us."
Nevin-Field shared, "I have been struck, both here and in Philly, by how people take this seriously. We have not had issues with people writing obscenities or things intended to harm a person/group of people. It seems that people take it in the spirit it is intended-to hold our neighbors in our hearts and prayers, and to share all the stuff of life together."
Who is using this board? The reverend says, "it is hard for me to say exactly who is writing on the board, but I do know it is a mix of people who come to church here and people who do not. It can be really poignant — people writing everything from someone they know and love, to refugees or prisoners or peace. It seems people appreciate the chance to name someone or something so others know and can pray with them. The things written on the board are read in the morning services every Sunday during the prayers — so we pray for everything and everyone listed."

title: Bradford House resident wants to feel safe at home after multiple assaults
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
Bradford House resident wants to feel safe at home after multiple assaults

 May 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 581
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Tena Cheaton looked forward to moving into the Bradford House Apartments about five years ago.At that time, Cheaton, now 59, was homeless.
She was receiving temporary disability assistance and waiting to be approved for supplemental security income, which is financial assistance for people who have little or no income and resources and have a disability, blindness or are 65 years of age or older.
"So I wanted to come," she said about Bradford House. "I didn't realize it was this bad."
Since moving in, Cheaton — who has PTSD, ADHD, bipolar disorder, fibromyalgia and back problems that include degenerative disc disease and spinal stenosis — said she has been assaulted, threatened and had her belongings stolen on the property.
Cheaton said that about two years ago, she was raped by a man who was staying with another tenant at Bradford House.
Cheaton said it happened in her apartment. She knew the man. He drugged her before raping her, she said.
After a few weeks of "throwing up constantly" and "crying uncontrollably," Cheaton went to rehab to get treatment.
She said it was her therapist that told her she didn't have to face her assaulter in the Bradford House halls everyday, and there were resources that could keep him out of the building.
Although Cheaton said she didn't call the police after she was raped, she did get restraining order against her rapist later on.
But despite the restraining order, Cheaton said she would still see her rapist in the halls at Bradford House.
Under the Violence Against Women Act, a housing provider may evict or terminate the assistance of a perpetrator of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault or stalking, according to the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development's Notice of Occupancy Rights under the Violence Against Women Act.
According to the notice, those who have experienced domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault or stalking must have the option to stay in their subsidized housing and can request an emergency transfer from the housing provider for safety reasons.
In a statement to the Star Democrat, Millennia Housing Management — which manages Bradford House — said the Bradford House property management team sends violations to anyone residing at the property that is the cause of an assault or theft.
Cheaton said she is not the only tenant that has been raped in the building. And this is not the only time Cheaton said she has been put in danger at Bradford House. She said she has also been held at knifepoint, threatened and assaulted on the property.
In one instance, Cheaton remembers taking her dog outside a few hours after midnight.
"I had just shut that door," she said. "And somebody standing way down there at the end of the building was hollering at me."
Cheaton, who said she doesn't leave the door to the building open for anyone, said the person was telling her to leave the door open.
She said the man got in her face and threatened to shoot her. By the time police arrived, he was gone, Cheaton said.
According to a Cambridge Police Department calls for service report requested by the Star Democrat, of the 1,099 calls for service to Bradford House made between Aug. 1, 2021, and Feb. 21, 2024, 18 were for reports of threats.
After being threatened outside the building, Cheaton — who has had experiences with substance abuse — said she moved out of Bradford House for about a month to live with her daughter.
"To stay sober in a building like this is very, very difficult," she said.

title: Diving into National Water Safety Month
author: CAROLINE COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENT
content:
Diving into National Water Safety Month

 May 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CAROLINE COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENT | Section: Life 
 
 506
 Words 

 Read News Document

 May is not just about blooming flowers and warmer weather; it's also National Water Safety Month, a crucial time to raise awareness about the importance of water safety, particularly for children.As families gear up for pool parties, beach vacations and lazy days on the river, it's essential for parents to prioritize safety to ensure that every aquatic adventure remains a fun experience.
Supervision is Key
First and foremost, maintaining constant supervision is paramount when children are around water. Whether it's a backyard pool, a nearby river or the ocean, a watchful eye can make all the difference.
Take turns designating a specific adult in your family or group as the assigned water watcher, and ensure they are not distracted by phones or other activities. Being present and attentive can be the most effective preventive measure against potential accidents.
Swim Lessons
Enrolling children in swim lessons early on is an investment in their safety and confidence around water.
Professional instructors can teach essential water skills, instill proper techniques and build a foundation for a lifetime of safe swimming. Caroline County Recreation and Parks, the YMCA and private swim instruction companies in the region offer classes suitable for different age groups, making it convenient for parents to get their kids started on this crucial life skill. Scholarships may also be available to help make lessons affordable for all families.
Know Your Limits
Understanding the swimming abilities of your children is crucial when selecting water environments. Whether it's a calm neighborhood pool or a more dynamic beach setting, choose locations that match the swimming proficiency of your kids.
Inexperienced swimmers may benefit more from controlled environments with lifeguards and clear safety guidelines.
Water Safety Gear
Equip your children with appropriate safety gear. For non-swimmers or those still building their skills, life jackets and floatation devices are essential.
Ensure that the gear fits properly and is Coast Guard-approved. These tools not only provide an added layer of protection but also boost confidence, allowing kids to enjoy the water with a sense of security.
Establish and Enforce Pool Rules
If you have a pool at home or if your children visit family or friends with pools, establish and enforce a set of safety rules.
Make sure your children understand the importance of following these rules, such as no running around the pool, no diving in shallow water and always entering the water feet first. Consistent reinforcement of these guidelines will create a safe and responsible pool environment.
Emergency Preparedness
Lastly, be prepared for emergencies. Ensure that you and your children know basic water rescue skills, CPR and how to call for help in case of an emergency. Quick response time is often crucial in water-related incidents, and having the knowledge and ability to act promptly can be lifesaving.
In conclusion, as we celebrate National Water Safety Month, let's pledge to keep our families safe, happy and splashing responsibly.
By prioritizing supervision, investing in swim lessons, choosing appropriate environments, using safety gear, establishing and enforcing pool rules and being prepared for emergencies, parents can ensure that their kids develop a love for water activities while staying safe in the process.

title: Police Unity Tour peddles through Denton
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Police Unity Tour peddles through Denton

 May 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 491
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — On May 11, a river of blue-shirted cyclists flowed down Market Street.All of these police officers on bicycles stopped at the Chesapeake Culinary Center for lunch on their Police Unity Tour, which starts in Portsmouth, Virginia, and ends in Washington, D.C.
The Police Unity Tour is a bicycle ride that raises awareness about officers who have died in the line of duty. The event raises money for the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial. Their motto is "We ride for those who died."
Anyone on any level of law enforcement can make the ride. Although Denton is a nice spot in the middle of their ride, there were no law enforcement officers from Caroline County in the ride.
"The Denton Fire Chief and Town Manager have all been great to us, opening doors. The vo-tech kids cooked lunch for us. The Culinary Center fed us," said Marlboro, New Jersey, Police Department Lt. Nicholas Szymanski.
"In 16 years, we have ridden through Denton every year. We had 650 on bicycles and another 150 or so on support. We started in Lewes, Delaware, and stopped just short of the bridge in Kent Island," Szymanski said.
These men and women have lots of visible support, not just from massive American flags hoisted between two fire truck ladders, but mini flag waving children who offer high fives along the way.
"We have chapter trucks and trailers that bring Gatorade, waters, snacks. We have a full mechanic's truck, ambulances and motor units. Believe it or not, we had the commissioner of Highway Patrol in California ride with us this year. We had about 50 motorcycles in our group alone. They will stop intersections for us. Once we start pedaling we don't stop," Szymanski said.
Their efforts have raised a lot of money over the years.
"Our chapter had 440 riders, and we raised over $400,000. We raised over $2 million overall. It is for fallen police officers. Our responsibility it to make sure that the names of the former police officers aren't forgotten," Szymanski said.
All the money goes to the National Law Enforcement Museum and the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial.
"All the names of the fallen officers are enshrined on (the memorial). There are 25,000 names on there at least. We did an expansion last year for more stones to have room for more names. We add five or 10 names to that wall every year," Szymanski said.
The names are important. But supporting the families who have lost loved ones is essential, he said.
"The most important of it — the reason we do this is we bring survivors along with us. That is somebody's family member that was killed in the line of duty. We have their wives, their kids, their family members, fathers, mothers ride with us. We had 50 survivors ride with us this year," he said.
What started with 18 riders in 1997 has grown exponentially. Since then, the Unity Tour has raised $35 million.
To learn more, go to policeunitytourchapterten.com

title: Clark, Iowa drawing sold-out crowds even on the road
author: Bill Haufe
content:
Clark, Iowa drawing sold-out crowds even on the road

 February 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: Sports 
 
 887
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Caitlin Clark has been a must-see attraction all season, with sold-out arenas where some tickets have gone for thousands of dollars on the secondary market.The prices are only expected to go higher as the Iowa star approaches the NCAA all-time scoring record over the next few weeks.
While teams like Tennessee and UConn would draw huge crowds on the road in the past and South Carolina has had a strong fan base the last few years, Clark is different. There has never been anything like it in women's basketball when an individual player has drawn so much interest from fans wanting to see her play.
"Nobody's ever had a player like this. She's a combination of Pete Maravich and Steph Curry," said Fox announcer Gus Johnson. "She plays in a different dimension and realm. Her ability to see, understand and anticipate the game and then from a physical aspect shoot the ball from almost anywhere when she gets into the frontcourt. Not even Diana Taurasi had this kind of range."
Schools that have hosted Iowa have seen an attendance increase over 150% compared to their other home games on average. Northwestern had the first sellout in school history on Wednesday night when Clark and Iowa came to visit.
According to ticket marketplace Vivid Seats, the top five most in-demand NCAA women's games this year have featured Iowa. The average price of tickets for the Hawkeyes since Clark joined the team in 2020 is up 224% and the average distance traveled by a fan to watch Iowa play is up 34% from last season.
"It's honestly, hard for me to wrap my head around. It's crazy, it's crazy the way people scream my name and really support us and I try to make time for as many as them as I can," Clark said. "Like whenever I walk off the court, it's so special just the way people scream our names and are so excited for our team. And that's something that never gets old. I was that kid a few years back, so it's crazy how time flies and I just try to soak it all in, every single moment."
It's not just kids who want to see Clark and her deep 3's in action.
Former Iowa high school teammates Susan Johnstad, Deb Littlefield and Stephanie Fournier met at the Iowa-Rutgers game on Jan. 5 in Piscataway, New Jersey. They played basketball and softball together at Roland Story High School, about 45 miles from where Clark grew up in Des Moines.
"It's been 30 years since we've all been together," said Johnstad, who suggested they travel from their current homes in Virginia, Massachusetts and Iowa to watch Clark. "We played six-on-six basketball, and Iowa has such a tradition of supporting women's basketball. Clark's skill set is just amazing. In her recent commercial for Gatorade, she said she dreams big — and it shows."
Johnstad says she's proud to see the joy last year's AP player of the year brings to fans wearing her No. 22 jersey, young and old.
"I'm a fan girl, for sure," said Johnstad, who is an administrator at Virginia Tech. "I can see her play on television. But (it's fun) to be able to see the people lined up beforehand and the girls working on their signs and doing the face paints."
Clark is part of a new generation of stars that fans can easily and constantly see, through highlights on social media and games available on a whole host of networks and streaming services.
Back when Candace Parker, Diana Taurasi, Maya Moore and Sheryl Swoopes were dominating the game it was harder to see them play. Twitter and Instagram weren't around — YouTube was launched in 2005 — and players weren't allowed to star in national commercial campaigns like Clark is doing with State Farm and Nike.
Last year's national championship game that featured Iowa and LSU drew almost 10 million viewers. This year, the Hawkeyes have already had games on NBC, Fox and ESPN. The overtime loss to Ohio State on NBC averaged 1.93 million viewers across the network and Peacock, peaking at 3.9 million during overtime. Over a million fans tuned in for Iowa's win over Indiana on Fox.
Also in that crowd for the game at Rutgers was New Jersey Devils President Jake Reynolds. With him were his three daughters, Makenzie, 13, Katelyn, 10, and Harper, 8.
"This is something we decided to go to. Not a Rutgers season ticket holder, but this was part of the Caitlin Clark phenomenon," he said. "It was something that I sat there in amazement, just looking at the energy of what was going on around this event. Then I was blown away by just the response from so many fans. And then I was really proud to see so many young girls there."
Reynolds said watching Clark play in person has had a lasting effect on his daughters.
"To be able to, one, just witness the phenomenon that it is," he said. "To be able to give my girls the opportunity and the experience to see that firsthand, someone that inspires them and someone that they aspire to be like, to be able to give them that experience and be able to share that experience with them is something that here we are several weeks later and it is still something that is talked about in our house."

title: Federalsburg celebrates voting rights on anniversary of historic election
author: Tom McCall
content:
Federalsburg celebrates voting rights on anniversary of historic election

 October 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: News 
 
 529
 Words 

 Read News Document

 FEDERALSBURG — Sept. 26 marked the first anniversary of the historic election of the first Black Town Council members in Federalsburg. The community gathered over several days to celebrate.Many Black residents of the town and NAACP members marked the occasion by observing Voting Rights Day on Sept. 26, participating in Unity Day activities on Sept. 28, and appreciating the new signage placed at the entrance to the primarily Black residential community of Brooklyn in Federalsburg.
"Federalsburg was hosting. The town was the organizer of the event. It is the first anniversary," Willie G. Woods, president of the NAACP Caroline County Branch, said. "We were there to support what was happening in Federalsburg. They had a cross section of vendors and participants and music and food."
Woods said it is important to stand up and be heard.
"You have to come together and share your ideas, your viewpoints and your respective cultures. And you have to respect the contributions that the diverse population is making," she said.
Brandy James, a Federalsburg Town Council member elected in last year's historic election, said the event was a success and that there was a good crowd.
"It symbolized unity to me. We had people from every aspect of Federalsburg. The faith-based community was there. Law enforcement was there. Not just Federalsburg police, but also the Caroline County Sheriff was there," said James.
She said there were many vendors there, including the Caroline County Health Department and smoking cessation resources.
"The NAACP has a table, Men For Change, there were churches with tables out there. They were giving away free cotton candy, and the kids had a blast. It was a great way to see everyone from across the lifespan come together and celebrate the unity of Federalsburg," James said.
She said the actual business of sitting on the council is slower than she would like, but she said everyone is being fairly heard.
"I am hopeful to see more African American people run for office in the future, and I am hopeful that the town business will get a little more streamlined and more organized," she said.
The Sept. 26 celebration and plaque were requirements of a settlement in a 2023 lawsuit brought against the town in federal court under the Voting Rights Act of 1965. Through months of charter amendments, legislation and federal court rulings, the town's previous at-large election system was changed in June to a two-district system to ensure more representation of Federalsburg's Black residents. District 1 has a 64% Black population and District 2 is predominantly white.
The sign that was placed at Brooklyn said, in part, "In coordination with the Mayor and the Council of Federalsburg, created an opportunity for Federalsburg's Black community to elect two representatives to the Federalsburg Town Council. Through their efforts, with support of the ACLU of Maryland and the guidance from the United States District Court, the town adopted and implemented a new and fair election system, undoing the 200 year exclusion of Black residents from town government. Federalsburg's historic election on September 26, 2023 resulted in two Black women winning seats to the town council: Darlene Pitt Hammond and Brandy James. This day forever marks a turning point in Federalsburg's diverse community."

title: Ward 4 candidates talk property taxes, housing
author: Konner Metz
content:
Ward 4 candidates talk property taxes, housing

 April 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 734
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Candidates for the Ward 4 seat on the Easton Town Council have offered varying opinions on the town's property tax rate.Incumbent the Rev. Elmer Davis, Moonyene Jackson-Amis and Cameron Keefe are squaring off in the town's election May 6. Each discussed their views on property taxes, housing and more in interviews with The Star Democrat's editorial board last week.
Currently, the town levies a tax on real property at 52 cents per $100 of assessed value. That mark hasn't changed since 2008. It's higher than Talbot County's other towns, but relatively low compared to Eastern Shore towns such as Cambridge, Denton and Salisbury.
Property values, though, have increased significantly in recent years. The state's 2025 reassessments showed the value of Group 1 residential and commercial properties in Talbot County increased by 22.1% from 2022. The town's proposed fiscal year 2026 budget projects $13.6 million in real property tax revenue, slightly up from last year. It was a tight and "lean" budget, Mayor Megan Cook has said.
Davis, who's been on the council since 2020, said the property tax rate should be increased.
"I think the mayor's playing around a little bit. … They're not fiscally responsible," Davis said. "We have not raised taxes, and here's the problem. We got that COVID money. We've been living high on the hog, and now we have to pay the piper."
Jackson-Amis, Ward 4's representative from 2001 to 2008, says the Town Council should have conversations with professionals about potential tax breaks.
"I think the property tax is a little steep," Jackson-Amis said. "It seems like the idea is to get, to have a money funnel. A funnel as opposed to exacting what's necessary to support the budget."
Keefe in his interview emphasized fiscal responsibility, while adding he understands new initiatives cost money.
"They make a lot of decisions that don't affect their wealth, but it affects everybody else's wealth," Keefe said of the council. " ... We need to dismantle this ivory tower thing."
HOUSING
The Ward 4 hopefuls each touched on plans to improve Easton's affordable housing stock. Keefe said "we need to make Easton not just survivable, but livable."
"We can say all the buzz words we want, but I would love to see specifically starter homes in Easton, things that draw young families here," Keefe said.
He said he hopes to sit down with town planners to discuss their proposed inclusionary zoning ordinance that would require residential developers to allocate 15% of their units as affordable.
Jackson-Amis says she's "all for inclusionary zoning." She hopes to revisit the requirement that developers include 25% low or middle-income units in projects, an effort she supported in her prior stint on the council.
"If you're getting a benefit from the town, we need to be able to exact a benefit from you," Jackson-Amis said. "If you're creating housing, we ought to know what our housing needs are, and that it shouldn't just be for the financial gain of wealthy people."
Davis said he's "not 100% sure" current housing legislation in the works will answer all of Easton's housing needs. He advocated for the town to buy a piece of land and work with nonprofits.
"The town should buy a piece of land," Davis said. "And the town should partner with Habitat (for Humanity) or some other organization to … ensure that we deal holistically with the person and the property."
EXPERIENCE
The Ward 4 candidates bring different experience levels to the table.
Davis, 58, said he focused on constituent representation during his time on the council, such as when he supported a seafood odor ordinance last year.
"I'm in the position as the council member because of the people," he said. "I represent those individuals in my ward. I'm not the end-all, be-all. So if my constituents say that this is what they want, then I represent them well."
Jackson-Amis, 77, said "we should look toward wisdom."
"Right now you need people with some seasoned ability to ferret out issues and help bring solutions to problems," she said. "So I don't think age really should be that important, but I think the experience is what should matter."
Keefe, 25, said he wants more youth involvement in the town.
"I know I'm young. That is by no means any reason to take this lightly," Keefe said. "I think this is important. I think there's a lot of potential for good that can happen from this. And above all of those things, I want to be a representative who listens."

title: Blues traveler - Blues singer Shemekia Copeland returns to Avalon with concert, music from award-winning album
content:
Blues traveler - Blues singer Shemekia Copeland returns to Avalon with concert, music from award-winning album

 August 3, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 241
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Award-winning Blues singer Shemekia Copeland is headed back to Maryland's Eastern Shore.Copeland will celebrate her new album "Done Come Too Far" with live performance at the Avalon Theatre in downtown Easton (40 E. Dover Street) on Friday, Aug. 18.The show starts at 8 p.m.Tickets are priced between $37 and $42.For more on tickets and the show: www.avalonfoundation.org or 410-822-7299 (Avalon Theatre Box office) Copeland is a popular Blues singer. Her new album is produced by Alligator Records and was nominated for a Grammy last year. The album won the Critics Award for Best Contemporary Blues Album and the album's producer, Will Kimbrough, won the Critics Award for Producer of the Year."Done Come Too Far"'s title track was the #2 most played track on SiriusXM's Bluesville channel, where Copeland continues to host her own daily radio program, according to a release promoting the upcoming Easton concert.Musical guests on Copeland's newest album include slide guitar wizard Sonny Landreth, Mississippi Hill country blues icons Cedric Burnside and Kenny Brown, Memphis soul keyboard legend Charles Hodges, Oliver Wood (of the Wood Brothers), Americana star Aaron Lee Tasjan and Pat Sansone (of Wilco)."This album was made by all sides of me - happy, sad, silly, irate - they're all a part who I am and who we all are. I'm not political.I'm just talking about what's happening in this country," Copeland said in the release.

title: Candidate was truly impressive
author: Staff Writer
content:
Candidate was truly impressive

 May 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 371
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last evening I attended the candidates' forum at the Avalon, moderated by Craig Fuller and sponsored by the Talbot Spy.It was well attended, and I'm glad that it will be available for viewing by those who missed the live event, because the upcoming May 6 election should be — and is — important to every single resident of Easton. It will impact town spending, how development takes place and whether we can work together to plan and achieve shared goals.
While I don't doubt all the candidates are devoted to their families, kind to their neighbors, happy to live in Easton, and aware of the issues, we should all expect a great deal more from public servants.
Only one candidate, Moonyene Jackson-Amis — running to represent Ward 4 on the council — was truly impressive to me. This highly educated woman — a practicing attorney, compassionate activist and experienced local public servant — spoke in specifics, rather than generalities. It was clear that she understands the needs of the residents of Ward 4 and the town at large.
She talked about practical ways to help wage-earners qualify for licensing in their various trades by incentivizing contractors to take advantage of their skills, thereby facilitating their advancement. She called for a study on repurposing the current hospital as a regional medical center for military veterans. She advocated for updates to a program she initiated during her prior term on the council so that residents can afford to stay in their homes. She suggested a new tourist attraction that would make use of an unused existing building. And she had other practical ideas as well. It's clear she has a well-thought-out action plan ready to go if she's elected.
What's more, Moonyene obviously knows how to leverage all the elements needed to bring plans to fruition. That is the essential asset drawn from her knowledge of the law and wealth of experience, an asset that others appear to lack. She wants to serve constituents, not herself.
I believe our Town Council will be a stronger, more effective body if Moonyene is elected. I hope everyone in Ward 4 already has a plan to be at our fire station on May 6 to vote for Ms. Jackson-Amis.
WENDY ROTH
Easton

title: MACo and Talbot County Council discuss fiscal pressures facing state
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
MACo and Talbot County Council discuss fiscal pressures facing state

 September 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 490
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — When entering last year's General Assembly, the fiscal situation Maryland faced needed serious attention. In some ways, that fiscal pressure has increased since.Michael Sanderson, the executive director of the Maryland Association of Counties, briefed the Talbot County Council on those financial troubles and more during a special meeting Tuesday.
He told council members a budget shortfall of potentially $600 to $800 million could be facing lawmakers in Annapolis. Fixing that is "not easy, but not impossible," he said.
"There are a couple of years of that in our forecast, and then it gets really serious," Sanderson said.
When fiscal year 2028 arrives, Sanderson warned that the state will run out of money in its trust fund that's been used for The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's expansive and optimistic education initiative.
Many counties have been under significant financial pressure due to state requirements stemming from Blueprint. Sanderson says the state will be feeling that level of pressure soon.
"The counties are feeling it now," he said. "The state doesn't really feel it for a couple years down the road, and that has been a meaningful disconnect."
Without significant timeline adjustments for Blueprint from the state, MACo feels there will continue to be that disconnect between the fiscal situation of the state versus the situation counties are facing. State funding for transportation, though, is already causing serious impacts, Sanderson said.
"The canary in the coal mine that's already chirping is in transportation," he told the council members. " … The conversation in the summer time is sometimes ambiguous and hazy and that sort of thing. But this year, not so much. They were just saying, 'If there aren't already shovels in the ground, we can't afford the next thing.'"
The Maryland Department of Transportation has been forced to delay many statewide projects amid a significant budget deficit. Earlier this month, the department released a draft plan that showed $1.3 billion in cuts from the state's six-year transportation plan.
Sanderson noted the "state's transportation challenge is not a function of the Key Bridge" rebuild, which is set to begin next year.
At the county level, council Vice President Pete Lesher said Talbot County is "finding itself in a slightly different place" than others.
"We are going through a number of capital construction projects, our health department, our sheriff's office, our 911 center," Lesher said, emphasizing some of those projects are receiving "pandemic-era related funds" from the federal government.
"The pinch that a lot of counties are feeling right now, the income tax, is not yet being felt in Talbot County," Lesher said. "We can look around at our neighbors and see what is coming, even though we are not yet in that position now."
Lesher thanked Sanderson and MACo President Johnny Olszewski Jr. for their work to represent the counties at the state level year-round.
"We know that we are stronger together in Annapolis," Lesher said. "And we see every year what a powerful voice MACo is for all of us jointly."

title: Man completes Eagleman after non-Hodgkins lymphoma
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Man completes Eagleman after non-Hodgkins lymphoma

 June 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: News 
 
 389
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — For Craig Casterella, mind over matter is more of a lifestyle than a saying. This was especially true on Sunday, when Casterella finished the Ironman 70.3 Eagleman in six and a half hours.The triathlon, held in Cambridge, consisted of a 1.2-mile swim, a 56-mile bike ride and a 13.1-mile run.
"I cried at the end. I was ecstatic. I couldn't hold my emotions in, and it truly just goes to show that with determination, consistency and resilience, you can do so much in any facet of life," Casterella said.
The 31-year-old was inspired to train for the Eagleman in 2024 after a yearlong battle with non-Hodgkins lymphoma, a blood cancer most commonly found in older adults. Casterella said only 22,000 people a year get diagnosed with the disease, so it's important to create and spread awareness.
When Casterella was diagnosed in October of 2023, his perspective on life changed.
"Your life flashes before you. You start thinking about your past, you start thinking about your present and then about your future," he said. "And when younger people get diagnosed with a serious illness that is life or death, your future becomes so important, and you think about what you can accomplish and what you can possibly do before ending up in a coffin or six feet under. You start thinking about those things."
While going through chemotherapy, Casterella found a community on social media.
"Social media was my outlet to find others who were going through disease and illness, but also attacking life while going through disease and illness," he said. Online, Casterella fostered relationships with people who he now considers mentors.
Since going into remission, he uses social media to inspire others to "attack life," even when facing adversity.
Casterella said endurance sports are like going through a disease or illness. He had to endure a lot of things he didn't want to while going through treatment, but he saw it as a way to challenge himself mentally and physically, just like the triathlon.
"For me, coming out of this weekend, realizing that truly anything we set our minds to, dedicate, commit to, you can do anything. Don't just dream it. The things you wish you could do, just set goals will do it. I promise, it's never too late to start," he said.
Casterella plans on racing in another Eagleman in the near future.

title: Family holding out hope for turf field project at Easton High
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Family holding out hope for turf field project at Easton High

 August 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 695
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The prospects of an artificial turf field at Easton High School are uncertain as the school year approaches.Jen Hawley's 18-year-old daughter, Elgin, has been a champion of the turf field. Elgin asked for it to be added to the school district's budget request last year as part of her wish with the Make-A-Wish Foundation.
Jen Hawley hoped to see the project take shape before Elgin left for college this summer. She asked Make-A-Wish to maintain its commitment to the project until July 31 before the nonprofit needed to begin working on a new wish for Elgin.
Talbot County Public Schools received $1.5 million from the county meant to allocate towards outstanding capital projects this fiscal year, such as the turf field, which has an estimated price of $1.8 million.
At the end of July, Hawley said she was told the Board of Education is passing on partnering with Make-A-Wish for the turf field project.
"We're right back to where we started," Hawley said.
In mid-August of 2021, on the third day of field hockey tryouts, Elgin had an aneurysm on the field. It took almost two weeks after she collapsed before she began talking again, and it wasn't until February 2022 that she returned to school.
Elgin, who graduated this spring, hasn't been able to play field hockey since the aneurysm. When Make-A-Wish Mid-Atlantic granted her one wish, she asked for a turf field to be put in at Easton High.
With support from Make-A-Wish and a group of supporters known as "Elgin's Army," the turf field was requested at a board meeting in July 2023 and later added to the budget by the board in December 2023.
At a Board of Education work session in June, President Emily Jackson said while she's a "vocal proponent" of the turf field project, she wasn't committed to allocating funds towards it this fiscal cycle.
"I am not necessarily saying, no, never let's not do it," Jackson said. "But I'm saying that I think there are a lot of questions to be asked. Is turf the best option? Should we be going with really high-quality grass instead? What is going to cause the least number of injuries?"
The board has not made an official decision allocating the $1.5 million. Capital projects that are vying for the funding, such as new auditorium lights at Easton High and a playground replacement at St. Michaels Elementary, total to around $3.3 million.
Hawley believes if the district had acted sooner and actively partnered with Make-A-Wish, the $1.8 million estimate for the turf field could have been significantly lowered by donations, as well as a potential contribution from a turf field supplier.
"Having Make-A-Wish on our team … we could've gotten the field for much less," Hawley said.
County Council Member Dave Stepp has been a proponent of the efforts of Elgin's Army and a potential turf field installation during the past year.
"Just from the overwhelming support of coaches and players who have shown up to express interest in how great that would be for our local athletes, I think that speaks for itself," Stepp said.
"I do know that they do have funds in reserve that they can make up the difference between the $1.5 (million) that we had given this fiscal year and the cost of the actual estimate," Stepp said regarding the Board of Education. "So they can do that at any time they're ready to do so, and I'm optimistic that they will, and I hope so personally sooner than later."
Lesli Creedon, president and CEO of Make-A-Wish Mid-Atlantic, said the organization is fully committed to providing Elgin another wish. Creedon said the average wish granted by Make-A-Wish Mid-Atlantic is around $10,000, and that the foundation was prepared to contribute around that mark toward a turf field installation.
"While I am disappointed that the BOE passed in the partnership with Make-A-Wish and do think (it's) shortsighted, I am hopeful that the county and its citizens will do more to support its young athletes and instill pride in our public schools," Elgin Hawley said in an emailed statement to The Star Democrat. "And whatever they decide they continue to think of me and my story to move the field forward as a priority."

title: Old Christmas - History, traditions and celebrations of Jan. 6 holiday
content:
Old Christmas - History, traditions and celebrations of Jan. 6 holiday

 January 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 3A | Section: News 
 
 479
 Words 

 Read News Document

 You might have thought Christmas was over. You might also associate Jan. 6 with the political events of 2021.But Jan. 6 is actually the end of traditional 12 Days of Christmas celebrations.
The 12 days marks the birth of Jesus (Dec. 25) through the Coming of the Magi (the Three Wise Men).
Some customs count the 12 days from sundown Dec. 25 until the morning of Jan. 6.
Early Christians celebrated Christmas on Jan. 6 until the Roman Empire moved the holiday to Dec. 25 in the 336 A.D. during the reign of Emperor Constantine. The late December date took the place of pagan holidays celebrating Roman gods and the Winter Solstice.
Still, Jan 6. continued to be celebrated as Christmas by Britons and other Europeans in the Julian calendar.
The changeover to the Gregorian calendar in 1582 moved Christmas to Dec. 25 and closer to the Winter Solstice.
It was adopted by the British and Irish in 1752 which helped bring the calendar change to the American colonies.
Other European countries, including Russia and its Eastern European neighbors, did not switch over until the early 20th Century. Orthodox Christians still celebrate Christmas on Jan. 7.
Still, Jan. 6 holds a place in Christmas celebrations for Armenians, the Irish as well as folks in Appalachia and some Christian believers such as the Amish and Mennonites.
Armenians - who are among the earliest in the Christian faith - still celebrate Christmas on Jan. 6.
In Ireland, the Jan. 6 celebrations have included women getting together for their own holiday festivities and the men of their households handling the cooking, cleaning and other chores for a day.
In Appalachia, Old Christmas still has a place for some with traditions such as getting together with family and friends, putting candles in windows and holiday food such as versions of fruitcakes (including apple stack cake), mincemeat pies and Christmas hams and serenading friends and neighbors.
There are also Appalachian superstitions that animals can speak at midnight on Old Christmas Day Jan. 6.
That superstition is on top Appalachians' holiday traditions such as eating ham hocks, black-eyed peas and greens on New Year's Day for good luck.
The Amish and Mennonites also celebrate Old Christmas with cakes, pies and other holiday foods as well as religious services. 
 
 Caption: AP PHOTO/JENS MEYER

 Old Christmas is celebrated Jan. 6 in Appalachia and by the Amish, Mennonites, some Irish and other Christians. The birth of Jesus Christ was originally celebrated on Jan. 6 by many Europeans in the Julian calendar before being changed to Dec. 25. Jan. 6 is also the end of the 12 Days of Christmas, according to various customs.

 AP PHOTO/CZAREK SOKOLOWSKI

 Christmas was long celebrated on Jan. 6 in Great Britain, Ireland and other part of Europe until the changeover from the Julian to Gregorian calendars. Armenians still celebrate the birth of Jesus on Jan. 6 and Old Christmas is still commemorated in Appalachia and by the Amish and Mennonites.

title: Mid-Shore Calendar
author: Staff Writer
content:
Mid-Shore Calendar

 September 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Calendar 
 
 2251
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Those seeking to have an event published in the Star Democrat's calendar are asked to email details to community@stardem.com.YARN AND NEEDLE GROUP, 12:30 to 3 p.m., Brookletts Place Talbot County Senior Center, Easton. Every Tuesday. Some help may be available for knitting and crocheting. Open to anyone 60 years of age or older at no cost. Info: 410-822-2869.
WEDNESDAY MORNING ARTISTS, weekly at 9:30 a.m., 900 Peachblossom Place, Cambridge. All are welcome, from beginners to pros. There is always opportunity and something interesting to learn and see. Group shares our artwork at meetings and collaborates with many different forms of media. Artists' work displayed in the window of Vintage Venue on Race Street in Cambridge. Facebook: wednesdaymorningartists. Email is: wednesdaymorningartists@gmail.com.
FREE ESTATE PLANNING SEMINAR, 6 p.m., Benedictine Community Services and Training Center, 723 Goldsborough St, Suite A, Easton. Guest speaker: Tara K Frame, Esq of Frame & Frame Attorneys at Law. Topics include: estate planning basics and special needs trust. Free admission. Advance registration requested 410-634-2292.
A DATE WITH HISTORY LECTURE, 1 p.m., Talbot County Free Library, 100 W. Dover St., Easton. "Sit, Stay, Heal: The Biology of the Human-Animal Bond and it's Healing Power" with Meg Olmert. Presented by Talbot Historical Society. Free admission, reservation required. 410-822-0773, kaylaw@talbothistory.org.
COMMUNITY TALK, 5:30 p.m., Oxford Community Center. Dan Small, the associate director of natural land stewardship at the Center for Environment and Society at Washington College, will talk about the plans for expanding the Oxford Conservation Park and how it fits with the goals of the Natural Lands Project. Free. RSVP at oxfordcc.org.
PAWS FOR READING, 3:40 to 4:25 p.m., every fourth Thursday, Central Branch library, Denton. Children ages 5 to 12 can proactice reading to a trained service dog. One registrant per session. Register: carolib.libcal.com.
CAMBRIDGE FARMERS MARKET, 3 to 6 p.m., Long Wharf, High and Water Streets, Cambridge. Find local produce, meats, cheeses, crafts, and more at the weekly, waterfront Cambridge Farmers Market. Info: office@downtowncambridge.org.
'ROOTED WISDOM' PODCAST LAUNCH, 7 to 9 p.m., Avalon Theatre, 40 E. Dover St., Easton. In this new podcast series, Anthony Cohen, historian, Menare Foundation president and explorer of the American past, sets out to find the stories of the Underground Railroad. Register: adkins.donorshops.com/product/RW-podcast-launch/rooted-wisdom-podcast-launch-september-26.
'VIOLIN VIRTUOSO,' 7:30 p.m., Easton Church of God, 1009 N. Washington St., Easton. The Mid-Atlantic Symphony Orchestra proudly opens its 27th season as the Delmarva Peninsula's only professional symphony orchestra with a concert series titled "Violin Virtuoso." Tickets: midatlanticsymphony.org.
FRIDAY NIGHT DINNER, 5 to 7:30 p.m., VFW Post 5118, 355 Glebe Road, Easton. Community invited. Held every Friday.
CHESAPEAKE FILM FESTIVAL, Ebenezer Theater, 17 S. Washington St., Easton. Info and schedule: chesapeakefilmfestival.com/.
YOGA CLASS, Oxford Community Center, 200 Oxford Road. 9:30 a.m. Intermediate yoga with Suzie Hurley. Info: 410-226-5904 or oxfordcc.org.
FEDERALSBURG HERITAGE DAY, 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., Heritage Museum, 100 Covey-Williams Alley. Special exhibit of images and artifacts from the Caroline County Minutemen. Former Federalsburg Town Manager and State Senator Rich Colburn will be speak at 1 p.m. Raffle, dinner at Exeter House, bake sale, light refreshments.
EASTON FARMERS MARKET, 8 a.m. to 1 p.m., 100 Block North Washington Street, Easton. Open rain or shine. Live music at 10:30 a.m.
ST. MICHAELS FARMERS MARKET, 8:30 to 11 a.m., 206 S. Talbot Street, St. Michaels. Open rain or shine.
CAR SHOW, 9 a.m. to 4 p.m., Preston Carnival Grounds, 114 Williamson St., Preston. Proceeds go to Bardet Biedl Syndrome Foundation and Preston Elementary special needs program. $20 registration. Info: 410-924-0042.
BEER GARDEN, 1 to 4 p.m., Adkins Arboretum, 12610 Eveland Rd., Ridgely. Kick off fall with an afternoon of live music, great beer, and tasty food in one of the Eastern Shore's most beautiful outdoor spaces. Tickets: adkins.donorshops.com/product/2024-BEERGARDEN/beer-garden.
CHESAPEAKE FILM FESTIVAL, Ebenezer Theater, 17 S. Washington St., Easton. Info and schedule: chesapeakefilmfestival.com/.
JOUSTING CHAMPIONSHIP, 1 p.m., Tuckahoe Equestrian Center, 619 Crouse Mill Road, Queen Anne. Jousting is Maryland's official state sport. Open to the public to watch. Please bring your own chairs. Info: 410-310-7945.
TALBOT BIRD CLUB, Waterfowl, gulls, terns, and passerines. Bring binoculars. Meet at Wade's Point parking area on the left before the Inn on Wade's Point Rd, McDaniel at 7 a.m. Leaders: Trish Cope (trishcope73@gmail.com) and Ron Griffin (901-634-7785 or ckayakin@yahoo.com). Breakfast to follow hosted by Lisa Sargeant ($5 donation).

title: TODAY IN HISTORY/April 22
author: Staff Writer
content:
TODAY IN HISTORY/April 22

 April 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 478
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On April 22, 2000, in a dramatic pre-dawn raid, armed immigration agents seized 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez, the Cuban boy at the center of a custody dispute, from his relatives' home in Miami; Elian was reunited with his father at Andrews Air Force Base near Washington.On this date:
In 1889, the Oklahoma Land Rush began at noon as thousands of homesteaders staked claims.
In 1915, the first full-scale use of deadly chemicals in warfare took place as German forces unleashed chlorine gas against Allied troops at the start of the Second Battle of Ypres in Belgium during World War I; thousands of soldiers are believed to have died.
In 1937, thousands of college students in New York City staged a "peace strike" opposing American entry into another possible world conflict.
In 1944, during World War II, U.S. forces began invading Japanese-held New Guinea with amphibious landings at Hollandia and Aitape.
In 1954, the publicly televised sessions of the Senate Army-McCarthy hearings began.
In 1970, millions of Americans concerned about the environment observed the first "Earth Day."
In 1993, the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum was dedicated in Washington, D.C., to honor victims of Nazi extermination.
In 1994, Richard M. Nixon, the 37th president of the United States, died at a New York hospital four days after having a stroke; he was 81.
In 2004, Army Ranger Pat Tillman, who'd traded in a multi-million-dollar NFL contract to serve in Afghanistan, was killed by friendly fire; he was 27.
In 2005, Zacarias Moussaoui pleaded guilty in a federal courtroom outside Washington, D.C., to conspiring with the Sept. 11 hijackers to kill Americans. (Moussaoui is serving a life prison sentence.)
In 2010, the Deepwater Horizon oil platform, operated by BP, sank into the Gulf of Mexico two days after a massive explosion that killed 11 workers.
In 2012, the U.S. and Afghanistan reached a deal on a strategic partnership agreement ensuring that Americans would provide military and financial support to the Afghan people for at least a decade beyond 2014, the deadline for most foreign forces to withdraw.
In 2013, a seriously wounded Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was charged in his hospital room with bombing the Boston Marathon in a plot with his older brother, Tamerlan, who died after a fierce gunbattle with police.
In 2016, leaders from 175 countries signed the Paris Agreement on climate change at the United Nations as the landmark deal took a key step toward entering into force years ahead of schedule.
In 2017, Erin Moran, the former child star who played Joanie Cunningham in the sitcoms "Happy Days" and "Joanie Loves Chachi," died in New Salisbury, Indiana; she was 56.
In 2022, hockey Hall of Famer Guy Lafleur, who helped the Montreal Canadiens win five Stanley Cup titles in the 1970s, died at age 70.
In 2023, Ken Potts, one of the last two remaining survivors of the USS Arizona battleship, which sank during the 1941 Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, died. He was 102. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Ed Spec Committee recommends North Caroline site for new Lockerman Middle
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Ed Spec Committee recommends North Caroline site for new Lockerman Middle

 July 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 467
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — The Caroline County Board of Education is one step closer to picking a new location for Lockerman Middle School.At the monthly Board of Education meeting Tuesday, the Lockerman Middle School Ed Specs Committee said that after the feasibility study and community input, the recommended location for the new school is on the same property as North Caroline High School.
Board of Education members decided not to formally vote on a location after receiving almost two hours of information from the Ed Specs Committee. The board decided to push the decision back to the August meeting.
Multiple reasons came forward on why the North Caroline High site was recommended over the Double Hills Road site.
"Some of the highlights that came out throughout the analysis and the surveys was again, the infrastructure. If you're not spending a lot of money on that, the site readiness, the educational alignment, a lot of really exciting ideas came out during the community meeting of ways that you could really have mentorships and things like that with the older and the younger students being on one site," said Robyn Toth, architect for the new school.
Reason included the use for indoor and outdoor activities and the ability to share space for events at North Caroline High.
"There's clear paths for the indoor and outdoor activities," Toth said. "There's no crossing of streets, lots of capabilities there also because you are sharing more spaces… There were some concerns about large events and right now, if they're at Double Hills or if they're at Lockerman now, where do we go for these large events? That don't happen that often and you don't necessarily need to build more space that the state's not going to support. Well, you've got a high school right there that's got a large auditorium. It's got a large gym."
With the North Caroline High location, development prices will be about $500,000 cheaper. The site development for the North Caroline High location will be $10 million, while Double Hills Road would cost $10.5 million.
Although in the community meetings multiple builds were shown, the new middle school, regardless of the location, will be a two-story building with a two-wing design.
According to the Ed Specs Committee Powerpoint, the new anticipated project budget would be $103.82 million with state funding coming in at around $80 million and local funding covering the remainder.
The only concerns brought up about the North Caroline High site were the solar array on the property and the traffic Central Avenue could receive from a new school being added to the location.
To purchase the solar panels on the property, it would cost about $180,000, which doesn't include the cost of relocation.
The Board of Education will take all the information received and make a decision on what location will be picked at its August meeting.

title: Bridge - Which should be the trump suit?
author: Phillip Alder
content:
Bridge - Which should be the trump suit?

 August 7, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: A8 | Section: News 
 
 256
 Words 

 Read News Document

 To start today, look only at the West hand. On your right, South opens one heart, you pass (I assume!), North responds one notrump (forcing or nonforcing, it doesnâ€™t matter), partner doubles (a takeout double of hearts), and righty rebids two hearts.What would you do?This problem faced four players at Bridge Base Online. You might pass, but that seems a tad cautious.Once you decide to do something, which suit would you prefer to be trumps: hearts or clubs?It seems clear to me that the answer is hearts. You cannot even guarantee an eight-card club fit, and you would have to win nine tricks. If so, surely you can take six or seven tricks in a heart contract for plus 200 or 500. Note the vulnerability.All four BBO players advanced with three clubs.Nine other Wests saw South open two hearts and East double in fourth position.Everyone ran to three clubs (using Lebensohl to warn of a weak hand).Now look at the full deal.How do two hearts and three clubs fareftIf the defenders are careful against two hearts doubled, they can take one spade, two hearts, two diamonds, one club and a diamond ruff for down two, plus 500.However, it isnâ€™t so straightforward. The play might well begin diamond, diamond, diamond ruff, a club to the king and another diamond. Then, though, South discards his spade loser and escapes for down one. East must shift swiftly to a spade, which is not obvious.Still, plus 200 would have been a cold top!

title: Waterfowl Festival soaring to new heights
author: Staff Writer
content:
Waterfowl Festival soaring to new heights

 November 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editorials 
 
 579
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Congratulations to the many people who made this year's Waterfowl Festival a success.The annual celebration of wildlife, art, music and history brought between 25,000 and 30,000 people to Easton last weekend.
Congratulations, too, go to Deena Kilmon in her first year as executive director of the festival. She is definitely at the top of the list for a rookie of the year award.
If there was any fear of a drop-off with new leadership, Kilmon put those fears to rest and set a high bar for success in coming years.
"We know we broke every record we've ever broken," Kilmon said on Monday.
"We had the highest attendance ever," Kilmon said. "It's hard for us to gauge because not everyone buys a ticket. But we do know that every parking space was full and every bus had about 45 minutes to an hourlong wait, and we had to add three buses on Saturday to accommodate the people."
Kilmon got a helping hand from Mother Nature who blessed the weekend with lovely weather and temperatures approaching 80 degrees under sunny skies for several of the days.
The executive director said multiple vendors — many of whom are already asking about next year — sold out or had record days at the festival.
If you have a 2025 calendar already, mark the weekend of Nov. 14-16 for the 54th Waterfowl Festival. We have no doubt that Kilmon will improve upon the tremendous success of this year's festival.
The success of the Waterfowl Festival is a success for the town of Easton and Talbot County too.
Downtown Easton shops were packed all three days of the festival, and restaurants had waiting lists for tables.
Kilmon called the relationship between the festival and local businesses "incredibly important."
"We're symbiotic," she said. "So if they succeed, we succeed and vice versa."
The three-day festival has an economic impact of more than $3 million each year, Kilmon said. It benefits hotels, restaurants, retailers and even local nonprofits.
"It's typically one of the biggest fundraising events of the year because a lot of the food vendors and people involved in the festival, they are nonprofits," Kilmon said. "And they're allowed to keep their proceeds, so it's extremely important to a lot of people."
At a breakfast Friday morning, Talbot County Economic Development and Tourism Director Cassadra Vanhooser extolled the virtues of the business community that makes the "wonderful things" that happen in the county possible.
"It's that private investment along with the public investment that builds the community," she said. "And it's the festivals like the Waterfowl Festival — the granddaddy of them all — that weaves that fabric of the quality of life that we all love so much."
The festival may have just celebrated its 53rd anniversary, but it continues to grow and evolve.
Throughout the festival venues music filled the air and complemented the many duck and geese calls typical of the festival. Overall there were 38 musical acts on multiple stages.
"That made the festival have a different vibe this year, I think," Kilmon said, "just made it more of a friendly family party on every corner."
Feedback has been "incredibly positive," and Kilmon is excited to begin work on continuing Easton's Waterfowl tradition.
"Fifty-three years of our community coming together just gets better every year," Kilmon said. "And we're already working on next year, believe it or not."
It is good that Kilmon and her team are already working on the 2025 show. This year's show will be tough to top. We have no doubt they will rise to the challenge.
