title: Talbot County considering new cannabis legislation
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot County considering new cannabis legislation

 July 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 523
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County is reviewing regulations on cannabis operations, but drafted legislation drew concerns from prospective business owners at a recent meeting.As drafted, legislation would bar cannabis growing and processing operations from locating within 500 feet of residential properties. That mark could be reduced for a specific project only if all property owners within that radius agree.
At a County Council meeting on July 8, a public hearing on the legislation was opened, during which two state license holders raised concerns. Discussion centered on changing the 500-foot setback to 200 feet.
Dave Ferraris, winner of a cannabis-processing license from the Maryland Cannabis Administration, which are awarded via a lottery, said the proposed restrictions would be "detrimental."
"It's not the wild west," Ferraris said of cannabis operations. "It's agriculture with oversight."
Easton resident Lori Yates received a license for cultivation. She said on July 8 that passage of the county legislation would hinder her progress toward acquiring a property in Cordova, the now-closed Triple Creek Winery.
"It really would pull the rug out from us trying to work with the current owners," Yates said.
On the prospect of a 200-foot setback, Yates said she feels it would still allow for proper space "to have it off of the public access road."
Brennan Tarleton, the county's planning and zoning director, noted that in the original draft legislation, there's already a written-in opportunity to reduce the setback to 200 feet if the affected property owners agree. But he said moving the starting point down from 500 feet is a possibility.
"Two hundred feet isn't a pie-in-the-sky idea for a setback," Tarleton said.
If passed, the legislation would require processors and growers to obtain site plan approval from the county and operate on a lot of at least 20 acres. Additionally, operators must procure professional testimony that cannabis odor is not "detectible from adjacent properties or public rights-of-way."
Ferraris voiced opposition to the "no odors" regulation, citing it is too extreme of a rule.
"Talbot County will realistically and effectively be disqualified from participating in cannabis processing and growing endeavors," Ferraris said.
He added that prospective cannabis operators aren't looking to exploit the county. "We're not asking for a blank check. We're just asking for a fair chance," he said.
Tarleton noted the county mostly mirrored Easton's cannabis ordinance in regard to the odor requirement. He said Easton restricted to just indoor growing operations, though. Tarleton said council could consider exempting open-air growing operations from the "no odors" rule.
Talbot's draft cannabis legislation also lays out standards for cannabis dispensaries to follow, largely falling in line with the state's recent legislation effective in July, 2024.
Dispensaries cannot be located within 500 feet of schools, child care centers, playgrounds, recreation centers, libraries, public parks or places of worship. They also can't locate within 1,000 feet of one another; that standard is present in Easton town limits, too, and in one case created competition between businesses.
While Talbot County's potential regulations stick with the state, local jurisdictions are permitted under state law to change those distance requirements.
The county's cannabis legislation wasn't eligible for a vote on July 8. It may return to the council at its July 22 meeting or later in August. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: New exhibition at AAM features artist Darlene R. Taylor
author: Staff Writer
content:
New exhibition at AAM features artist Darlene R. Taylor

 April 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment 
 
 613
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A new art exhibition from multidisciplinary artist Darlene R. Taylor has debuted at the Academy Art Museum in Easton.The HEIRLOOMS exhibition runs through July 14.
Taylor is an artist who is based in Washington D.C. and the Eastern Shore.
"In HEIRLOOMS, Darlene R. Taylor (b. 1960) affirms the resonance of memory in material culture as she imagines portraits of Black women obscured in historical archives. History is a muse that guides Taylor to know the past from the women who lived it. HEIRLOOMS examines the presence of Black women in Maryland's Talbot County communities and Taylor's own ancestry and follows the artist's experience researching and interpreting photographs found in archives and family albums. Taylor employs mixed-media collage using vintage linens, laces, cottons, and buttons collected and handed down from mother to daughter, friend to friend," according to an announcement from the museum.
"I've been using antique textiles for some time, many of which I found in antique stores locally in Maryland. But the works in HEIRLOOMS have an even more resonant history. I had been thinking about the way the handkerchief holds so many emotions and experiences—sweat and tears, joy and sadness. When I shared that thought with my friend circle, they responded by giving me handkerchiefs and linens passed down through their own families. In this way, my work is becoming its own archive of Black women's lives. The cloth holds memory, and when it is given to me, I am connected to an ancestor through that exchange," Taylor said.
According to AAM:
"Her use of women's personal effects also draws inspiration in part from artifacts unearthed during two excavations commissioned by the Museum at the former home of Henny and James Freeman, one of the earliest- documented free Black landowning families who lived on the Hill Community site from 1787-1828. This site was gifted to AAM in 2023, and the Museum has plans to rehabilitate the existing structure on the site and connect it to new construction of an annex that will provide needed administrative space, as well as commemorate the historical significance of Easton's Hill Community. Part of the annex will be named The Henny and James Freeman Wing and showcase the objects unearthed from the excavations in outdoor displays that tell the story of the family and neighborhood. Of the more than 6,000 historical artifacts unearthed, the most remarkable finds were personal items including buttons, jewelry, children's toys, a woman's shoe buckle, and a hair comb. These unique objects offer a rare connection to Black domestic life in the eighteenth century— particularly the lives of Black women and children, whose stories were frequently lost to history."
"In trying to imagine these lives, I am always asking what is behind each woman's gaze. Much of my work is based on photographs of women I find in historic archives. Even though we can see their faces, we often know more about the objects pictured in the room than we do about the women. So I try to stand with each woman, to look at what she is looking at. I'm not staring at her; I'm seeing the world as she sees it and observing those elements that make up her world," said Taylor.
A handmade paperback book HEIRLOOMS is available for purchase in AAM's Museum Shop as well as a limited-edition fine art print of the image The Storyteller with an excerpt of the poem Porch Telling written by Darlene R. Taylor.
"Taylor's HEIRLOOMS stitches together the forgotten stories of Black women, weaving memory and material into a vibrant tapestry of resilience and remembrance. We are thrilled to showcase Taylor's beautiful works on paper and to amplify voices that have historically been silenced," said. interim director Jennifer Chrzanowski. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: He was better off without his aces - Bridge
author: Phillip Alder
content:
He was better off without his aces - Bridge

 October 19, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Phillip Alder | Page: A15 | Section: News 
 
 291
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Sometimes, you must wonder how long ago some of my deals were played. Occasionally, the bidding will tell you -- as here. North's double of three clubs was for penalty, not takeout, as it would be today.This old deal features a truly incredible defense -- one of the most imaginative ever. The deal was reported by Frenchman Jacques Blaizot, who was sitting West. He was in the Palace of Da Lat, partnering Bao Dai, then the Emperor of French Indochina. (Later, the palace was in South Vietnam.)Defending against three no-trump, West led the club ace. How do you think the defense went?West opened with a cautious three clubs. North doubled for penalties, but South, with his distributional hand, wisely didn't pass. (Three clubs was unbeatable.) Then, when North bid three hearts, South thought he was facing a heart-club two-suiter. So, rather than look for a nonexistent spade fit, he settled for three no-trump.This is how Blaizot reported the play: "I led the club ace and under the eyes of the panic-stricken spectators, Bao Dai discarded the diamond ace! I continued with the club queen and he discarded the spade ace! Immediately, silence filled the room. Discreetly, the spectators, struck with fright, got up and whispered into each other's ears. Then, little by little, a disquieting rumor spread through the palace: 'The emperor has gone mad. He threw away all of his aces.' But no! Bao Dai wasn't playing to lose."If the emperor had kept either of his aces, South could have established that suit without letting West on play. Now, though, West had to win a spade or diamond trick and could cash enough club winners to defeat the contract.©2023, UNITED FEATURE SYNDICATE DISTRIBUTED BY ANDREWS MCMEEL SYNDICATION FOR UFS

title: Espinal, Easton pastor arrested by ICE, returns home
author: Konner Metz
content:
Espinal, Easton pastor arrested by ICE, returns home

 August 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 269
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Daniel Fuentes Espinal returned home Friday after nearly a month of being detained by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement.Espinal's daughter, Clarissa Fuentes Diaz, flew to Louisiana last week to bring Espinal home, according to a Facebook post by family friend Len Foxwell on Friday.
"It was an emotional time for me — to see him after almost a month of not seeing him," Diaz told The Baltimore Banner.
Espinal, pastor of Iglesia del Nazareno Jesús Te Ama since 2015, was arrested the morning of July 21. He was on his way to his construction job, his family said. He was taken to ICE's field office in Salisbury and then transferred to Baltimore, where he spent three nights in Baltimore before being transferred to a detention center in Louisiana.
Espinal was granted bond on Tuesday, family told The Baltimore Banner.
His arrest received regional and national attention. In Easton, it stopped services at his congregation and sparked weekly protests against ICE.
Earlier this month, Easton Town Council members called for Espinal to be returned to his family.
Espinal has been in the country since 2001 and has no criminal record, his family has said. Following his arrest, ICE stated that Espinal was arrested for overstaying his six-month visa.
"Daniel Omar Fuentes Espinal is an illegal alien from Honduras who was arrested by ICE on July 21, in Easton, Maryland," the statement said. "Fuentes entered the United States on a 6-month visa and never left in 24 years. It is a federal crime to overstay the authorized period of time granted under a visitors visa."
This story may be updated.
Reporter Lily Tierney contributed to this story.

title: Clear, indisputable facts on Malkus
author: Staff Writer
content:
Clear, indisputable facts on Malkus

 May 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 379
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The senator's daughter, Betsy Malkus has come to her father's defense in her recent opinion article, but she has again overlooked the following facts – the real reasons for changing the name of the Choptank River bridge.Sen. Malkus led the Maryland opposition to defeat Maryland's 1962 Civil Rights bill, as proposed in the federal Civil Rights bill created to outlaw racial discrimination. This was the primary legislation outlining today's law of the land. When Malkus and a few other segregationists failed, he led the group to try to exempt individual counties from state legislation. Again, that failed, but in return, Malkus then tried to exempt bars from the accommodations portion of the bill.All of his various efforts to dilute the national and state civil rights bills failed, and the landmark national bill passed with the Maryland legislature complying.He publicly decried civil rights legislation of any kind as being "un-American."He proposed a bill to provide criminal penalties for anyone claiming discrimination.He proposed a bill that would make it a crime to make false statements about a community — another unconstitutional act. He continually blamed the media and "outsiders" for all of Cambridge's troubles, without helping to correct its real economic and racial problems.He voted against the repeal of a state law forbidding interracial marriage.On national TV, he said Martin Luther King was a "communist troublemaker" and Gloria Richardson was a "media-hungry agitator."He publicly supported Gov. George Wallace's bid for president in 1964.At a Goucher College televised conference with Gov. Wallace, he said, "Cambridge's Nonviolent Action Committee employed the same tactics as Hitler."He sent a letter to President John Kennedy complaining that his attack by three black boys in Baltimore was not given as much news coverage as the shooting of Medgar Evers. This is the only letter on record to either President Kennedy or Attorney General Robert Kennedy addressing the issue of racial problems in Cambridge with an attempt to calm the issue – an odd letter for a state senator (of the same party), who never asked for federal assistance.
Correction: Gov. Hughes did not veto the building of the bridge – he vetoed naming the bridge after Sen. Malkus. The governor said: "It didn't seem right for the bridge to be named after the state's staunchest segregationist."
PATRICK HORNBERGER
Trappe

title: Galena passes budget while starting first time investment
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Galena passes budget while starting first time investment

 June 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 622
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GALENA — After a public hearing for the budget where no members of the public attended, Mayor John Carroll and the Galena Town Council on Monday night passed the ordinance to their fiscal year 2025 budget.The total allocations divided between fund categories: General, $553,250; Sewer, $342,246; and Water, $173,675 — for a combined total of $1,069,171 matched their total income for a balanced budget.
The town budget includes a tax revenue of $258,000, alongside $76,678 in receivables for utilities.
The property tax rate, Carroll said, remains set at .0222 per $100 of assessed value. There was no increase in taxes, no increase for additional fees, water or in trash and recycling.
Town Attorney Tom Yeager reminded the council they were passing the ordinance to pass the budget.
Ultimately, they approved of ordinance 2024-01FY-25 Budget.
Also during this budget session, the town embarked for the first time in investing. They decided to take some money out of their savings and place it in an interest bearing certificate of deposit account.
Financial and Administrative Clerk Marisa Pisapia, while bringing up various line items, got the attention of the council about this. Once they scoured places to invest they chose to secure their investment with PNC Bank for eight months at a 4.65% interest rate.
Council member Sarah Merrell made it official.
"I make a motion to authorize doing a CD out of our water savings account," she said.
The motion passed unanimously.
Carroll detailed the next step in the process. Right before they leave for the Maryland Municipal League June 23 — 26 in Ocean City, they'll meet with someone from PNC Bank. From there they'll set up an account to get things in motion.
As a first, reiterated Carroll, "we're dipping our toes in it."
In other financial matters, Grants Coordinator and Tech Support Grant Audrey Erschen talked about the various grants she's been working on.
She received notification their Teen Play Area was included in the State of Maryland's FY2025 Budget, and must be approved by the Maryland Board of Public Works. The grant was for climbing equipment and installation.
They were not awarded this year on their No Gym, Think Outside Application, but she'll try again next year.
And in the tech department, she was informed they would not have to replace their Quick Books until 2026 — a relief for the council.
Maintenance and Facilities Coordinator Warren Walters had updates of his own particularly concerning the wastewater treatment plant. They had removed 42.55 tons of sludge in 2024, with a total cost of $2,957.24. Total effluent gallons (liquid waste or sewage discharged) discharged were 3,873,000 and daily average effluent gallons were 25,463.
Carroll who wanted to get a general idea, said, "It looks like we're averaging 25,000 gallons or so. That's what I wanted to see, where we're truly at. I want to know what our capacity is always. And when it fluctuates during a certain point of time."
Walters, working with Erschen, said his goal going ahead is in mitigation procedures, aiming to reduce the production of methane and leachate that can contaminate surface waters. This process involves managing wastewater at its source, which can include water conservation and recycling.
Walters is in conversations with the Environmental Protection Agency, so the town possibly won't have to spend money on the mitigation process. Carroll thought that a good idea, and mentioned that he's been talking with the University of Maryland Finance Center too. The idea is once they have their survey complete, they'll open up the conversation even more.
"We can attack it from both angles," Carroll said, "state and federal."
After hearing updates on all departments, Yeager commended the council on their work.
Carroll noted the completion of the budget was a team effort.
The Galena Town Council's next meeting will be on Monday, July 1. See more information at townofgalena.com.

title: Natural Resources Police use thermal imaging to rescue lost kayaker in Talbot County
author: Konner Metz
content:
Natural Resources Police use thermal imaging to rescue lost kayaker in Talbot County

 July 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 344
 Words 

 Read News Document

 BROAD CREEK — Police and firefighters teamed to locate a lost juvenile kayaker last weekend in Talbot County.On July 4 around 10 p.m., Maryland Natural Resources Police were informed of a lost kayaker in the Broad Creek area, which is on the west side of the county south of St. Michaels. Officials said he was on the water for "several hours" and around three miles from home.
Using thermal imaging cameras, a Natural Resource Police aviation unit quickly found the lost person — in around five minutes, according to Sgt. John Buchanan, chief pilot for NRP. Buchanan was in the aircraft with tactical flight officer Christian Helwig.
Buchanan said the kayaker left out of Grace Creek.
"I think it got dark on him, and he didn't know where he was," Buchanan said.
Once located, police used a spotlight to direct a rescue boat from the Tilghman Island Volunteer Fire Company toward the juvenile.
A video posted to Facebook by Natural Resource Police shows the aircraft hone in on the kayaker and direct the fire boat to retrieve the juvenile.
Buchanan said such a rescue isn't too common, but it become somewhat prominent during boating season.
"(The) Chesapeake Bay and the tributaries are very large," Buchanan said. "When you start thinking about the different rivers and creeks and stuff off the Chesapeake Bay, we go out on different search missions like that probably a few times a month."
The pilot emphasized Helwig's expertise is crucial to such rescues. Helwig handles the thermal imaging camera, which can expose subjects in dark conditions, as well as a mapping system to pull up addresses and latitudes and longitudes.
"He's gotten really good with it, he's worked really hard at it," Buchanan said. "He's made us as a team very successful going out and doing these search missions."
Buchanan advises those going out on the water, especially alone, to be prepared with a charged cell phone and other equipment in case of emergency.
"Have a life jacket if you're out at night," he said. "Obviously have some kind of flashlight. And know the area, that's probably the biggest thing." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: QAC hears 5-year capital project preview
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
QAC hears 5-year capital project preview

 December 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 675
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — With a number of large projects on the horizon, the Queen Anne's County finance department provided a head-start to the budget process with an overview to the County Commissioners Nov. 26.Jeff Rank, director of budget and finance, presented data from a Capital Budget Work Session including a preview of major capital projects currently in the planning stages for the upcoming five years.
Due to the fact that the county has more costly projects than usual, the finance department sought to present an early start to the review process, he said.
The total capital project expenditures programmed for the current year and planned for the next five years is about $285 million, according to Rank.
Going back 20 years, the average capital plan was about $31 million per year, which adjusted for inflation is about $35 million per year, he said.
"If we stick to this average which has been our current comfort zone this puts us at about $96 million above that threshold over the next five years, " Rank said.
Upcoming major projects include a new regional detention center in Church Hill at about $24.2 million, a potential Centerville Middle School replacement at $20.5 million, a $20 million recreation center, new sheriff facilities at $16 million, and historic courthouse renovations at $10 million, he said.
Proposed projects not yet programmed into the capital plan include Queen Anne's County Library expansion, new Board of Elections facility, and potential uses for the old Board of Education building.
Also presenting an overview of debt measures and debt management policy, Queen Anne's County has a cap of 10% for debt as a percentage of general fund expenditures, Rank said, noting over the next five to six years, the county is not expected to hit that cap.
Another county debt measure is debt as a percentage of real property assessable base, with a cap set at 2.5%. The county is only expected to hit a high of about 1.5% by the end of 2030, Rank said.
The other debt measure is per capital debt as related to per capita income. With a policy stating a maximum of 8%, the county is in compliance with 5% come 2030, he said.
Over the past two years Queen Anne's County hasn't had any debt, but there is potential in the next three years, Rank said.
Current debt measures are recommended by the Government finance Officers Association for counties nationwide, according to Rank, noting Maryland counties have burdens that most other counties in the country do not.
Maryland counties are required to provide funding for local boards of education, pay for County Road systems to a higher proportion than most other counties in the country and Maryland also has high levels of service for public safety efforts in the county, he said.
Excluding funding for the Board of Education, the county typically keeps annual cost increases very close to the annual inflation increases of three to four percent, Rank said.
For each year debt service increases at rates above inflation, cuts must be made to other county services including public safety, education, roads, and park maintenance, he said.
"It's when that happens we find it difficult to maintain our current levels of service with all the other things we have to pay for in the county," Rank said.
The Finance Department meets with the Board of Education quarterly to keep in better sync with their programming and projects, according to Rank.
Moving forward the finance department recommends a smoother flatter debt burden from year to year rather than wild increases, he said.
For the upcoming capital budget schedule, departments have begun preparing budgets for next year's capital plan due Jan. 10.
Early to mid March will see finance meetings with County Administrator Todd Mohn who will submit the proposed budget to the commissioners March 25.
Budget work sessions will be held at the end of March or early April and ideally the final budget will be adopted June 10.
Many projects are dependent on state shared revenues and grants that the county can leverage additional dollars for, which will also be part of the decision making process going forward, Mohn said.

title: Growing goodness — Sandy's Garden gives back to community
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Growing goodness — Sandy's Garden gives back to community

 April 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 584
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Sandy Zappia owner of Sandy's Garden donates her produce to the food pantries in Kent County, including the Maryland Food Bank.Fresh fruits and veggies are delivered to those in need, grown using no pesticides or herbicides with natural compost on 3.5 acres on Annie Crow Road. There, a small but dedicated operation of 20-25 volunteers build their organization aiming to make fresh and healthy food available each week.
On Saturday, a week before Easter, Zappia delivered a little bit of that joy to the farmers market on High Street, introducing the community to 25 of her baby chicks, the hardworking future egg providers for the community.
Although it was a little cold out, the chicks weren't, warmed by heaters. The chicks greeted children, teens and adults who held and petted them — a friendly Chestertown welcome. Believe it or not, some have never held a baby chick, Zappia said.
The recent arrivals, coming from Murray McMurray hatchery are a rainbow assortment which will offer a variety of different colored eggs.
Zappia loved introducing her little feathered friends while teaching lessons on rural life.
"Today was exactly what I was hoping for, just spreading joy to people. What a great way to spend a Saturday."
Zappia encouraged people to add to their volunteer number as they prepare for summer planting season.
For Zappia, gardening is a passion, first discovered through her late husband while raising their three children on a West Virginian farm. When she moved back to Maryland to stay close to her immediate family, she put farming on hold, and had a fulfilling career as a preschool teacher at Friendship Montessori School.
After her husband passed away, and her children were grown, going separate ways, that farming desire was restored. In Rock Hall, there were plans for a garden restaurant and for her to run the garden. Those plans fell through, and attempts for Zappia to purchase the garden did not take root.
However, another opportunity arose, and she purchased 3.5 acres of cornfield, which would become the future home of her own operation.
"The idea for Sandy's Garden came about when the restaurant garden where I was working had more produce than we could use- so we donated it to the local food pantry. What an eye-opener! I had no idea of the need for fresh fruit and vegetables in the county. I realized at that moment that I wanted to help meet that need."
Sandy's Garden was established, and today there is a garden, a chicken coop to house her newest, adorable arrivals, a beehive to pollinate those plants and a greenhouse so they can grow crops year-round.
Although they are not a 40-acre farm, they can grow a lot with what they have, Zappia exclaimed. With a goal to provide food to the pantry every week, with heart, hard work and dedication they have been doing just that.
For example, the date of the interview, April 18, they dropped off 38 pounds of spring crops, lettuce, spinach and kale. In May, they will add warmer weather crops, like tomatoes, green beans and peppers to the mix.
Zappia showed appreciation to all her volunteers, hoping for many others.
"I love to teach people but even if you want to just hang out with the chickens, you're welcome to do that too," Zappia said.
Sandy's Garden is a non-profit dedicated to nurturing our community by making sure everyone has access to wholesome food. Scope it out at at sandysgarden.org or 304-761-0286 or contact her at sandysgardeninc@gmail.com.
'We are a happy little self-sustaining area," Zappia said, laughing.

title: House GOP introduces bill to repeal Biden college plan
author: MATHEW SCHUMER Capital News Service
content:
House GOP introduces bill to repeal Biden college plan

 February 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MATHEW SCHUMER Capital News Service | Section: National 
 
 549
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — The House Committee on Education and the Workforce has advanced a Republican-sponsored bill that includes measures repealing key aspects of the Biden administration's plans to make college more affordable.The College Cost Reduction Act, introduced by the panel's chairwoman, Rep. Virginia Foxx (R-North Carolina), passed on a party-line 22-19 vote.
The measure presents numerous programs intended to strengthen the integrity of higher education institutions across the country, but also would gut much of President Joe Biden's efforts to help students afford college. Democrats on the committee offered a series of amendments to the bill aimed at blocking the GOP repeals, but all were defeated.
"Unfortunately, President Biden has decided time and time again that the executive branch should also hold the legislative pen," Foxx said, "Congress has the task of creating laws that reflect the interests of the people. It is not the role of the executive pen."
Last August, the Biden administration launched the Saving on a Valuable Education (SAVE) program, aiming to cancel debt to borrowers who originally owed $12,000 or less in loans and had repaid at least ten years of those loans.
The program is slated to begin in February, with 6.9 million Americans already enrolled, according to the White House.
Biden's original plan, as laid out in his 2022 executive order to cancel up to $430 billion in student loans, was blocked by the Supreme Court in a 6-3 decision last June. The court determined that the secretary of education lacked the power to issue debt relief on the scale described in the administration's plan.
Last September, Foxx introduced a resolution with Rep. Lisa McClain, R-Michigan, to nullify the SAVE plan, but the full House never voted on it.
Foxx's College Cost Reduction Act, introduced in January, would establish a streamlined data system to convey information about colleges, create a performance-based grant program, and hold academic institutions responsible for unpaid student loans.
In the committee meeting to consider the bill, Democrats introduced 30 amendments to alter some fundamental aspects of the legislation.
Rep. Bobby Scott (D-Virginia) praised parts of Foxx's bill, "such as codifying Postsecondary Student Success Grants and eliminating interest capitalization and origination fees on student loans," but the panel's ranking Democrat objected to some provisions that he said would make it harder for people to go to college.
Rep. Kathy Manning (D-Michigan) offered an amendment to strike language from the bill repealing Biden administration regulations to protect student borrowers during changes in ownership of academic institutions.
Another Biden administration regulation the Foxx bill aims to repeal is the 90-10 rule, which requires for-profit universities to secure at least 10 percent of their funding from non-federal sources. Rep. Mark Takano (D-California) introduced an amendment to strike this section from the final bill but was rebuffed by the GOP majority.
Rep. Ilhan Omar (D-Minnesota) offered a motion to remove the bill's rescission of Biden's SAVE plan, but that motion was defeated.
"The new (SAVE) program created by the Biden administration… creates a generous IDR (income-driven repayment) plan that Republicans now want to strip away," Omar said.
Rep. Suzanne Bonamici (D-Michigan) unsuccessfully tried to amend the bill with language streamlining the process of finding on-campus accommodations for students with disabilities.
Bonamici's proposal is part of a group of bills unveiled Monday by Democratic members of the education panel referred to collectively as the Roadmap to College Student Success.

title: YMCA welcomes community to health expo
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
YMCA welcomes community to health expo

 October 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 370
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — On Oct. 17, health agencies, partners, businesses, nonprofits and community organizations attended the Kent County Family YMCA for the annual Health and Wellness Expo.Pickleball players and basketball hoopers were momentarily replaced with health vendors. Tables were set up in the gymnasium, where attendees could get information for health wellness; anything from house gutter protection to cochlear ear implant options.
"This expo is dedicated to fostering partnerships among local organizations that provide valuable services and education on essential health and wellness topics," said Gale Drenning president of HomePorts, a partner of the event.
This year, Acme Pharmacy provided flu and COVID vaccines.
At the next table over, the new Health Educator at the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Chestertown, Sandy Wilson-Hypes demonstrated CPR practices on a mannequin, inviting guests to try it out.
Teenager, Nate Perogoy was up for the challenge, exercising chest compressions to the tune "Staying Alive," a perfect tempo at 100/120 compressions per minute.
In addition to the vendors, classes were provided.
In "Unlock the Secrets of Ancient Nutrition," Bill Schindler author, internationally-known chef and founder of Eastern Shore Food Lab, instructed how to get the most nutrients from food and sustain your health amid a worldview of unhealthy practices.
Lt. Sean Maloney of the Kent County Sheriff's Office gave his presentation: "Don't Be A Victim! The Latest Scams, Schemes, and Frauds." He said threats come from everywhere: computer hackers, romance scams, fake scanners at ATMs and stores, dumpster diving and mail.
He pointed out victims can be anybody, but especially retirees with disposable income.
Gloria Carter offered a dance-based cardio class, available Mondays and Wednesdays at the YMCA.
Throughout the afternoon, while people went from table to table, they were treated to the musical talents of River Voices from Chester River Chorale directed by Stephanie LaMotte.
Outside, under a blue sky and moderate weather, food was provided by Happy Chicken and Lockbriar Farms. Patrons enjoyed squash soup, pumpkin ice cream and fresh-pressed apple cider.
The expo was well-attended, with over 300 programs handed out, said a volunteer.
Throughout the years the expo had many homes, but for the past three years the YMCA has been proud to host it.
Executive Director of the YMCA Erica Osterhout and her staff expressed excitement welcoming the expo each year.

title: Country Cooking: Memories and recipes from grandparents
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Country Cooking: Memories and recipes from grandparents

 September 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1276
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Grandparents Day is Sept. 7 this year. In 1978, the late Jimmy Carter, who was the president, designated the first Sunday after Labor Day each year to honor grandparents.What a wonderful day to honor those important people in our lives. My grandparents died many years ago, but the memories live on. Generations have changed; grandparents are younger (it seems), lifestyles are somewhat different, but we still have Mom-Mom and Pop-Pop.
My mother and I would sit and talk about days I spent with my paternal grandparents. They too had a large farm, and my older siblings and I would help with farm work.
I recall thinking that the grandparents' farm duties were out-of-date compared to the "modern" equipment my dad used. Then my older brother's fourth generation farm down on the river was ultra-modern.
My grandparents were an important part of my life. My maternal grandmother died at age 18 when my mom was 2 years old, so I never had the pleasure of knowing this person who gave me the best mother ever. My paternal grandparents were dear to me as they were all I had.
I have lots of stories to share with you all in the coming months. Stories of mischief and fun growing up with large families on large farms.
Food seemed to be a very popular activity for grandparents when the grandchildren came. I have many great memories of special dishes such as fresh made biscuits, pies, dumplings, soups, stews, beans and fried chicken.
Cooking is a tradition that still happens today with my own grandsons.
A few times a month, one of my grandchildren has spent the day with me. A few years ago, when we ran out of things to do, we started baking. This has been so much fun.
Not only have we developed math skills, reading skills, and the ability to follow directions, but we have also developed an awesome relationship between generations.
Our first bread to be made was banana bread.
BANANA BREAD
1/2 cup shortening, 2 eggs, 1 cup sugar, 2 cups flour, 1 tbsp sour milk, 1 tsp baking soda, 2 ripe crushed bananas, 1/2 cup crushed nuts (optional).
Cream shortening with eggs and sugar. Add flour, sour milk, baking soda, crushed bananas and nuts. Mix well and bake in a preheated 350-degree oven for one hour. For best results, use a medium size baking pan.
PUMPKIN BREAD
2 2/3 cups sugar, 2/3 cup shortening, 4 beaten eggs, 2/3 cup water, 1 can pumpkin puree (1 lb), 3 1/3 cups flour, 1/2 tsp baking powder, 2 tsps baking soda, 1 1/2 tsp salt, 1 tsp cinnamon, 1/2 tsp ground cloves, 2/3 cup chopped walnuts, 2/3 cup chopped dates.
Cream together sugar and shortening. Stir in eggs, water and pumpkin. Sift together flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, cinnamon and cloves. Mix well with the wet ingredients. Add walnuts and dates. Pour into two greased 9-by-5-inch pans. Bake at 350 degrees for one hour and 15 minutes.
GRANDMA'S ROSEMARY DINNER ROLLS
1 package (1/4 ounce) active dry yeast, 1/4 cup warm water (110° to 115°), 3 cups bread flour, 2 tbsps sugar, 1 tbsp minced fresh rosemary, 3/4 tsp salt, 2/3 cup warm 2% milk (110° to 115°), 1 large egg (room temperature), 1/4 to 1/3 cup canola oil, 1 large egg yolk, 2 tbsps 2% milk.
In a small bowl, dissolve yeast in warm water. Place the flour, sugar, rosemary and salt in a food processor: pulse until blended. Add the warm milk, egg and yeast mixture; cover and pulse 10 times or until almost blended. While processing, gradually add oil just until dough pulls away from sides and begins to form a ball. Process 2 minutes longer to knead dough (dough will be very soft). Transfer dough to a greased bowl, turning once to grease the top. Cover and let rise in a warm place until doubled, about 1 hour. Punch down dough. Turn onto a lightly floured surface; divide and shape into 12 balls. Roll each into a 15-inch rope. Starting at one end, loosely wrap dough around itself to form a coil. Tuck end under; pinch to seal. Place 2 inches apart on greased baking sheets. Cover and let rise until doubled, about 30 minutes. For egg wash, in a small bowl, whisk egg yolk and milk; brush over rolls. Sprinkle it with remaining rosemary. Bake at 350 degrees until golden brown, 18-22 minutes. Remove from pans to wire racks; serve warm.
EASTERN SHORE SWEET POTATO BISCUITS
2 cups mashed sweet potatoes, 3/4 cup sugar, 2 1/4 cups flour, 1 1/4 tsp salt, 2 tsps baking powder, 5 tbsps shortening.
Mix sweet potatoes with sugar, flour, salt and baking powder. Add 5 tablespoons shortening last and mix dough. Roll dough and cut with biscuit cutter or roll into small balls 3/4 inch thick. Bake at 450 degrees for 20 to 25 minutes.
FRIED CHICKEN
1 frying chicken, salt, 1 1/2 cups flour, pepper, paprika, 1 1/2 cups shortening.
Wash chicken in cold water and cut into pieces. Soak in cold water for a few minutes with 1 tsp of salt. Drain chicken. Season flour with salt, pepper and paprika to taste. Heat shortening in a fry pan. Dredge the chicken in the flour mixture and place in the oil. Cook until golden brown on both sides, about 20 minutes on each side. Drain on paper towels. I usually mix my flour mixture in a brown paper bag and shake to coat. I also save the flour mixture to make a gravy in the grease when chicken is cooked.
GRANDMOTHER'S SOUTHERN COLLARD GREENS
2 tbsps lard or shortening (divided), 1 large onion (chopped), 6 garlic cloves (minced), 1 1/2 pounds smoked ham hocks, 6 cups water, wine, 2 tsps seasoned salt, 1 to 3 tsps crushed red pepper flakes, 1/4 tsp sugar, 1 large bunch collard greens (coarsely chopped).
In a six-quart stockpot, heat 1 tbsp lard over medium heat. Add onion and garlic; cook and stir until tender. Add ham hocks, water, seasoned salt, pepper flakes and sugar. Bring to a boil. Reduce heat; simmer, uncovered, until meat is tender, 55 to 60 minutes. Add collard greens, wine, and remaining 1 tbsp lard. Return to a boil. Reduce heat; simmer, uncovered, until greens are very tender, 55 to 60 minutes. Remove meat from bones; finely chop and return to pan. Discard bones. Serve with a slotted spoon.
GRANDMOTHERS CORN PUDDING
4 large eggs, 1 cup whole milk, 1 can (15 ounces) cream-style corn, 1/2 cup sugar, 5 slices day-old bread (crusts removed), 1 tbsp softened butter. In a bowl, beat eggs and milk. Add corn and sugar; mix well. Cut bread into half-inch cubes and place in a greased 9-inch square baking dish. Pour egg mixture over bread. Dot with butter. Bake, uncovered, at 350 degrees until a knife inserted in the center comes out clean, 50 to 60 minutes.
GRANDMOTHER'S TANDY CAKE
4 large eggs (room temperature), 2 cups sugar, 1 cup 2% milk, 1 tsp vanilla extract, 2 cups all-purpose flour, 1 tsp baking powder, 1/4 tsp salt, 1 3/4 cups creamy peanut butter, 5 milk or dark chocolate candy bars (1.55 ounces each) chopped, 2 tbsps butter.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. In a large bowl, beat eggs and sugar until thick and lemon colored. Beat in milk and vanilla. In another bowl, combine flour, baking powder and salt; gradually add to egg mixture and mix well. Spread into a greased 15-by-10-inch baking pan. Bake for 20 to 25 minutes or until lightly browned. Cool for 15 minutes on a wire rack. Spread peanut butter over top; cool completely. In a double boiler or metal bowl over simmering water, melt chocolate and butter; stir until smooth. Gently spread over peanut butter. Refrigerate for 30 minutes or until firm.

title: Maryland legislators kick off 447th General Assembly
author: Konner Metz
content:
Maryland legislators kick off 447th General Assembly

 January 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 670
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — With snow piled up around the Statehouse, Maryland lawmakers returned to downtown Annapolis for the 447th General Assembly on Wednesday.More than 560 bills were prefiled in either the House of Delegates or Senate prior to the opening session. While both chambers began introducing bills Wednesday, the focus largely remained on the state's looming budget deficit that will be tackled in the coming weeks.
The state is predicted to face a $2.7 billion budget deficit in fiscal year 2026. Gov. Wes Moore (D), who some Republicans have criticized for his fiscal decisions, must submit his balanced budget proposal by next Wednesday.
Leadership in the House and Senate acknowledged the deficit will be center stage but spoke optimistically about what's ahead.
House Speaker Adrienne Jones, a Democrat from Baltimore County, said the House, which reviews the budget first, will "use it to reflect our values."
"As we begin this session, I know there has been a lot of talk about our financial limitations. And there should be," Jones said. "We can't deny our difficult fiscal reality. But instead of talking about what our budget can't do, I'd like to talk about what it can do. Most importantly, our budget has the power to protect the most vulnerable Marylanders."
Jones noted health care and transportation as areas that will continue to be prioritized, as well as the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's expansive education initiative.
"We don't want to talk about cuts and prioritizing programs, but we have to," Jones said. "We don't want to talk about high-energy costs, but we have to. And we have to talk about protecting the investment we made for our students and teachers in The Blueprint."
Senate President Bill Ferguson, a Baltimore Democrat beginning his sixth year in the role, said the General Assembly's efforts to fund and facilitate reconstruction of the Francis Scott Key Bridge last year showed the aptitude of Maryland's lawmakers.
"This institution showed exactly who it is," Ferguson said. "Within days, we had put together legislation working with our House counterparts, with the governor, setting up the PORT Act in a bipartisan way to find ways to put resources immediately to use, to set the state up for success in the midst of crisis."
Ferguson said the budget deficit is the General Assembly's next significant challenge.
"I've been thinking about it a little bit differently recently, in that yes it is a challenge, but really, it's an opportunity for us in this body," Ferguson said. " … What do we want our future to look like? How do we take this challenge and have the hard conversations about what do we prioritize to invest in people and to build communities in a way that everyone has the opportunity to thrive."
The Senate president offered positivity through the fact that the state came in under budget and ahead of schedule on a significant project just outside of the Statehouse — the Maryland Department of Legislative Services building. A ribbon-cutting ceremony will be held tomorrow, he said.
"What emerged was everything that the state of Maryland should look like," Ferguson said of the new building that he called "beautiful."
Leadership in both chambers remained the same Wednesday. Ferguson and Senate President Pro Tem Malcolm Augustine, a Democrat from Prince George's County, were unanimously nominated to their positions.
In the House, Speaker Pro Tem Dana Stein, a Baltimore County Democrat, was nominated and approved for a second consecutive year. Jones begins her sixth full term as speaker.
On Wednesday, the House Speaker reflected on the fact that her first job in public service was made possible by the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act, legislation the late President Jimmy Carter extended during his time in office.
"I know that we all love public service," Jones said. "And when I think about public service, I think about the late President Jimmy Carter. As it turns out, I owe a lot to President Carter."
Jones said those are the ways in which "government can do powerful things for regular people."
"Progress isn't linear, it's incremental," Jones said. "It takes time. It takes resilience."

 EASTON — On Tuesday evening, Talbot County Council members gathered to elect council officer positions for the next year.Each council member received a ballot to mark their vote for council president and vice president. title: Where has grace gone in winning?
author: Staff Writer
content:
Where has grace gone in winning?

 October 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 207
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I understand competition — athletic, business and political. I've engaged in them all, and I value each for the lessons they teach. Losing, when it happens, can even make you stronger.In debate or sport, you must prepare. You must know your opponent's strengths and weaknesses, and you must have a strategy. And win or lose, you are judged not only by the outcome but by how you carry yourself. I learned long ago: You lose with honor, but you win with grace.
So I ask — where has grace gone? Where has decorum gone? Today it seems acceptable to shout down opponents, to sneer and label, to point fingers instead of making points. These are tactics we would scold in children, yet they are now common currency in our politics.
I always valued the end of a contest, when you could shake hands, smile and respect the person across from you — even if you didn't like them. The best opponent was never the one I agreed with, but the one I could respect.
The true test of character, in debate or in life, is simple: Would I welcome this person as my next-door neighbor? Increasingly, I fear too many of today's loudest voices would fail that test.
DAN McKEW
Easton

title: Caroline superintendent projects 'good budget year,' discusses Blueprint
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Caroline superintendent projects 'good budget year,' discusses Blueprint

 December 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 617
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — At last week's Caroline County Board of Education meeting, Superintendent Derek Simmons provided board members with a preview into the district's fiscal year 2026 outlook as budget season nears.Simmons said he and his team are in the process of developing a draft budget. What happens in this year's state legislative session is expected to impact how the budget looks, the superintendent said.
"We are really contingent upon what happens at the state level for our funding, and we do expect the General Assembly to be very engaged in things that could impact us budget-wise," Simmons said. "So it is 100% likely we will not have a clear picture of our budget, of our revenue numbers until mid-April at best."
At the Dec. 3 meeting, Simmons reviewed the fiscal year 2025 budget, noting that around 60% of unrestricted funds were spent on salaries and wages. Those funds largely come from the state, as the district received around 66% of its FY25 revenue from the state in unrestricted money.
"When we talk about where our expenses come from, it's people," Simmons said. "No surprise as we've said for years, we are a people business. It takes people to educate children. It takes people to make school work."
Contracted services accounted for just under 7% of the unrestricted budget. Board Member Troy Plutschak said he wants the board to find out how much auditing through outside companies costs.
Simmons said the district is often audited, but that moving audits in-house would be difficult and put the district in a "world of hurt." Potentially, one or two finance-related positions would be added, along with adding a stress onto the workload of school principals, Simmons said.
According to the superintendent, he doesn't expect federal money or county allocations to drastically change heading into fiscal year '26. "We knew '25 was the tight year," he said.
Assuming no major changes are made to the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's initiative to increase education funding, Simmons has an optimistic outlook. That's partly due to increased multilingual learner, special education and overall enrollment in the county.
"We are anticipating what should be a good budget year for Caroline County Public Schools," Simmons told the board.
BLUEPRINTWhile there was positivity in the fiscal year 26 forecast, Simmons made clear to board members that the outlook could drastically change if state legislators enact major adjustments to funding in Blueprint.
Changes to fiscal 26 funding "can have absolute detrimental impacts to Caroline County Public Schools," he said, since Caroline County Public Schools is "not a district that has extra wealth to go to to fill gaps."
"Not trying to paint a dire picture, but I don't want to paint roses where they may not exist," he said. "They should. But I want to make sure that everybody in the public is very clear as well. It should be, but if they go changing things in the FY 26 formula, it will hurt in this county more so than others probably."
State legislators may be tasked with discussions about Blueprint funding this winter, as the state faces a predicted budget deficit of $2.7 million for fiscal year 2026.
Blueprint will require all schools to meet a minimum teacher salary of $26,000 by July 2026. Caroline County Public Schools has not met that mark yet, but Simmons said the district is making progress.
"We are still working to get our starting teacher salary up to the mandated $60,000 by FY27," Simmons said. "We have done a great job through negotiations. We're roughly $5,000 away."
Looking to the next budget cycle, salaries and maintaining adequate staffing levels are at the top of mind for the superintendent and his team.
"We need to stay competitive with salaries and benefits for all employees," Simmons said.

title: Celebrating the Fourth
author: JIM JOHNSON jjohnson@chespub.com
content:
Celebrating the Fourth

 July 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: JIM JOHNSON jjohnson@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 257
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Three hundred-plus people crowded the streets of St. Michaels on the Fourth of July painting the town red, white and blue.The annual Children's Parade stepped off at 10 a.m. led by Police Chief Jeffrey Oswald, an antique fire engine and the color guard from Scout Troop 741 carrying the flag.
The highlight of the parade was the children — most sporting red, white and blue attire — who marched the parade route that started and ended at the St. Michaels Historical Museum and looped through downtown where the streets were lined with cheering paradegoers. The parade took just over 20 minutes, which seemed like a long time for many of the children as temperatures reached the mid-80s.
Brian Collison and his 14-year-old daughter, Constance, stood on a downtown corner, Brian playing patriotic songs on his trumpet with Constance accompanying him on the drums. The Collisons came from Denver, Colorado, to visit relatives in St. Michaels over the holiday weekend.
Four friends from Crofton came to St. Michaels, the third time they marched in the parade. The four — Megan Elias, Ellie Cockrell, Taylor Sundick and Ella Davis — painted their faces red, white and blue.
"We love being patriotic," Sundick said.
Following the parade a traditional Fourth of July program was held on the museum lawn starting with the Scout troop raising the flag and reciting the Pledge of Allegiance. The program included patriotic and folk songs.
The Fourth of July weekend in St. Michaels concluded Saturday with Big Band Night at the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum followed by fireworks at dusk.

title: Talbot Board of Ed sees initial budget proposal
author: Konner Metz
content:
Talbot Board of Ed sees initial budget proposal

 January 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 720
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Talbot Board of Education had its first look at the district's proposed budget for fiscal year 2026 Monday.During a board work session Chief Financial Officer Sarah Jones presented the draft budget, which totals $85.8 million in unrestricted dollars — an $8.6 million increase from fiscal year 2025, Jones noted.
Jones provided the year-to-year budget changes by looking at 12 different categories of expenditures. The areas in which increases were highest are fixed charges ($2.23 million increase), instructional salaries ($1.7 million increase) and other instructional costs ($1.47 million increase).
Jones added that while $9 million to $10 million in grants are expected next year, anticipated grant funding is more than $5 million less than last fiscal year. That drop in grant funding precipitated a portion of the rise in the requested unrestricted budget.
In Annapolis, it still remains to be seen how Maryland's expected $2.7 billion deficit is tackled and if legislative decisions will impact funding for The Blueprint for Maryland's Future, the state's education improvement and funding initiative.
Talbot school leaders say budgeting will be a fluid process in the coming months as they keep an eye on state legislation and the Accountability & Implementation Board, an entity that ensures the state and county governments are correctly implementing Blueprint.
"There's one area where I did do a little bit of hedging our bets, on the conservative side," Jones said of the proposed budget. "I don't think we'll know any of that until April or May. But as certain pieces of legislation gather steam and seem to gather support and seem likely, then I think we will work behind the scenes to figure out how we will address this if this comes to fruition."
In creating the draft budget, Jones and Superintendent Sharon Pepukayi emphasized that the district considered its top priorities: academic equity in math, an engaging environment for students and staff, recruitment and retention levels, and meeting Blueprint objectives.
Monday's discussion included a breakdown of 33 proposed additional positions for the next fiscal year. The proposed budget includes a $3.6 million jump in salaries and wages.
"This list is whittled down, if you can believe it, from a longer list of wants and desires," Jones said. "And it was very much informed by school administration. This is what they felt they needed in their buildings."
ADDITIONAL POSITIONSJones outlined the 33 additional positions that are in the requested budget. Six of those positions are for English for Speakers of Other Languages teachers, assistants or coaches.
She cited the district's need to serve its multilingual population, along with the state funding for multilingual learning, for adding the positions.
"Our (Maryland Comprehensive Assessment Program) data … demonstrates that we do consistently underserve our multilingual students," Jones said. "And so, we just need to provide more resources there."
Board of Education President Emily Jackson asked if those English for Speakers of Other Languages positions will be difficult to fill.
"Because I know we've had problems — specifically with ESOL in the past — finding people who are qualified and had a desire to do that," Jackson said. "And that's a quarter of the positions we're looking for."
Zulieka Jarmon-Horsey, assistant superintendent of administrative services, systems and strategies, said it's a challenge both in Talbot County and statewide. She said recruitment and retention are key aspects.
"We have to definitely start promoting earlier and just doing the best that we can," Jarmon-Horsey said. "And doing things that are unconventional, like our on-site career fair that's going to be happening here this week."
Other requested positions in the budget include: an art teacher at Easton Middle, a high school math coach, a middle school reading coach, four special education positions at Easton Elementary and a special education teacher at Easton Middle.
One athletic trainer to serve Easton High School and St. Michaels Middle High School was also on the proposed list.
"I'm happy to see that at the top of the list," Jackson said of the athletic trainer role. "I would be in favor of two … making sure that we have coverage for all of our athletic events. I know sports parents, they have eyes on that."
The draft budget will be discussed again at Wednesday's monthly Board of Education meeting before the board hosts its joint meeting with the Talbot County Council on Jan. 22. On Feb. 10, the board will host a public hearing on the budget.

title: Man surrenders to police after hours long standoff in Chestertown
author: STAFF REPORTS
content:
Man surrenders to police after hours long standoff in Chestertown

 March 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORTS | Section: Crime 
 
 309
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — A day-long law enforcement operation on Flatland Road ended peacefully Friday when a man experiencing a mental health crisis surrendered after firing multiple gunshots and prompting widespread community response.The incident began around 5:45 a.m. March 28, when Chestertown Police Department and Kent County Sheriff's Office responded to shots fired in the 100 block of Flatland Road. Witnesses, including neighbor Todd Hughes, reported hearing gunshots around 5 a.m., followed by someone knocking on a nearby door.
Police vehicles were first spotted in the area around 5:30 a.m., with tactical response escalating throughout the morning. At approximately 8:30 a.m., a SWAT-type vehicle with a large ram approached the house, officers repeatedly calling for the individual to come out, saying they wanted to "check on him" and were "not there to hurt him."
The extensive operation disrupted community activities. Shortly before 1 p.m., parents were notified that students on bus routes near Flatland Road and Hilltop Drive would need to be picked up from school due to safety concerns. Radcliffe Creek School, the closest school to the incident, advised keeping students indoors.
Residents in surrounding areas, including a trailer park near Sunny's Mart, were advised to stay inside.
Law enforcement personnel were observed in nearby woods, and a helicopter and drone were part of the operation.
At approximately 1:30 p.m., the subject voluntarily exited the residence and surrendered without incident. He was taken into custody and transported to a local medical facility for a mental health evaluation. Criminal charges are pending, Chestertown Police Chief Ron Dixon, lead agency on the incident, said.
Flatland Road remained closed throughout the day, with motorists advised to avoid the area. Authorities used the Everbridge alert system to notify nearby residents of the ongoing situation.
While initial police statements suggested no immediate public risk, neighbors expressed concerns about the incident's severity. The precise circumstances leading to the standoff remain under investigation.

title: ESCR offering free introductory lessons
author: Bill Haufe
content:
ESCR offering free introductory lessons

 April 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Bill Haufe | Section: News 
 
 366
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Eastern Shore Community Rowers (ESCR) are back on the water with a new season, new shells, and new times.ESCR is an adult (18-over) rowing team based at Evergreen on Port Street, supporting a wide range of skill levels, ages, and experience. The group is committed to sharing its passion and knowledge of rowing to anyone interested in learning.
ESCR has scheduled two free information sessions: April 12 and April 19 from 8:30 a.m. to 10:30 a.m. at Evergreen 770 Port Street. The sessions will be a chance to meet coaches and team members, learn about the 60-foot, eight-person rowing shells to singles, and how rowing is a super fun, sweaty good time.
ESCR will host two full Learn-to-Row clinics, April 28-May 1, from 5:30-7:30 p.m., and Saturday, May 3, from 8:30-10:30 a.m. Clinics will also be offered May 12-15 from 5:30-7:30 p.m., and Saturday, May 17, from 8:30-10:30 a.m. The cost is $400 for these 10-hour sessions.
ESCR is dedicated to teaching our community to row and offer more access area rivers. Scholarships are available to encourage everyone who may be interested. Beginners are encouraged to join the Learn-To-Row clinics, or to take private lessons from one of ESCR's accredited rowing coaches to acquire the skills needed for practices.
"The only criteria," said Board Safety Officer Terry Gleim, "is that you be able to swim and (are) strong enough to properly hold an oar. If swimming is an obstacle, ESCR will assist in helping you learn."
The rowing season runs from April-December with afternoon sessions for novices, 5:30 p.m. workouts Monday, Wednesday and Friday, and 7 p.m. rows on Tuesday and Thursday for more advanced rowers. There will also be a 7:30 a.m. row on Saturdays for all members.
"ESCR is open to anyone over 18 interested in having fun, getting healthy, and appreciating our beautiful waters," said Chloe Tong, the executive director. "The health of our rivers, as well as personal health, is an intrinsic part of our conversation."
As a non-profit, ESCR raises money through private donations, grants, and modest membership dues needed to fund the additional boats and necessary equipment for next year's rowing season.
For more information visit www.ESCRowers.org, or email head coach Chloe Allen: Director@escrowers.org

title: Easton introduces proposed $28M budget for FY26
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton introduces proposed $28M budget for FY26

 April 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 367
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Mayor Megan Cook said Easton's fiscal year 2026 budget focuses on transitioning the town out of an era of one-time funding sources and pandemic-related dollars."That period of growth positioned us well, but now we shift our focus to the responsibility of maintaining what we built," Cook said. "This year's budget is lean, focused on sustaining our progress by investing in the essentials."
At Monday's Town Council meeting, Cook presented a balanced draft budget with $28 million in general funds, nearly even with last year's mark. The capital fund budget came in just above $1 million.
Easton's property tax rate will remain the same as it has been since 2008 — 52 cents per $100 of assessed value. The town is projected to bring in around $13.6 million in real property taxes, according to the draft fiscal year 2026 budget, slightly up from last year.
"When you compare tax rates across the region, Easton stands out," Cook said. "We have the second lowest municipal property tax rate among surrounding towns, but we're also the largest community and provide the most comprehensive range of services."
The budget aims to equip town government departments with the necessary tools and training to do their jobs, Cook said. While "it's not exciting as building new things," she said, it's an important focus.
In the draft fiscal year 2026 budget, just above $1 million is allocated for transfer to capital work. That's down from the around $2.2 million mark in fiscal year 2025.
Cook added that areas of government improvement will include adding safety features to town hall, providing leadership training to Easton employees and hiring a new town manager. The town has been without a permanent employee in that role since last August.
Expenditure categories in the draft general fund budget include:
Public safety (police, fire, code enforcement, etc.): $11.5 million.
Public works: $7.1 million.
General government (financial administration, IT, HR, planning and zoning, executive functions, etc): $5.3 million.
Economic development: $503,000.
Recreation: $192,000.
"This year's budget reflects a shift: from growth driven by outside funding to careful maintenance, steady service and smart planning for what comes next," Cook said Monday.
A budget hearing is scheduled for the Town Council's next meeting on May 5. The budget can be accessed online at eastonmd.gov/CivicAlerts.aspx?AID=53.

title: TODAY IN HISTORY/Aug. 6
author: Staff Writer
content:
TODAY IN HISTORY/Aug. 6

 August 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 276
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On August 6, 1945, during World War II, the U.S. B-29 Superfortress Enola Gay dropped an atomic bomb on Hiroshima, Japan, resulting in an estimated 140,000 deaths.Also on this date:
In 1806, Emperor Francis II abdicated, marking the end of the Holy Roman Empire after nearly a thousand years.
In 1825, Upper Peru became the autonomous republic of Bolivia.
In 1890, at Auburn Prison in Auburn, New York, William Kemmler became the first person to be executed via the electric chair.
In 1926, Gertrude Ederle became the first woman to swim across the English Channel.
In 1942, Queen Wilhemina of the Netherlands became the first reigning queen to address a joint session of Congress, telling lawmakers that despite Nazi occupation, her people's motto remained, "No surrender."
In 1962, Jamaica gained independence from the United Kingdom after 300 years of British rule.
In 1965, President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Voting Rights Act, prohibiting racial discrimination in voting.
In 1991, the World Wide Web made its public debut as a means of accessing webpages over the Internet.
In 2011, insurgents shot down a U.S. military helicopter during fighting in eastern Afghanistan, killing 30 Americans, most of them belonging to the same elite Navy commando unit that had killed Osama bin Laden; seven Afghan commandos also died.
Today's Birthdays: Actor-director Peter Bonerz is 87. Actor Dorian Harewood is 75. Actor Leland Orser is 65. Actor Michelle Yeoh is 63. Basketball Hall of Famer David Robinson is 60. Movie writer-director M. Night Shyamalan is 55. Singer Geri Halliwell Horner is 53. Actor Vera Farmiga is 52. Actor Soleil Moon Frye is 49. Actor Leslie Odom Jr. is 44. Soccer coach and former player Robin van Persie is 42.

title: TODAY IN HISTORY/May 20
author: Staff Writer
content:
TODAY IN HISTORY/May 20

 May 20, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 452
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On May 20, 1927, Charles Lindbergh took off from Roosevelt Field on Long Island, New York, aboard the Spirit of St. Louis on his historic solo flight to France.On this date:
In 1862, President Abraham Lincoln signed the Homestead Act, which was intended to encourage settlements west of the Mississippi River by making federal land available for farming.
In 1916, the Saturday Evening Post published its first Norman Rockwell cover; the illustration shows a scowling boy dressed in his Sunday best, dutifully pushing a baby carriage past a couple of boys wearing baseball uniforms.
In 1932, Amelia Earhart took off from Newfoundland to become the first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic. (Because of weather and equipment problems, Earhart set down in Northern Ireland instead of her intended destination, France.)
In 1948, Chiang Kai-shek was inaugurated as the first president of the Republic of China (Taiwan).
In 1956, the United States exploded the first airborne hydrogen bomb over Bikini Atoll in the Pacific.
In 1959, nearly 5,000 Japanese-Americans had their U.S. citizenship restored after choosing to renounce it during World War II.
In 1961, a white mob attacked a busload of Freedom Riders in Montgomery, Alabama, prompting the federal government to send in U.S. marshals to restore order.
In 1969, U.S. and South Vietnamese forces captured Ap Bia Mountain, referred to as "Hamburger Hill" by the Americans, following one of the bloodiest battles of the Vietnam War.
In 1985, Radio Marti, operated by the U.S. government, began broadcasting; Cuba responded by attempting to jam its signal.
In 2009, in a rare, bipartisan defeat for President Barack Obama, the Senate voted overwhelmingly, 90-6, to keep the prison at Guantanamo Bay open for the foreseeable future and forbid the transfer of any detainees to facilities in the United States.
In 2012, Robin Gibb, who along with his brothers Maurice and Barry, defined the disco era as part of the Bee Gees, died in London at 62.
In 2013, Ray Manzarek, a founding member of the 1960s rock group the Doors, died in Germany at age 74.
In 2015, four of the world's biggest banks — JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup's banking unit Citicorp, Barclays and the Royal Bank of Scotland — agreed to pay more than $5 billion in penalties and plead guilty to rigging the currency markets.
In 2018, the Vegas Golden Knights reached the Stanley Cup Finals, becoming the first NHL expansion team to achieve the feat since 1968.
In 2020, President Donald Trump threatened to hold up federal funds for two election battleground states (Michigan and Nevada) that were making it easier to vote by mail during the pandemic.
In 2022, longtime New Yorker writer and editor Roger Angell, who contributed hundreds of essays and stories to the magazine over a 70-year career, died at age 101.
