title: Cage-free egg bill cracks under pressure
author: KIERSTEN HACKER Capital News Service
content:
Cage-free egg bill cracks under pressure

 March 19, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KIERSTEN HACKER Capital News Service | Section: General Assembly 
 
 760
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — A bill promoting cage-free eggs once got people excited but now it's stuck in committee, leaving sponsors uncertain if its future is on the sunny side.The measure would require all shell eggs raised or sold in Maryland to be cage-free by 2026. This would prohibit Maryland farmers with over 3,000 egg-laying hens from using what's known as battery cages, or conventional wire cages where hens are kept in close confinement.
The law would also require any eggs sold in Maryland supplied by other states to be cage-free.
"I think that we should be treating animals humanely," said House lead sponsor Del. Jennifer Terrasa (D-Howard County). "I think that's the bottom line."
But despite early optimism, Sen. Karen Lewis Young (D-Frederick), the Senate sponsor, tells Capital News Service she doesn't expect the bill to advance this session, even though she thinks cage-free eggs are "inevitable."
A stalemate would be at least a short-term win for agricultural interests in their ongoing national fight with animal rights advocates. The Humane Society has been advocating for cage-free eggs across the country, recently launching a six-figure advertising campaign for this legislation in Maryland. Some farms have adopted cage-free practices voluntarily.
Many farmers are against putting the requirement in law because of the increased cost of production, short phase-in period and potential for their birds to experience heightened health risks outside of the cage.
Farmers want to make their own decisions for how to best raise their birds.
Some advocates are surprised the legislation hasn't been successful in Maryland as other states passed similar laws regarding cages for farm animals. It's "rare" for Maryland to be behind on humane legislation, said Jennifer Bevan-Dangel, Maryland state director for the Humane Society of the United States.
"We've looked at what we consider the cruelest confinement practices," Bevan-Dangel said. "And these battery cages are one of the most inhumane tools that are still being used when we look at the farm animal landscape."
If the bill were to pass, it's estimated that six million birds would come out of cages, Bevan-Dangel said. About 11 farms that produce shell eggs in Maryland meet the criteria of 3,000 egg-laying hens, Bevan-Dangel said, but the sale prohibition would affect birds in other states as well.
According to state numbers, approximately 600 million eggs were produced in Maryland in 2022. About 10 million of those eggs came from smaller farms with fewer than 3,000 hens, which Bevan-Dangel said often use cage-free practices anyway.
But the farming community has pushed back on the legislation vigorously, citing financial concerns they say could put them out of business. Should surrounding states decide not to ban battery cages, Maryland farmers could be disadvantaged in the egg market, said Tyler Hough, director of government relations for the Maryland Farm Bureau.
"We would be forced out of business, our employees out of work," said Bill Dix of ISE America, a Maryland-based egg producer.
Some opponents argue there are cases where cage-free housing systems could even have negative effects on the welfare of hens. Access to the ground and other birds means more exposure to diseases, parasites and pecking order injuries, said veterinarian Matthew Weeman, legislative chairman for the Maryland Veterinary Medical Association.
The Maryland Veterinary Medical Association did not take a position on the bill but submitted informational testimony. Sometimes a cage is better for a bird and sometimes it isn't, said Weeman.
"We don't need a legislative mandate that says here you have to raise the bird this one way because that one way may not stand the test of time in perpetuity," Weeman said.
Many supporters of the bill argue that the egg industry is increasingly shifting toward cage-free practices anyway. By June 2023, according to the USDA, the share of cage-free hens increased to 38% of egg-laying hens in the U.S. Even large restaurant and grocery chains have made cage-free commitments, thus contributing to the increase in cage-free practices.
Weeman says this shift is not by industry choice, but instead by the work of activist groups. Some farmers are just giving in to the public pressure, he said.
Mandating cage-free eggs could price people out of buying eggs, farmers argue. In a 2023 report, the United Egg Producers determined that if regular eggs are taken from the market, the number of consumers who will forgo buying eggs will increase by 20 percentage points.
But Terrasa said this legislation would remove the cost of the premium for cage-free eggs, thus opening access to all Marylanders.
"I paid for it, that's fine," Terrasa said. "But I think everybody should be able to make that same ethical decision without the cost of the premium on it." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Barn fire outside Cambridge causes $150,000 in damages, fire marshal says
author: Konner Metz
content:
Barn fire outside Cambridge causes $150,000 in damages, fire marshal says

 June 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 131
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — A pole barn fire outside Cambridge on Thursday afternoon took hours to control and caused an estimated $150,000 in damages, according to the Office of the State Fire Marshal.Around 4:50 p.m. on Thursday, firefighters responded to Town Point Road, where a barn full of hay caught on fire. No injuries were reported.
The fire marshal lists the blaze as accidental and said it was caused by a "spontaneous combustion of the hay."
According to Cambridge Rescue Fire Company Chief Brad Walters, there were around 500 bails of hay in the pole barn. Surrounding equipment and woods were exposed to the fire, but no animals were hurt in the incident, he said.
Walters said crews were at the scene for around five hours. About 100,000 gallons of water were used, he added.

title: Historic Stevensville welcomes Chamber crawl
author: Laura Tayman
content:
Historic Stevensville welcomes Chamber crawl

 October 9, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Laura Tayman | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 700
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE-Late last month, on a beautiful fall evening in the historic Stevensville area, members of the Queen Anne's Chamber of Commerce were treated to a unique and highly successful networking event. Staying open after hours, business owners and chamber members were able to network and get a peak at each other's storefronts.Chambers across the country have begun sponsoring "crawl" events where members are welcomed into businesses located close to each other, allowing participants drop-in visits to learn more about each participating business, sampling their products and meeting their owners."This was our first such event," said Chamber Executive Director, Linda Friday, of the Sept. 27 event. "We were excited for our members to learn more about this special area of our community.We had nearly 70 participants registered to attend, with some never having even been in historic Stevensville before." The owners of the businesses were excited to share their history and success with Chamber guests as participants made their way through the few blocks on, and just off Main Street.Bill Huffnell, owner, and Amy Francis, director of Marketing and Communications, of Bay Point Wealth were on hand to greet visitors at their Stevensville office, which happens to be the historic Stevensville bank building of 1903. The building was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1983 and today still showcases the original ornamental pressed tin ceiling and vault. Huffnell provides the building as a site for the Kent Island Heritage Society to use on their tours for $1 a year.Members of the Historic Stevensville Arts & Entertainment District volunteers also greeted guests as they strolled Main Street; providing information on upcoming events, as well as regular activities taking place in the area, as was the Art East organization that supports local artists with regular meetings, trips, book discussions, and participation in community events.Across the street, Joan McWilliams's My Little Studio displayed the many talents of a shared-space gallery, where local artists and crafters rent space to create, show, and sell their work. Classes ranging from jewelry making to quilting are taught there as well.The sweets lovers were not disappointed. Over at the Tasty Toucan, owner Nikki Neboscynsky greeted chamber members Beth Mosner and Anna Hetzel, both from Miltec UV, who asked about her shop and how business was going.Mosner said, "Lots of members were excited about this event. It's nice to learn more about what these unique businesses have to offer." Across the street at the Peace of Cake bakery, sisters Kirsten and Kim Cate were busy working in the open kitchen and receiving compliments from happy chamber members who were enjoying a variety of their freshly baked items.Owners and sisters Kirsten and Kim Cate started their business in the same location 22 years ago and are still going strong."Business is a challenge," said Kirsten, "but baking is in our blood. For us, it's more than making a living." Chamber member Erich Krach, branch manager of Shore United Bank in Stevensville, said the crawl was his favorite chamber event so far. "I enjoyed seeing their businesses and seeing what we can offer them for support," said Krach.Chamber Board Member Eva Stoops participated as a both a chamber board member and a business located along the "crawl route." Stoops, co-owner of Chesapeake Environmental Lab, Inc., said she wasn't sure how the event would go at first."Right at 5 p.m. everyone started showing up," she said. "It's a fabulous event for both the participating businesses and the chamber.Many people don't how much the chamber does in providing these kinds of services and resources." Jessica Dolbec, who volunteers for both the Historic Stevensville Society and the Arts & Entertainment organization and works for Improvement Zone that is located on Main Street, assisted the chamber with providing regular communication among the participating businesses."It's wonderful to see the businesses open at this time, normally they are closed by now," she said. "I hope that this is a win-win for both groups." 
 
 Caption: LAURA TAYMAN
 
Maureen Wheatley is one of several local artists whose works are sold in My Little Studio in historic Stevensville owned by Joan McWilliams. The studio was open and guests welcomed at the Queen Anne's Chamber of Commerce's recent crawl.

title: Talbot County Democrats marked election night with celebration of campaign efforts
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Talbot County Democrats marked election night with celebration of campaign efforts

 November 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 691
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Cheers filled the BAAM Center on election night as dozens of local Democrats watched votes roll in for the 2024 general election and celebrated the end of a highly divisive election campaign.To be in community among like-minded residents, Talbot Democrats hosted an election watch party filled with food, drinks, guests dressed in their best campaign gear and deep discussion about hopes and fears for the future.
Patrick Firth, chair of the Talbot County Democratic Central Committee, said this celebration was needed for the community on the Shore. Firth said the people gathered on Tuesday are the heartbeat of the Democratic community and more than anything deserved a celebration and to feel appreciated for all their work.
"We had a record of over 200 individual volunteers helping us throughout the election, from greeting voters to canvassing, to phone banking," Firth said. "Talbot led the Eastern Shore this past weekend in canvassing, knocking on over 1000 doors in Talbot County."
Lined around the room were political signs showing support for Vice President Kamala Harris, Maryland Senate candidate Angela Alsobrooks and Talbot County candidate for Board of Education Candace Henry.
Kathy Hostetter, resident of Wye Mills, said she was feeling hopeful Tuesday night though she understood the presidential race would be close. Hostetter shared her enthusiasm for Alsobrooks, who hours later would win a U.S. Senate Seat in Maryland.
"Talbot County is one of the most beautiful places," Hostetter said. "We have a great state here in Maryland, we've got a great blue state. So tonight, we're very hopeful, and we want to keep it blue."
Hours after the party ended, former president Donald Trump triumphed over Democratic opponent Kamala Harris. Though initially expected to be a close race, Trump flipped several swing states in his favor and won the popular vote for the first time as a candidate.
Election night was a mix of triumphs and defeats for Democrats in Maryland. Alsobrooks claimed victory over incumbent Republican former Gov. Larry Hogan. Additionally, Maryland voters overwhelmingly supported an amendment to Maryland's constitution for reproductive freedom.
Michele Dappert, president of the Talbot County Democrat Party, said though Maryland is a famously blue state, this year's election has divided voters, especially in Talbot County.
According to the State Board of Elections' unofficial 2024 General Election Results for Talbot County, over half of voters chose former President Donald Trump as their presidential candidate and an overwhelming number of residents voted for Republican candidate Larry Hogan for U.S. Senate.
Dappert said though there is political separation among those on the Eastern Shore, all voters have essentially the same end goal: to have their values understood, heard and put into practice.
"Look, I get it, politics can be contentious, but when you meet people locally at the door, most of us are just trying to get by, and we're just trying to send our kids to school, have clean water, be able to walk outside and feel safe no matter what you look like and who you are," Dappert said. "And those are all very universal values, so I find it very important to defend them."
Sitting next to Dappert in a Kamala Harris camo cap and a blue shirt, which showed "CLXXVII Minutes" on the front and "11,780 Votes" on the back, was her father George Dappert. George Dappert explained the meaning behind his shirt.
The front represented, in roman numerals, the 186 minutes Trump watched TV during the Jan. 6 insurrection. The back represented the number of votes Trump was trying to find in Georgia to turn the state in his favor during the 2020 Presidential Election.
George Dappert said the Democratic Party has done everything they could in terms of getting out to vote, talking to people and getting the message out there for others to vote. For him, practicing the political right of voting is essential to democracy and he urges everyone to continue to be politically active regardless of major elections.
"It is what generations of our forefathers and foremothers have fought for, bled for, marched for, done everything that they could," George Dappert said. "To willfully not vote is an abdication of your responsibility and what they have given from their past to our future." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

Oct. 17

1954 — Adrian Burk of the Philadelphia Eagles passes for seven touchdowns in a 49-21 victory over the Washington Redskins. Burk completes 19 of 27 passes for 232 yards and his longest touchdown pass is 26 yards.

2000 — Patrick Roy sets an NHL record with his 448th career victory as Colorado beats Washington 4-3 in overtime. Roy snaps a tie with Terry Sawchuk, who held the mark since 1970. Sawchuk earned his 447th victory in his 968th game, while Roy wins No. 448 in his 847th game.
2015 — Star forward Cristiano Ronaldo becomes Real Madrid's all-time leading scorer across all competitions, overtaking club legend Raul with his 324th goal in a 3-0 win over Levante.
2015 — Jalen Watts-Jackson scoops up a flubbed punt attempt and lumbers 38 yards for a touchdown on the final play of the game, giving No. 7 Michigan State a shocking 27-23 win over No. 12 Michigan at the Big House.
2017 — Boston's Gordon Hayward breaks his left ankle just five minutes into the season, a grisly injury that overshadows Kyrie Irving's return to Cleveland and the Cavaliers' 102-99 win over the shocked Celtics.
2021 — The Chicago Sky defeat the Phoenix Mercury 81-74 to win their first WNBA Championship three games to one. The Sky's Kahleah Copper is named Finals MVP.

title: Experts discuss Mid-Shore impacts of human trafficking
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Experts discuss Mid-Shore impacts of human trafficking

 April 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Local News 
 
 751
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Around 180 people attended the For All Seasons presentation on human trafficking on Tuesday night at the Avalon Theatre, where a panel of experts painted a picture of a changing landscape for trafficking crimes.With the increasing use of social media, traffickers find and groom their victims at home, a more methodical trust-gaining method than before the advent of the internet, they said.
According to Thomas Stack, anti-human trafficking and sexual assault response manager for Mayor's Neighborhood Office of Safety and Engagement for the City of Baltimore, because young people's lives are so transparent online, traffickers can target individuals who are alone, mad at their parents and not doing well in school. Low self esteem is the target, he said.
"It is all about getting the word out there. Human trafficking has been around a long time, but the awareness has probably only been around for the last 20 years," Stack said. "Maryland has a toxic mixture of both poverty and wealth. The poverty is a major risk factor for exploitation and the wealth is the buyers of sex, the people who are willing to purchase people for their pleasure."
Maryland is also geographically vulnerable to trafficking, the experts said.
"We are two hours from Philly, three hours from New York, we have a lot of sporting events, we have two major cities, and we have airports and casinos, everything a trafficker wants," Stack said. "Like we have the Preakness coming up. There will be a lot of males who have traveled here. The traffickers know that and will bring their victims of sex trafficking to service those males."
The speakers made it clear that human trafficking happens in the Mid-Shore community.
"There was a 15-year-old trafficked in Denton, so it is here," Stack said.
By becoming more aware of the problem, they said, community members can identify victims and reach out.
Heather Amador, deputy director of victim services policy and programs for the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy, was one of the speakers. She said members of the community can look for signs of trafficking, like bruises, new tattoos and new suggestive clothing.
Red flags can also appear online, Stack said, like if a teenager has multiple Facebook profiles with some that have nothing to do with their family or friends.
"Human trafficking is here. People don't want to believe that their neighbors are capable of such things," Amador said. "A lot of human trafficking victims don't even identify as a victim. They see themselves as voluntarily engaging in it. They don't see the coercion that goes along with it. They are deceived to go down this path or forced into addiction. They think they are helping someone else out."
Amador had one victim in her office who simply said she needed to make money. She was a runaway and had nowhere to go, Amador said, and she needed housing.
Amador came across a case where a child had to perform a sex act to get lunch money in her lunch account and emphasized that that is trafficking too.
For All Seasons offers a host of services around human trafficking, from trainings, to getting the word out, to psychological services, to addiction services.
Beth Anne Dorman, CEO and president of For All Seasons, says it takes a village to combat trafficking.
"Our anti-human trafficking efforts focused on a team-based approach," she said. "We collaborate with law enforcement, first responders, Department of Social Services, child advocacy centers, school administrators, teachers and the hospital, officials from the towns and counties we serve."
Then she introduced a video of Maryland Comptroller Brooke Lierman, who created and helped pass legislation to make the Maryland Regional Navigator program when she was a legislator. This program supports survivors of trafficking. For All Seasons is a participant.
"Maryland recorded 118 cases of human trafficking involving 173 victims. This figure includes sex and labor exploitation. Child sex trafficking is also a concern. Since 2012 over 500 children have been identified by Child Protective Services as reportedly being trafficked in Maryland. This remains vastly under reported," Lierman said in the video.
She said she was committed to ensuring access to services for every survivor of sex trafficking in Maryland. She highlighted For All Seasons as "essential to the safety and wellness of our communities."
The night ended with a call to action for the audience.
"It is a hidden crime so we all have to be alert," said Susan Ahlstrom, regional navigator at For All Seasons. "We all have to be vigilant."
For more information on human trafficking and available resources, visit missingkids.org, polaris.com and netsmartz.com

title: Monster munchies: Duff Goldman and Rosanna Pansino host creepy cookie contest
author: Caroline Collacutt
content:
Monster munchies: Duff Goldman and Rosanna Pansino host creepy cookie contest

 October 12, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Caroline Collacutt | Page: 14A | Section: News 
 
 386
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Sugar, spice and everything spooky: Season 2 of "Halloween Cookie Challenge" airs Mondays through October on Food Network."Celebrity pastry chef Duff Goldman and social media sensation Rosanna Pansino celebrate the wildest and most colorful holiday of the year!," Food Network describes."They'll bring together the best cookie makers in the country to compete in two challenges and create the creepiest, spookiest and tastiest Halloween cookies ever made! The winner takes home a trick-or-treat bag filled with $10,000!" And that's $10,000 every episode.New contestants park their brooms at the kitchen door and take on Goldman and Pansino's cookie challenge every week, showcasing talent from far and wide.So far this season, the competing cookie confectioners have faced monsters big and small, exploring what would happen if our favorite Halloween treats had a taste for us, too. Bakers have been asked to: make two-sided trick-or-treat bags - with one side being light and fun while the other is dark and spooky - out of lemon candies, black licorice and peach rings; decorate cookies with scary self-portraits; craft life-size oozing zombie parts out of cookies, overflowing with gooey marmalades and jams; and create creepy, 3D haunted mirrors - each old and cracked with crunchy treats like kettle chips, pretzels and corn chips.This week, "Edible stained glass is one of the most colorful and bewitching trends in the cookie world, and four cookie experts make glowing Halloween stainedglass cookies," the network promises."After one cookier is eliminated, the remaining three masters build giant, elaborate Halloween fun houses that would thrill any Halloween carnival-goer. The judges will really feel like they are at a carnival as the bakers must incorporate fun fair flavors like caramel apples, grilled corn, popcorn balls and deep-fried sandwich cookies." In the season's final episode, the final four competing cookie makers hope to scare the pants off hosts Goldman and Pansino by making edible, three-story haunted houses. Then, in the last round, Food Network has shared that, "The three remaining cookiers host a séance by making playable spirit boards. To make sure there is maximum 'spirit' in their boards, they will include spirits like apple brandy, cinnamon whiskey, coffee rum and black currant liqueur." A rambunctious carnival filled with delicious treats, Season 2 of Food Network's "Halloween Cookie Challenge" airs new episodes Mondays through October. 
 
 Caption: Rosanna Pansino co-hosts "Halloween Cookie Challenge"

title: Maryland Stories: U.S. Army veteran honored for 50 years with the DAV
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
Maryland Stories: U.S. Army veteran honored for 50 years with the DAV

 May 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 643
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Ralph Gough began working with the Disabled American Veterans when he was medically discharged from the military in 1974, and last month — a half century later — he was recognized for his work.The Lexington Park resident, who serves as a judge advocate, received an award on April 27 for his 50 years of service with the St. Mary's DAV Chapter 26 in Lexington Park.
"It's a wild moment," Gough said as he sat at a picnic table at the Leonardtown Wharf a few days before the ceremony. "Where has the time gone? I look at it from the time I've come in and I look around [now]. A lot of friends have passed on and I wish they could have been here. It's been rewarding. It makes me feel that that I reached someone [to help]."
"It's cool," said DAV Chapter 26 Vice Commander James Williams, who has been a member of the St. Mary's chapter the past three years. "He won't tell you but he's the go-to guy. If you have questions or problems he has the information."
Gough said the DAV is an important resource for veterans; its website provides a calendar of upcoming events, services and 28 links veterans can click on to access forms and information.
"It's helped improve communication with other veterans," he said, "and it does [benefit] claims which helps us increase our compensation, and for those who don't get compensation it helps them get theirs."
The DAV Chapter 26 is open 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. Wednesdays at the Local Lodge 4 Machinist Union hall at 21795 Shangri-La Drive in Lexington Park. It has moved a few times over the past couple years.
"We don't have a home and we've been fighting that for years," Gough said. "And if we did have a home where we could be open eights hours a day or whatever, we as veterans could come in and get together."
Gough was asked if the DAV is a type of fraternity for veterans.
"Yes it is, and once you get to know [the vets] and they start to come in and there's a bond that you never break," he said. "My only downside is that I've met a lot of people who went to Vietnam and I had no overseas experience. I'm glad I didn't [have to go overseas], but it can be hard to bond [with those who have]. They have the stories and I can't imagine."
Gough graduated from Great Mills High School in 1968 and was drafted two years later. He was sent to Fort Holabird in Baltimore, then to Fort Dix, N.J., for eight weeks of basic training. He later attended Redstone Arsenal, Missile and Munition Center & School in Huntsville, Alabama, before being assigned to the 200th Ordnance Detachment GMGS Unit Training Command to begin on the job training. The GMGS is a type of grenade launcher.
He later went to Quartermaster School at Fort Lee, Virginia., to become a missile repair parts specialist, which he did the rest of his military career and made him eligible for promotion to E-5 Special Fifth Class.
Because of an injury to his foot, Gough received a medical discharge on Oct. 11, 1972.
"It helped me a lot," Gough said of the services he received from the DAV in the 1970s. "They do it all for you. I've stayed around for 50 years just to see if I could help people."
"It's the most rewarding job I've had," Williams said. "Every Wednesday my mind is set to help veterans, because every veteran has a different story."
He began working at the DAV in 1974 and has held several positions, including a stint as commander from 1993-1995.
"As long as I can move and have a little breathe [in me]," Gough said, "I'll always be there to help people."
For more about the St. Mary's County DAV Chapter 26, call 240-925-5439 or go to www.davch26stmarysmd.com.

title: TODAY IN HISTORY/July 14
author: Staff Writer
content:
TODAY IN HISTORY/July 14

 July 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Columns 
 
 365
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On July 14, 1789, in an event symbolizing the start of the French Revolution, citizens of Paris stormed the Bastille prison and released the seven prisoners inside.Also on this date:
In 1798, Congress passed the Sedition Act, making it a federal crime to publish false, scandalous or malicious writing about the United States government.
In 1881, outlaw William H. Bonney Jr., alias "Billy the Kid," was shot and killed by Sheriff Pat Garrett in Fort Sumner in present-day New Mexico.
In 1912, American folk singer-songwriter Woody Guthrie was born in Okemah, Oklahoma.
In 1933, all German political parties, except the Nazi Party, were outlawed by the government of Nazi Germany.
In 1945, Italy formally declared war on Japan, its former Axis partner during World War II.
In 1960, 26-year-old Jane Goodall first arrived at the Gombe Stream Reserve in present-day Tanzania to begin her study of the wild chimpanzees living there.
In 2004, the Senate scuttled a constitutional amendment banning gay marriage. (Forty-eight senators voted to advance the measure — 12 short of the 60 needed — and 50 voted to block it.)
In 2009, disgraced financier Bernard Madoff arrived at the Butner Federal Correctional Complex in North Carolina to begin serving a 150-year sentence for his massive Ponzi scheme. (Madoff died in prison in April 2021.)
In 2013, thousands of demonstrators across the country protested a Florida jury's decision the day before to clear George Zimmerman in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin.
In 2015, world powers and Iran struck a deal to curb Iran's nuclear program in exchange for relief from international sanctions.
In 2016, terror struck Bastille Day celebrations in the French Riviera city of Nice as a large truck plowed into a festive crowd, killing 86 people in an attack claimed by Islamic State extremists; the driver was shot dead by police.
In 2020, researchers reported that the first COVID-19 vaccine tested in the U.S. boosted people's immune systems as scientists had hoped; the vaccine was developed by the National Institutes of Health and Moderna Inc.
In 2022, the National Galleries of Scotland said a previously unknown self-portrait of Vincent Van Gogh was discovered behind another of the artist's paintings when experts took an X-ray of the canvas ahead of an upcoming exhibition.

title: Republicans continue to push Talbot Board of Elections on election judge breakdown
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Republicans continue to push Talbot Board of Elections on election judge breakdown

 October 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 775
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — County Republicans continued to push the Talbot County Board of Elections to equal its selection of election judges during the board's monthly meeting on Wednesday morning.The breakdown by party was 62 Democratic judges, 50 Republican judges and 11 unaffiliated judges in September, according to Election Director Tammy Stafford. Local officials have indicated at meetings that the number of judges for each party may now be closer to equal, but this has not been confirmed by the Board of Elections.
Election officials have said the makeup is "fluid" and will change up until Election Day. During Wednesday's meeting, Stafford said "judges are always needed" and that her office "continuously" accepts interest forms.
According to Sept. 18 meeting minutes read aloud Wednesday, staffing for the election began in June of 2023. Training for those who filled out interest forms began in early 2024.
In the last month, concerns have circulated regarding a party imbalance of election judges, or those who staff polling places on Election Day.
Local officials, including Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble and Talbot County Council Member Dave Stepp, have cited that the board is not in compliance with state law.
Maryland election code states "each polling place shall have an equal number of election judges" from "the majority party" and "the principal minority party."
State election law permits judges not affiliated with either party for precincts with six or more judges, as well as "one or more election judges who are minors." The number of unaffiliated judges "may not exceed the lesser of" the majority or minority party, law states.
These concerns led to a flurry of responses from state agencies emphasizing the security of the electoral process. In an Oct. 2 statement responding to a letter sent by Gamble to the Talbot Board of Elections, State Board of Elections Administrator Jared DeMarinis said voters should feel "confident" in the state's election security and "compliance with the law."
Attorney General Anthony Brown weighed in as well, writing a letter to Gamble on Oct. 7.
"Even at the individual polling place level, while all local boards make best efforts to achieve exact party balance, this is not always possible for reasons outside the local board's control, including the number of judges from each party who volunteer," Brown wrote.
Stafford stated at the Sept. 18 meeting that the training for election judges can no longer be done after Oct. 8 since the room used for training is also used for canvassing.
During Wednesday's public comment, Gary Judy, a member of the Talbot County Republican Central Committee, said he's heard from Republicans who applied to be an election judge but were not told there are no vacancies for this year's general election. He said the fact that the board did not achieve exact party balance is "extremely alarming to Talbot County voters."
"We decided to keep close track on it this year," Judy said, "and can confirm that there were more than enough Republicans who signed up to be election judges to fill the available Republican positions of the equal representation required by Maryland election law."
On Wednesday, Judy provided board members with copies of a letter written by the Maryland Republican Party addressing election judge concerns in Talbot County. Adam Wood, executive director of the Maryland Republican Party, later told the Star Democrat that the letter was a "draft" letter and had not been sent to the state board.
Shari Wilcoxon, also a member of the Republican central committee, spoke during public comment, asking the board to ensure "parity" of election judges.
"I think that it is an actual embarrassment that this board is allowing the executive director free rein to break the law," Wilcoxon said. "It is your duty to hold her feet to the fire, and that she does what is Maryland law."
Wilcoxon questioned why election judge applications were denied in February and March.
"February and March had to do with the primary," Stafford responded. "Let's be specific here. That was the primary. Those were the first people who were contacted for the general (election)."
This led to tense back-and-forth between Wilcoxon and Stafford.
Board President Susan MacKinnon stepped in, asking Wilcoxon to stop speaking.
"You have had the opportunity to speak, you are now being disruptive," MacKinnon said to Wilcoxon. "You are being disruptive, and if you continue being disruptive, I will call a recess and have you removed."
Wednesday's meeting was the board's last regularly scheduled meeting before the election Nov. 5. During Stafford's report to the board, she said "logic and accuracy testing on the electronic equipment was completed" on Sept. 16. The Board of Elections will have its logic and accuracy testing documentation available for public inspection Friday at 10 a.m. at 215 Bay Street in Easton.

title: Lockerman Middle School celebrates new STEM Center
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Lockerman Middle School celebrates new STEM Center

 December 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 469
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Lockerman Middle School's new science, technology, engineering and mathematics center was celebrated on Tuesday for providing students with unique opportunities and STEM-related resources.The STEM Center held a ribbon-cutting Tuesday afternoon with partners from the University of Maryland Medical System. A $500,000 grant was given to the Cal Ripken, Sr. Foundation, which is funding STEM centers at 10 different schools in Maryland, including Lockerman.
Caroline County Public Schools Superintendent Derek Simmons said the foundation's contribution is bringing unique experiences to Lockerman students.
"There's no way that this level of resource and these tools would be able to get in the hands of our middle school kids if it wasn't for your partnership and Ripken Foundation's work," Simmons said.
On Tuesday, students showed off the new tools and gadgets that were funded by the grant, such as a 3D printer, coding robots and electronic kits. In the school cafeteria, two students flew drones.
Sixth grader Gracie Spiering showed off her knowledge of how to make backpack security alarms or model cars using littleBits Electronic kits. She knew how to order the kit's pieces and wires, and learned how the coding worked.
"It's been so much fun to have in class," Spiering said. "Everybody's been so ready to come into that class."
Meanwhile, many students have been utilizing the 3D printers to make ornaments for the holidays. Seventh grader Madison Watson said it's been a smooth learning process thanks to the help of her teachers.
"It's pretty fun to have them just at any time we really want them to be here," Watson said.
Lockerman Middle School Principal Jeannine Necessary said students love learning how to use the new materials. Staff members were trained and encouraged to integrate the STEM tools into everyday learning, the principal said.
During the ribbon-cutting, University of Maryland Shore Regional Health President and CEO Ken Kozel said the healthcare system appreciates students involved in STEM because the students are "highly motivated and educated."
"We're here to promote STEM because it's such an important part of the healthcare system," Kozel said. "We're local, we're small, we're a community hospital system, but we need our community to help support our workforce needs."
With a handful of students excited to show off the new technology on Tuesday, Simmons reflected on how much the grant means to the Denton middle school, given the district's financial challenges.
"About 60 to 65 percent of our students qualify for free and reduced meals, which puts a little bit different lens on the opportunities that our kids have to access things," Simmons said. "It also puts a lens on the opportunity the school system has funding-wise to be able to provide those avenues.
"We are thrilled that we were selected by you guys, in partnership with the Ripken Foundation, to be able to provide opportunity and access that we could've never funded for our students."

title: Police: Couple robbed homeless man inside his tent
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Police: Couple robbed homeless man inside his tent

 October 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 442
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A man and a woman face assault, theft and other criminal charges after they allegedly attacked and robbed a homeless man inside his tent in Elkton, according to Cecil County District Court records.Investigators identified the suspects as Elkton residents Justin William Hand, 27, and 50-year Brandy Lee Gibbs, who, according to court records, had been "longtime friends" with the alleged victim.
The investigation leading to their arrests and the charges against them started at approximately 11:45 p.m. on Wednesday (Sept. 25), when the alleged victim went to Elkton Police Department's headquarters on Railroad Avenue and told an officer that he had been robbed, court records show.
The man reported that he was inside his tent in a wooded area near the West End Gardens Motel property in the 200 block of West Pulaski Highway, when Gibbs asked him for $20, police said. After the man declined, Gibbs allegedly started yelling aggressively as she accused the alleged victim of "being smart with" her and then ordered Hand, who was standing nearby, to kill him, police added.
At that point, Hand allegedly started beating the man with a "metal blunt object," prompting the alleged victim to hold up a mattress to deflect the blows, according to the charging document.
Then Gibbs and Hand cut open the man's tent with their knives, court records allege.
The man told investigators that Gibbs yelled, "Stop," to Hand and, at that point, the suspects got into white 2019 Dodge Ram and sped away, police reported.
After the suspects had fled, the man realized that his bicycle and $150 were missing, police said, noting that his bike is valued at $150. During the incident, the man's tent and mattress were destroyed, translating to a $500 loss, police added.
Court records indicate that the man told investigators that he was "longtime friends" with Gibbs, whom he described to police as "an older white female of medium build with no teeth." He, however, did not know her last name — only that it started with a "G," police noted.
The alleged victim described Hand as a "middle aged" white man of "skinny build with face tattoos," police reported.
"Due to the suspect descriptions, officers believed the suspect description provided matched those of Brandy Gibbs and Justin Hand, who(m) officers are familiar with through prior contact," according to the charging document.
When an investigator displayed photos of Hand and Gibbs, the alleged victim identified them as the suspects, court records show. Investigators were able to track down Hand and Gibbs and arrest them, police reported.
Hand and Gibbs are each facing numerous criminal charges, including home invasion, first-degree assault, robbery, theft, malicious destruction of property and related conspiracy counts, court records show.

title: 13th annual Watermen’s Appreciation Day draws a crowd
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
13th annual Watermen’s Appreciation Day draws a crowd

 August 12, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 437
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ST. MICHAELS — Hundreds of people enjoyed boat docking contests, steamed local crabs, live music and family activities to celebrate the 13th annual Watermen's Appreciation Day hosted at the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum on Sunday.Watermen's Appreciation Day brings people together to celebrate the longstanding history of watermen on the Eastern Shore, as well as fundraise for the Talbot Watermen's Association.
Jeff Harrison, president of the association, said the event began in 2010 and has grown throughout the years. For Harrison, the number of people attending every year shows the local community's support for watermen.
"There is this appreciation for the local watermen in this area and, of course, all over the Bay," Harrison said. "And we are actually trying to grab a hold of that in some of our fundraisers and to let people know that we do appreciate them and that we're glad that they appreciate us also."
Harrison, dressed in a yellow volunteer shirt, was part of a team of over a 100 volunteers assisting attendees and contestants.
The Harrison family were all part of the volunteer team. Ashley and James Harrison, along with a group of five boys under the age of 13, stood behind a volunteer table near crowded bleachers awaiting the boat docking competition.
Ashley Harrison said volunteering at the Watermen Appreciation Day event is a family tradition she married into and has decided to establish in her family. This tradition stems from her husband, who comes from a family of watermen and who began volunteering when he was a young boy.
"We like doing stuff for the children," Ashley Harrison said. "We have three of our own, and we love seeing them have fun at events as well. And we like helping our community and showing our visitors that come here that this is a really great place to come and we're a tight knit community."
Under the sun, hundreds of people crowded and squeezed together to catch a glimpse of the boat docking contest. Boat owners of all ages showed off their skills and embraced cheers and support from the crowd.
Shannon Mitchell, vice president of engagement for the Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, said this event is a part of a partnership between the museum and local watermen to benefit the watermen in their fundraising, sponsorship and silent auction work. The museum benefits from the admission intake, she said.
"This one is very much mission-focused in supporting our local watermen," Mitchell said. "It's a big piece of why the museum exists to begin with. They tell a big story about the Chesapeake Bay and our region, so it's really exciting to see everyone come out and support them."

title: Kent Island Community Garden relocates
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Kent Island Community Garden relocates

 October 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 410
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A local garden will now find a fresh home in the community as the Queen Anne's County Commissioners approved a lease agreement with Kent Island Community Garden, Inc. for relocation to 210 White Pine Lane in Stevensville Oct. 8.The community garden formerly located in the Harbor View section of Chester used the land next to Galilee Lutheran Church for about ten years, group representative John McKnight said. Following the land sale from the church, the garden had to look for a new home and McKnight reached out to the County Commissioners over the summer for assistance.
Formed in 2015 as the Galilee Community Garden, the Kent Island Community Garden serves the need for a community garden in the Harbor View area of Chester and has since blossomed to include church volunteers, local Master Gardeners, Boy Scout Troop 495 and neighbors of all sorts ready to get their thumbs green.
The community garden also partners with the University of Maryland Extension Master Gardeners Program for educational opportunities.
The garden offers many beds of vegetables, flowers, and a separate herb garden with an irrigation system and compost area.
The Maryland Food Bank cites that one in three Marylanders face hunger. "With several of our gardeners in independent living facilities and one handicapped gardener, we realize how critical it is to establish a new space for our community garden," McKnight said.
Voicing their appreciation for the garden, the county Commissioners approved a $1,500 grant to help the garden blossom at its new location.
The new location's property next to the offices of the Fire Marshal is an ideal location to offer sufficient land for growth along with the necessary utilities as well as close proximity to the Cross-Island Trail, local schools, and the public library.
"It's going to be a great resource for the county," McKnight said.
The Kent Island Community Garden is always looking for new gardeners and civic minded groups to help build garden beds, according to McKnight.
The all inclusive garden stakes claim in having the only handicapped-accessible garden beds in the county, he said.
"We are a diverse and unique group of twenty gardeners and are the only community garden in Queen Anne's County that is open to all, " McKnight said.
Looking ahead, the garden hopes to build a few garden beds before winter sets in and In the spring seeks funds to install a deer fence around the perimeter, he said.
More information about Kent Island Community Garden can be found by contacting McKnight at McKnightJohn143@gmail.com or 202-257-3754.

title: WHCP running membership drive through Nov. 11
author: Contributed
content:
WHCP running membership drive through Nov. 11

 November 3, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 6 | Section: News 
 
 501
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WHCP (91.7 FM) has just come on as a full-service NPR member station for the Mid-Shore with Morning Edition, All Things Considered, and 80% of its schedule devoted to being a "Music Discovery Station." The station offers a diverse lineup of musical styles - big band, neo-soul, blues, indie music, jazz, folk, classic country and deep tracks from the Boomer Tunes era.In addition, the station offers Mid-Shore news updates on Mid-Shore Mid-Day, some of which are provided by partners at the The Star Democrat.Additionally, every day the WHCP Community Calendar is updated, presenting events throughout the Mid-Shore region, along with 20-20 Marine Weather, which offers up-to-date forecasts twice each hour.To support all of these public radio offerings, WHCP is holding a membership drive through Nov. 11."A generous anonymous local donor has made a matching gift of $10,000 so that membership support is automatically doubled until we reach the $10,000 level," said Mike Starling, founder, president and general manager of WHCP."We are excited our new signal on 91.7 reaches roughly 75,000 people on the Mid-Shore (Talbot, Dorchester, and portions of Caroline, plus over 100,000 more in Wicomico and Southern Maryland)," he said. "We are now touting signal coverage, but more importantly the program upgrades as a grassroots community station carrying NPR's most popular programs too." During the station's very first fall membership drive, WHCP said it is proud to be among a select group of 17 NPR member stations that can offer the NPR+ podcast bundle of 16 podcasts as a thank-you gift to those joining or renewing their membership of at least $96 annually ($8 per month).Additionally, Premier Movie Theaters in Cambridge and Easton have partnered with WHCP, and the station is making two passes available to any current members (new, returning or sustaining at the $60 family membership level and above). Passes can be picked up at WHCP's Cambridge studio."New and renewing members are critically important to our program plans for the year ahead," said Starling. "Individual annual memberships start at just $35, and you can become a sustaining monthly member for less than $7 a month, at whcp.org/donate." In addition to its regular programming, WHCP also operates a free public service with the Mid-Shore Reader, a round-the-clock radio reading service for those who cannot read the printed word on their own.Fresh daily readings of books, newspapers and magazines, including The Star Democrat, are read each week by local volunteers, as well as the monthly Attractions, Shore Monthly and Tidewater Times magazines."If you or someone you know suffers from vision loss, or who otherwise cannot see, hold, or comprehend the printed word, this service is available free of charge," said Starling. "Just contact the station at info@whcp.org to learn more or volunteer to be a reader on the Mid-Shore Reader." There are four ways to listen to WHCP Radio - on the air at 91.7 FM, via the WHCP app, online at whcp.org, or simply ask Alexa to "launch WHCP Radio." For more information about becoming a member of WHCP, visit whcp.org or call 443-637-6000.

title: Residual bill passed by Caroline County Commissioners
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Residual bill passed by Caroline County Commissioners

 September 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 365
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — On Tuesday morning, the Caroline County Commissioners voted to approve the long-discussed bill that would establish county regulations for storing food processing residuals, animal waste from the food processing process.These residuals, particularly dissolved air floatation, or DAF, residuals have been the topic of several heated discussions in the county since residents began raising health complaints and environmental concerns over how the material was being stored by some in the county late last year.
The county came up with a permitting system. There will be a universal permit requirement in order to store food processing residuals. It creates limitations on how residuals can be stored and permits the county to fine violators.
It would require that those storing the material use closed-top containers, going a step further than recently passed state legislation.
Attorney Stewart Barroll said commissioners and Caroline County staff had heard "voluminous" public comments that have been taken into account.
Prior to voting, two amendments were approved by commissioners involving distances from the storage containers.
Commissioner Franklin Bartz said he would prefer the storage distance and an occupied dwelling be increased to 2,000 feet measured horizontally rather than the 1,250-foot distance that was in the bill.
After discussion, the commissioners unanimously voted to approve the change.
Commissioner J. Travis Breeding requested a second amendment that would require the storage not to be within 500 feet of a well. This way, it would allow property owners to move wells somewhere else on their property to be 500 feet away from stored residuals to not contaminate water sources.
Commissioner Larry Porter brought up the discussion of postponing voting on the act until the Maryland Department of Agriculture shares their regulations. The vote had been postponed at the prior two meetings so the commissioners could review the proposed amendments to the legislation.
Breeding said there would not be a need to postpone for regulation changes because commissioners are acting well within the parameters of Maryland statue.
"There's only so much that the Department of Agriculture can do," Breeding said. "Everything that we have done inside of this legislature is not in conflict with the statue that the state has."
The bill was unanimously approved by the commissioners and has been enacted into the county law. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: DoCo Axe Co. aims to support community
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content:
DoCo Axe Co. aims to support community

 March 24, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com | Section: Business 
 
 711
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — For DoCo Axe Co. co-owner Sabrina Franciotti, the business is about more than having fun.Although DoCo Axe Co. offers fun in multiple forms — from virtual reality escape room adventures to a virtual golf simulator to virtually-projected axe throwing games — Franciotti said the local business is also a great place to practice healthy coping mechanisms.
"Coming to a place like us is actually super beneficial to your mental wellness," Franciotti said. "Being around other people doing this activity that we coach you through, we can help you with. ... It's cathartic to sink the axe in the wood."
Franciotti, along with Rob Chase and her husband Carmen Franciotti, took over the business in December 2022.
Along with offering a place for people to practice healthy coping, DoCo Axe Co. wants to help the community in other ways.
This year, the local business started naming a DoCo Axe DoGooder of the Month. Every month, people can nominate someone who is doing good in the community. Whoever wins the title that month receives $50 from DoCo Axe Co.
Franciotti herself is also working to do good in the Cambridge community and beyond. In 2022, she started a nonprofit called Homeless & Human, which works to advocate and resource share for people who are experiencing homelessness or on the verge of homelessness.
Franciotti understand that the resources available to those experiencing homelessness "far under-weigh the overwhelming needs." For years, she experienced homelessness as a single mother with two kids and a full-time job.
Technically, Franciotti said, she is still homeless, living with her sister.
"Most people are struggling to find housing," she said. "Even well-employed people."
Owning DoCo Axe Co. has given Franciotti the opportunity to make more connections in the community and get the word out about her nonprofit.
"We have a donation box," she said about DoCo Axe Co. "We tell every single person who comes through the door what they're supporting is this."
Franciotti said that conversation is important because a lot of the business' clientele don't know about the needs of the homeless population.
"So we can have this opportunity to chat with people about how it's teachers and nurses and the person who's working at the grocery store ... (who) are struggling to find housing and just survive day to day."
Although DoCo Axe Co. has made itself a part of the community, it is facing multiple challenges as a local small business. Franciotti said the business is not currently making a profit.
The main challenges come from difficulties with staffing, a decrease in consumer spending and rising costs, from operating expenses to card processing fees, she said.
Franciotti said the problems DoCo Axe Co. is facing aren't unique in Cambridge. She said other local business owners she has spoken with are facing similar challenges.
Dorchester Chamber of Commerce President Bill Christopher said finding staffing is one of the biggest challenges local businesses are currently facing.
The reason for this challenge includes a decrease in the workforce during the COVID-19 pandemic, an increase in people retiring early and even a lack of childcare options.
Christopher said that even if a person can find childcare, the cost can be so expensive that it doesn't make sense to work and pay for childcare.
Christopher also said the expectations for people who are graduating school and entering the workforce aren't "level-set with what the economy needs."
"So we've got to attack all three of these things to get the (staffing) problem solved," he said.
Promoting a business and the cost of running a business are two other major challenges local businesses face.
"The dollars and cents," Christopher said. "Because if you find the staff, can you afford them?"
There are multiple ways that people can support DoCo Axe Co. — and not just with a wallet.
Franciotti said learning about the business, having conversations about it, sharing and interacting with social media posts and even clicking on the website to boost its search engine optimization can all benefit DoCo Axe Co.
And for those that have the means to support businesses with their wallet, Christopher said a dollar spent locally goes far in the community.
"You go to DoCo Axe and you spend that dollar, they're going to then use that dollar to pay for other things in the community, so it stays here," he said. "That's the key. Rising tides raise all boats." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Deepening Divides - Democrats Split Over 'Anti-Zionism Is Antisemitism' Measure; Poll Shows U.S. Racial, Generational Differences Over Israel-Hamas War
content:
Deepening Divides - Democrats Split Over 'Anti-Zionism Is Antisemitism' Measure; Poll Shows U.S. Racial, Generational Differences Over Israel-Hamas War

 December 11, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Page: 3 | Section: News 
 
 954
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The U.S. House of Representatives approved a measure Wednesday declaring that "anti-Zionism is antisemitism" prompting a split among Democrats.A majority of House Democrats did not vote for the measure as a public opinion poll from Gallup shows substantial divides among Americans over the Israel-Hamas war in Gaza by age, race and political persuasion.
Whites, older voters and Republicans tend to back Israel in its war against Hamas after the Oct. 7 terror attacks while younger Americans, people of color and Democrats disapprove of Israel's air strikes and ground invasion of Gaza aimed at the Islamic militant group, according to a poll released Nov. 30 by Gallup.
The congressional measure condemning antisemitism passed with support from 216 Republicans and 95 Democrats. The resolution's most controversial component was plank equating anti-Zionism with antisemitism.
Zionism is a movement and belief system that supports the Jewish state of Israel in the Middle East.
"Zionism is the movement for the self-determination and statehood for the Jewish people in their ancestral homeland, the land of Israel," according to the Anti-Defamation League.
Thirteen Democrats voted against the measure and 105 Dems voted 'present' or did not vote neither supporting nor opposing the resolution.
One Republican - U.S.
Rep. Thomas Massie of Kentucky - voted against the anti-Zionism/antisemitism measure. Another four GOP lawmakers did not vote.
"Anti-Zionism isn't antisemitism," Massie said in a social media statement pointing to congressional remarks by U.S. Rep. Jerrold Nadler, D-New York, that some Orthodox and other Jews are not in agreement with modern Zionist constructs.
Nadler, the House's most senior Jewish members, said some Orthodox Jews believe only the Messiah can establish a new state of Israel and the measure can label progressive Jews and others critical of controversial judicial reforms in Israel as antisemitic.
Nadler and U.S. House Majority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, D-New York, were among those voting present on antisemitism measure.
The 13 Democratic no votes came from progressives who have been critical of Israel's war in Gaza against Hamas and U.S. support for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu after the Islamic militant group's Oct. 7 attacks.
Opponents of the measure - which referenced rises antisemitic vandalism and violence - included U.S. Reps. Jamaal Bowman and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York, Rashida Tlaib of Michigan, Ilhan Omar of Minnesota and Pramila Jayapal of Washington "We must be steadfast and clear in condemning antisemitism. The extreme GOP resolution on the floor today had no Democratic cosponsors and inappropriately said all anti-Zionism is antisemitism. Muddying the waters about what antisemitism is, is completely wrong and unhelpful," said Jayapal who had to clarify recent comments about whether she condemned Hamas' rapes and violence against women and girls in the Oct. 7.
GOP SUPPORTS MEASURE U.S. Rep. Andy Harris, a Republican representing the Eastern Shore, voted for the antisemitism measure along with Maryland Democratic U.S. Reps.
Steny Hoyer, David Trone, Dutch Ruppersberger and Kweisi Mfume. Maryland Democratic U.S. Rep. Jamie Raskin and John Sarbanes voted present.
House Republicans overwhelmingly backed the resolution which labels some pro-Palestinian slogans as antisemitic.
"More Jews were murdered on October 7th than on any other single day since the Holocaust.
Let that sink in. We have even seen members of this very body repeat blatantly antisemitic rhetoric and spread lies about Israel and her right to exist. Let me be absolutely clear: such hate has no place in the halls of Congress nor our national discourse. It is our fundamental responsibility as leaders and Members of Congress to condemn and fight these horrific acts of hate and discrimination against the Jewish community," said U.S. Rep. David Kustoff, R-Tennessee, one of the main sponsors of the resolution.
GOP backers of the measure point to a rise in antisemitic incidents and pro-Hamas and pro-Palestinian rhetoric that calls for or insinuates the destruction of Israel. They also point to the 106 no or present that did not support the measure - 105 of them from Democrat.
"The world has seen a drastic rise of antisemitism since October 7th that is deeply disheartening and extremely concerning," said U.S. Max Miller, R-Ohio. "Elected leaders must have the courage to condemn and fight all forms of domestic and global antisemitism.
While I am glad this resolution passed the House today, I am disappointed that 106 of my colleagues failed to take this opportunity to condemn antisemitism forcefully." AMERICA DIVIDED The Gallup poll released Nov. 30 shows significant splits over the Holy Land war by race, political party and gender.
The polls shows 71% of Republicans back Israel's war against Hamas in Gaza versus support from 36% of Democrats.
Fifty nine percent of men approve of Israel's war in Gaza versus 44% of women, according the Gallup Among people of color, 64% disapprove of Israel's attacks against Hamas in Gaza while 61% of whites backs Netanyahu's efforts to dismantle the militant group.
There is a similar split my age with 67% of younger Americans (ages 18 to 34) disapproving of Israel's war against Hamas and 63% of voters 55 and older backing the Israel Defense Forces' military effort.
Palestinian health authorities in Hamas-controlled Gaza say more than 17,000 people have died since Holy Land war stared in October Israeli officials say Hamas fighters killed more than 1,200 people and took more than 240 hostages in the Oct. 7 terror attacks. 
 
 Caption: ASSOCIATED PRESS

title: YMCA back to normal operations after Saturday fires
author: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com
content:
YMCA back to normal operations after Saturday fires

 January 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 559
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Peter Hyman was in his gym clothes and already on his way to the YMCA on Peachblossom Road around noon on Saturday when he learned there had been a fire at the Y.When he arrived moments later, Hyman, who is president of the YMCA's board, said he saw members of the community and Y staff gathering, many visibly upset by the event.
"The staff was upset. It was an upsetting moment, and I just did what I could to help both in terms of the emotions of the folks as well as the physical reality of the situation," he said Sunday morning.
The fire, which involved a second-floor closet at the Y, was one of two that the Easton Volunteer Fire Department and other departments responded to at the YMCA Saturday, according to Easton Fire Chief JR Dobson.
At around 5:30 p.m., firefighters were once again called to the Y, where an HVAC unit was on fire on the building's roof.
Neither fire resulted in any extensive damage to the building, according to YMCA of the Chesapeake CEO Robbie Gill.
Dobson said the first fire was extinguished by the Y's sprinkler system before firefighters arrived at the scene. The second fire was quickly extinguished by firefighters using a fire extinguisher after gas feeding the HVAC unit was shut off, the fire chief said.
The fires closed the Y for the remainder of Saturday, but regular operations resumed Sunday morning with all facilities but the racquetball courts open for use. The racquetball courts were largely undamaged, Gill said, but due to their proximity to the first fire, a sprinkler had gone off over them, meaning they had to be closed Sunday while staff worked to dry the area.
"We were fortunate there wasn't a substantial amount of damage to the building," Gill said. "And now we're working with local authorities to provide any information we can to help them investigate."
While the second fire's cause was ruled by the Office of the State Fire Marshal to have been a mechanical failure with the HVAC unit, Dobson said, the cause of the first fire is still under investigation.
Gill said the first fire is not believed to have been caused by any mechanical or similar failure.
Though the fires did not cause extensive damage to the facilities, Hyman said the events were particularly upsetting for Y staff and regulars because of the role the YMCA plays in the Easton community.
"We're lucky," he said. "Our YMCA is not just a place to work out and exercise. It really is a community. It's a very wonderful group of people… I've been a member of the Y for years, and it really is a community across cultures, all kinds of folks. And it's a really special place."
Dobson said multiple departments, including the Easton, Oxford and Trappe volunteer fire departments and Talbot County Emergency Services, responded to the events Saturday. These departments worked with staff and others on the scene to evacuate the building and secure the area.
Gill said although Saturday was "a little bit of a traumatic day," the coordinated community response to the fires served as a reminder of the importance of the YMCA.
"The Y has been around for 168 years, so it's an institution in the community that serves one in three people, and it's wonderful to see so many people care for it at that level," Gill said.

title: GREENSBORO TOWN COUNCIL/ Sept. 18, 2025
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
GREENSBORO TOWN COUNCIL/ Sept. 18, 2025

 September 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 344
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO – At the Sept. 18 Greensboro Town Council meeting, the following actions were taken:William Schaffner, vice president of the Greensboro Historical Society, thanked the councilmembers and the Greensboro Public Works team for assisting the Historical Society with its move. Schaffner mentioned the Historical Society would need a temporary space due to ongoing repairs at its new building and requested consideration from the commissioners.Town officials announced all four police cruisers have been lettered, two with ghost lettering and two with regular lettering.Officials said a meeting with the Maryland Department of the Environment and Caroline County regarding the old wastewater treatment plant indicated MDE is making it mandatory to annex the property into town limits.Officials said the first phase of the Sutton Park project, funded by a $250,000 Department of Natural Resources grant, is expected to begin in October.Ordinance 2025-0-06, regarding weeds, grass, refuse and waste, was passed.Resolution 25-R-02, a resolution to annex land at 13514 Greensboro Road, where the old pump station was located, was introduced. The resolution requires a referral to the Planning Commission and a public hearing.Resolution 2025-R-03, a resolution to authorized the town manager to execute necessary agreements for the relocation of the wastewater pump station project and stream bank restoration, was passed.Ordinance 2025-O-07, an ordinance eliminating an administrative fee and establishing a 2% monthly fee for Goldsboro, was introduced.Ordinance 2025-O-08, an ordinance to amend the zoning map to apply the essential government practices zoning district to the property at 13514 Greensboro Road upon annexation, was introduced.The councilmembers elected to not move forward with "Whoville," a Christmas holiday event. The cancelation came after discussion of time and money spent. Town Manager Cindy Yost revealed a loss of money and an attendance drop from 3,005 in 2023 to 875 in 2024. The town will allow residents to propose ideas for alternative events to be held.The council voted to move the regular October meeting from the third Thursday to the first Thursday, Oct. 2, and flip the workshop to Oct. 16, with a potential special meeting on the third Thursday if needed.
